div1.p: CENTRAL CRIMINAL COURT
Sessions Paper.
SAVORY, MAYOR.
TWELFTH SESSION, HELD OCTOBER 19TH, 1891.
MINUTES OF EVIDENCE.
TAKEN IN SHORT-HAND, BY
JAMES DROVER BARNETT
AND
ALEXANDER BUCKLER,
Short-hand Writers to the Court,
ROLLS CHAMBERS, No. 89, CHANCERY LANE.
THE POINTS OF LAW AND PRACTICE
REVISED AND EDITED BY
EDWARD T. E. BESLEY, ESQ.,
OF THE MIDDLE TEMPLE, BARRISTER-AT-LAW.
LONDON:
STEVENS AND SONS, LIMITED, 119, CHANCERY LANE.
Law Booksellers and Publishers.
THE
WHOLE PROCEEDINGS
On the Queen's Commission of
OYER AND TERMINER AND GAOL DELIVERY
FOR
The City of London,
AND GAOL DELIVERY FOR THE
COUNTY OF MIDDLESEX AND THE PARTS OF THE COUNTIES OF ESSEX, KENT, AND SURREY, WITHIN THE JURISDICTION
OF THE
CENTRAL CRIMINAL COURT
Held on Monday, October 19th, 1891, and following days.*

BEFORE the RIGHT HON.
JOSEPH SAVORY, LORD MAYOR of the City of London; the Hon. Sir
ROBERT SAMUEL WEIGHT , Knt., one of the Justices of Her Majesty's High Court of Justice; Sir
JAMES CLARKE LAWRENCE , Bart., Sir
POLYDORE DE KEYSER , Knt., Aldermen of the said City; Sir
THOMAS CHAMBERS , Knt., Q.C., Recorder of the said City;
PHINEAS COWAN , Esq.,
STUART KNILL , Esq.,
WALTER HENRY WILKIN , Esq., GEORGE FAUDEL PHILLIPS, Esq.,
HORATIO DAVID DAVIES , Esq., JNO. VOCE MOORE, Esq.,
ALFRED JAMES NEWTON , Esq., and
JAMES THOMSON RITCHIE , Esq., other of the Aldermen of the said City; and Sir
WILLIAM THOMAS CHARLEY , Knt., Q.C., D.C.L., Common Serjeant of the said City; Her Majesty's Justices of Oyer and Terminer and General Gaol Delivery, holden for the said City, and Judges of the Central Criminal Court.
GEORGE ROBERT TYLER , Esq., Alderman.
HARRY SEYMOUR FOSTER , Esq.
FREDERICK HILL , Esq.
CLARENCE RICHARD HALSE, Esq.
*Also cases removed to this Court under the Order in Council.
SAVORY, MAYOR. TWELFTH SESSION.

A star (*) denotes that prisoners have been previously in custodyâ€”two stars (**) that they have been more than ones in custodyâ€”a dagger (â€ ) that they are known to be the associates of bad charactersâ€”the figures after the name in the indictment denote the prisoner's age,
LONDON AND MIDDLESEX CASES.

764.
THOMAS LIDDIARD (29),
CHARLES NOLL (23),
ALFRED HUTCHINSON (36), and
CHARLES HASTIE (35) were indicted for
a robbery with violence on
Joseph Webb, and stealing Â£8 14s.; Second Count charged Hutchinson and Hastie with feloniously receiving the same.

MR. CHARLES MATHEWS ,
for the Prosecution, offered no evidence against Hutchinson and Hastie, who were Acquitted.
MR. WARBURTON defended Liddiard.

JOSEPH WEBB . I am Band-sergeant on board Her Majesty's ship Rodney, which is in dry dock at Chathamâ€”on the night of 2nd September I was in London; I went to the Britannia Theatre, in Hoxtonâ€”at the end of the performance I left, and on getting into the street some person came up and spoke to me, and in consequence of what he said I went with him to what I believed to be a public-house, in Central Street, St. Luke's; I have since heard that it is called the Central Clubâ€”when I got there I saw the prisoners Liddiard, Noll, and Hastie; they were not togetherâ€”Noll was sitting on a bench on my left; Liddiard was standing, and Hastie was in a cornerâ€”the third man, who took me in, was nearer the barâ€”they were not very far from each other; the place is very-smallâ€”I wanted to get away directly I got inâ€”Liddiard and the third man called for drink; they were all drinking togetherâ€”I paid for it; the third man generally called for it; Liddiard, Noll, and the third man drank itâ€”Hastie was not in our company at allâ€”afterwards something was said about closing timeâ€”I wanted to get out two or three times, but they said, "All right, no hurry yet," so I remained on till closing timeâ€”they all left together, but I walked on ahead; I wanted to get a bedâ€”Hastie had left about twenty minutes beforeâ€”I had got on about one hundred yards when the third man came up, touched me on the shoulder, and said, "Do you accuse me of putting my hand in your pocket?"â€”I said, "Certainly not; you know who I spoke to, and who I

caught hold of," and I pointed to Noll; but I said, "There's no harm done; I want to get a bed, and I wish you good night"â€”Noll had put his hand in my left overcoat pocket twice in the house, and I said to him, "Don't keep doing that; if you want to rob me you will have to face me"â€”the third time he did it I caught hold of his wrist, and said, "If you want anything to drink, or if you want a shilling I will give it you, but don't try to steal"â€”he said he was not trying to stealâ€”everybody there could hear what was saidâ€”I was quite soberâ€”when I left the house I had a Â£5 note and Â£3 in gold in an Admiralty envelope in my inside overcoat pocketâ€”I changed a sovereign in the house to pay for the drink; I took it from the envelope, and had fourteen shillings change, which I put in my trousers pocketâ€”after the third man spoke to me I turned round and saw the two prisoners; the third man struck me in the mouth and knocked me down, bleedingâ€”I got up and started to defend myself; I could see clearly that I was among thieves; Noll struck me a sly blow in the mouth and knocked me down again, and Liddiard gave me a kick behind the ear when I was on the ground, and I had a big lump there next day; the third man then said, "Now for his pockets"; one of them was trying âœ— pocket, and he said, "You big fool, it is not there"â€”the third married all my pockets, and literally turned them outâ€”he took the silver from my trousers pocket, and put his hand in my overcoat pocket and took the money out of thatâ€”then one of them said, "Let's finish it, and make a job of it"â€”I said, "I am going to stick to one of you," and I sang out, "Murder" and "Police"â€”the police came up directlyâ€”I became a little dazed, and was bleeding, and had several punches about the bodyâ€”I stuck to Liddiard till the police came upâ€”the third man got away, he was the one that knelt on my chest and took the money out of my pocketâ€”I was wearing a hat; this (produced) is it, it has my name inside, it came off in the struggleâ€”I said to the policeman, "I have lost my hat"â€”Liddiard, or one of them, said it was his hatâ€”I went to the station and gave the prisoners in custody; they were searched, a sixpence and a penny was found on Liddiard, and on Noll two shillings and sixpence in silver and a penny in bronzeâ€”the third man who got away had my money.

Cross-examined. Before going to the Britannia I had been walking about, nowhere in particular; I had never been in London before; I had been in one public-house and had a glass of ale, at the bar at the theatre I had two moreâ€”when I came out of the theatre I asked a boy the way to a lodging-house, and then the man came up and spoke to me and took me to this club; he was rather a well-spoken man and decently dressedâ€”I paid for drink in the place; they had gin, I had two or three glasses of ale, nothing elseâ€”I thought I was going to a club, but I found it was nothing but a den of thieves, and I wanted to get out; I thought by my generosity they might let me swing clear of itâ€”I am quite sure that I had my money about me when I went into the houseâ€”I could not swear that Liddiard spoke to me in the houseâ€”Noll kept feeling in my pocket, but he did not take my money, because I felt it in my pocketâ€”it was about a quarter-past eleven when I came out of the theatre, and it was a little before two when I came out of the club; I was in there all that timeâ€”I asked them several times to let me out; the door was boltedâ€”there was no fighting in the houseâ€”it is in rather a narrow streetâ€”this
is my hatâ€”I don't know what sort of hat Liddiard was wearingâ€”the men did not treat me; they all drank out of the same mug.

RICHARD FENNIMORE (G 260). At half-past two in the morning of 3rd of September I was on duty in Central Streetâ€”I heard shouts of "Murder" and "Police"â€”I ran in the direction; Brown 316 was on the spot before meâ€”I saw the two prisoners there; Noll was being held by a policemanâ€”the prosecutor was standing there, bleeding from the nose and mouthâ€”Liddiard had a hat in his handâ€”he dropped itâ€”Brown picked it upâ€”the prosecutor claimed it, and his name was insideâ€”we took the prisoners to the station, where they were charged and searched, and on them a small sum of money was found.

Cross-examined. Brown is not hereâ€”Liddiard made no attempt to run away; he went quietly to the stationâ€”I did not see any other hat on the groundâ€”this is the sort of hat generally worn by people of this classâ€”the night was darkâ€”this occurred just alongside a lampâ€”I did not see anything of the stout man who got away.

GUILTY .â€”
Twelve Months' Hard Labour each.

765.
JOHN SQUIRES (21)
PLEADED GUILTY to a burglary in the dwelling-house of
George Augustus Johns, and stealing postal orders and other goods.â€”
Nine Months' Hard Labour.

766.
HENRY WOODS LUNN (21)
, to stealing, whilst employed in the Post Office, a parcel containing property of the
Postmaster-General.â€”
Three Years' Penal Servitude.
[Pleaded guilty: See original trial image.]

767.
MATTHEW ANDERSON (51)
, to stealing letters whilst in the employ of the Post Office.â€”
Three Years' Penal Servitude.
[Pleaded guilty: See original trial image.]

768.
JAMES WILLIAM TYE (27)
, to a like offence.â€”
Fifteen Months' Hard Labour.
[Pleaded guilty: See original trial image.]

769.
ERNEST EDWARD HOLMES (32)
, to a like offence.â€”
Twelve Months' Hard Labour.
[Pleaded guilty: See original trial image.] And

(770),
HENRY EDWARD VIVEASH (42)
, to a like offence.â€”
Nine Months' Hard Labour.
[Pleaded guilty: See original trial image.]

771.
JASPER ARTHUR ARMSTRONG (39)
PLEADED GUILTY to stealing Â£176, the money of the
Bank of South Africa, his masters.

p.hi:
The prosecutors recommended the prisoner to mercy. He received a food character.â€”
Judgment respited.

div1.p:
772.
JOHN SMITH (19)
PLEADED GUILTY
to stealing part of a chain from the person of
Joseph Thorpe; and
GEORGE JEFFS (17) (indicted with John Smith)
to stealing a chain and medal from the person of
John Handley. A police officer stated that the prisoners had borne good characters.â€”
One Day's Imprisonment each.

773.
HERMANN JAEGER (40)
, Stealing fifty-one yards of flannel, the goods of
William Henry Powell; Second Count, receiving the same.

HENRY WOODWORTH . I am a porter to Mr. Powell, a manufacturer, of 4, Edmonds Place, Aldersgate Streetâ€”on 7th October, at half-past three, I was on the third floor, and I heard a noiseâ€”I rushed downstair and saw the prisoner standing on the staircase with a piece of flannel; he is not employed in the warehouse, and had no business thereâ€”he did not see me coining; I made no noise coming downâ€”he then took the flannel into the warehouse and put it in the proper place to which it belonged, and from which it had been takenâ€”I don't remember what I said to himâ€”he said, "A big man has run away with this, and I am

taking it back"â€”he walked to the counter and picked up a pattern of flannels, and said he wanted to buy some capesâ€”I asked his name; he said he was Mr. Hartâ€”we don't sell capes, he did not buy anythingâ€”I detained him till Mr. Powell came in, and then he sent me for a policemanâ€”there were fifty-one and a half yards of flannel, value about Â£2 10s., in the parcel I saw the prisoner withâ€”he had no authority to remove it from its placeâ€”no one else was thereâ€”I had not heard anyone run downstairs, if anyone had done so I should have heard him.

WILLIAM CUSHING (City 202). I was called to take the prisoner for stealing this flannelâ€”he said he was going up the stairs when he met this big burly man coming downstairs with the roll of flannel, and he threw it at him and ran awayâ€”he gave his name at the station as Hermann Jaeger, of 36, Commercial Road; he did not live thereâ€”I did not hear him give the name of Hartâ€”I have made inquiries, but cannot find out anything about him.

The prisoner, in his defence, said he went to see Mr. Geissler, who was represented by Mr. Powell, and that a man coming downstairs with the parcel dropped it, and that he (the prisoner) picked it up; and he added that the policeman saw the man run away.

GUILTY .â€”
Six Months' Hard Labour.

774.
EXELBY DAULBY (23)
, Unlawfully uttering counterfeit coin.

ARTHUR POWELL . I am barman at the Bell public-house, Pall Mallâ€”on October 7th, about 3.30 p.m., I served the prisoner with half a pint of aleâ€”he gave me a florinâ€”I put it in my mouth and broke it, and said, "Where did you get this from? "â€”he said, "In change across the counter"â€”I said, "I shall have to call the manageress," and went towards the barmaidâ€”he could not hear what I said to her, but he went out quicklyâ€”I ran after him, and found him stopped by a policemanâ€”I said that he had tendered a counterfeit florinâ€”he said nothingâ€”I took him to the stationâ€”before he left the house I said, "I will take the money for the ale, please?"â€”he gave me a good shilling, and I gave him 1s. 6d. and fivepenceâ€”that was before he ran awayâ€”I gave the pieces of coin to the manageress, who gave them to the constable.
Cross-examined by the Prisoner. I saw your back going out very quickly, and I ran out at the other door.

WALTER MARSHALL (C 55). On October 7th, about 3.30, I was in St. James's Square, and saw the prisoner running very fast from the Bell towards me, and Powell following him, calling, "Stop him!"â€”I closed on him, and Stopped him before Mr. Powell came upâ€”he said, "All right; I will go back"â€”nothing had been said to him at that time; Mr. Powell then came up, and said he had been passing counterfeit coin, and asked me to take him back to the public-houseâ€”the prisoner said nothing; he was taken to the Bell, and then to the station, where I searched him, and found one shilling and sixpence in silver, and eightpenceâ€”these two pieces of a florin were handed to me.
Cross-examined. You did not stop ten or twelve yards from meâ€”before any charge was made you said, "All right; I will go back"â€”I stopped you twenty yards from the Bell.

EMILY YOUNG . I am barmaid at the Crown, Albert Embankmentâ€”on 16th September I served the prisoner with a glass of ale; he gave me a half-crown; it looked rather funny and was greasyâ€”I saw it tested in a brass tester on the till, and it broke into four or five piecesâ€”I took it to the manageress, who took it to Mr. Bell, who said to the prisoner, "Did you know it was a bad one?"â€”he said, "I did not"â€”Mr. Bell said, "Who do you work for?"â€”he said, "Nobody"â€”I asked him his nameâ€”he said, "William Wood"â€”I did not hear him give any address.

JOHN EDWARDS (L 81). On September 16th Mr. Bell called me and said, "The man has tendered a counterfeit half-crown," and showed me the four piecesâ€”I said, "How did you come by it?"â€”he made no replyâ€”I asked him who he was; he said, "I gave my address to Mr. Bell, and he wrote it on a paper"â€”Mr. Boll gave me a paper, and said that was the name he received from the prisonerâ€”I have a copy of it hereâ€”I searched him, and found 5s. 6d. good silver and some bronzeâ€”he was taken to the station and charged; he made no replyâ€”he gave his name, William Daulby, 4, Borough Roadâ€”I found that correctâ€”he was taken before a Magistrate next day, and remanded, and discharged, there being only one uttering against himâ€”I produce the four pieces of coin; the inspector took them, and they were handed to the Mint authoritiesâ€”Mr. bell has left the. public-house, and I cannot find him.
WILLIAM JOHN WEBSTER . I am an Inspector of Coin to the Mintâ€”this florin is a counterfeitâ€”a coin breaking in four pieces is a test of its being bad, and that is coupled with the greasiness.
The prisoner's statement before the Magistrate: All I can say is I took them in common exchange; I was not aware they were bad."

He received a good character.
GUILTY .â€”Strongly recommended to mercy by the JURY on account of his youth.â€”
Judgment respited.

775.
FREDERICK CLARK (26) and
WILLIAM THOMAS SMITH (24)
PLEADED GUILTY
to stealing a roll of oilcloth in the dwelling-house of
James Henderson; also
to stealing a barrow, the property of
James Milton.â€”
Six Months' Hard Labour each.

776.
EMILY WATSON, Unlawfully
endeavouring to conceal the birth of her child, MR. BLACK, for the Prosecution, offered no evidence.
NOT GUILTY .

777.
SAMUEL OCKENDEN
PLEADED GUILTY to feloniously marry
ing
Alice Constable, his wife being then alive.â€”
Two Days' Imprisonment.

778.
JOSEPH TURNER (17)
to a burglary in the dwelling-house of
Frederick Brown, and stealing 1s.; and to a previous conviction of felony.
Three Months' Hard Labour.
[Pleaded guilty: See original trial image.]

779.
ARTHUR GEORGE DIXON (35)
to burglary in the dwelling-house of
Harry Dixon and stealing four bottles of beer; also to a previous conviction.â€”
Four Months' Hard

780.
HENRY MANNING (35)
to unlawfully obtaining nine mufflers from
William Smale, and goods from
Lester George Simpson.â€”
Nine Months Hard Labour.
[Pleaded guilty: See original trial image.] And

(781).
FRANK GRAHAM (19)
to feloniously breaking and entering the shop of
Julius Ulman and stealing three necklaces and a muffineer, and Â£12.â€”
Two Days' Imprisonment.
[Pleaded guilty: See original trial image.]

782.
HARRY WALLIS (23)
, Robbery with violence, with another person, on
Walter Coupland, and stealing a watch and Â£1 15s.

WALTER COUPLAND . I am a labourer, and live at 21, Elm Park, Brixton Hillâ€”on the night of 22nd September, a little after nine, I saw the prisoner in the Railway Hotel in Altantic Roadâ€”he asked me to treat him; I did soâ€”I had a drink of mild and bitter; he had aleâ€”I had three drinks, all beerâ€”I did not notice any other man thereâ€”I went out and went towards home; the prisoner followed meâ€”I went into the White Horse; he followed me in and asked me again to treat himâ€”I did not; I had some beerâ€”when I left the prisoner followed me; I crossed the road, and I was then seized by two menâ€”they knocked my hat over a fence, took me by the legs and threw me over the fence, and then jumped upon me and kicked me in the side, and gripped me by the throatâ€”the prisoner was one of the menâ€”I don't remember what occurred afterwards until I saw the prisoner brought back by two gentlemen and a policemanâ€”I lost a sovereign from my left pocket, and half a sovereign, and 5s. in silver from my right pocket, and a five cent, pieceâ€”this is the coin.
Cross-examined. I did not pull the coin out of my pocket in the public-house, nor did I see you pick it up; I know the coin by a hole which I made in it with my penknife.

THOMAS GREGORY . I am a builder and live at 30, Fentiman-road, Kenningtonâ€”on the night of 22nd September I saw the prisoner over a fence at the lower part of Brixton Hill; I heard faint cries of "Police," and I went across and looked over the fence and saw two men kneeling down; one of them was leaning on the prosecutor's head, and the prisoner was stooping over the lower part; the prosecutor was lying on the groundâ€”the man that has got away had him by the throatâ€”I could not see clearly whether the prisoner was hurting the prosecutor; the prisoner ran one way, and the other the otherâ€”the prisoner was nearest to me, and I went after him along Brixton Hill; his boot came off, and I saw him limping; he ran round the corner; another witness took up the chase, and stopped him; I was close behind himâ€”I said, "You will have to come back "â€”he said, "It was a fair fight; what the b----hell do you know about it?"â€”I took him back, and on our way back a boy said, "Here is a boot," and the prisoner picked it up and put it onâ€”when we got back I saw the prosecutor lying down just over the fenceâ€”some one said, "Get an ambulance; the man is dying"â€”the police attended to him a few minutes, and he came to, and said, "Where is my watch, and where is my money?"â€”his pockets were turned inside outâ€”the prisoner said to him, "Hullo, Walter; you are all right, are you not?"â€”the policeman said to the prosecutor, "Do you know this man?"â€”he said, "Yes; he has got my money"â€”the prisoner said, Somebody threw my hat over, and I got over for it"â€”the prosecutor had been drinking.

HENRY JAMES BRAND . I am a paperhanger, at 333, Lyam Road, Brixtonâ€”on the night of the 22nd of September, about twenty minutes to eleven, I heard faint cries of "Police"; I stood for a moment, and saw the last witness going across the road towards the fenceâ€”I followed himâ€”I saw two men, the prisoner being one of them, jump over the fence into the laneâ€”I gave chase, and caught him about two hundred yards offâ€”he had his waistcoat on, but no jacketâ€”he asked me what I wantedâ€”I told him he would have to go to the stationâ€”with the aid of the last witness I took him back to where the prosecutor was lying.

CHRISTOPHER ANGEL (W 584). On the night of the 22nd September, about a quarter to eleven, I was on duty on Brixton Hillâ€”I saw a crowd, and found the prisoner detained by the two last witnessesâ€”I looked over the fence, and saw the prosecutor lying on his back in the field; his trousers pockets were turned inside outâ€”he was in a dazed conditionâ€”when he came to he looked round and saw the prisonerâ€”he said, "He and another threw me over the fence, and took my watch and money "â€”I said, "Do you wish to charge him?"â€”he said, "Yes"â€”the prisoner said, "I got over the fence to look for this man's hat; I am not afraid to go to the station"â€”I took him to the station, searched him, and found on him a half-sovereign and ninepence-halfpenny in bronze, and this small silver coin; the prisoner said it was a threepenny-piece, but I found it was a five cent, piece, and the prosecutor immediately identified it as hisâ€”the prisoner was perfectly sober; the prosecutor was under the influence of drinkâ€”I could not see any bruises about him; he did not complain, or want medical assistanceâ€”the prisoner made no reply to the charge.

p.hi:
The prisoner, in his defence, alleged that he had been drinking with the pro
secutor and others; that the prosecutor lost his hat, and insisted on having the prisoner's hat; that a quarrel ensued, and when the police came up he thought it best to get away.

div1.p: DAVID JENKINS . I am a coal porter, but have lately been acting as a potmanâ€”on Tuesday, 22nd September, I was in the Railway Tavern about six o'clockâ€”I saw the prisoner there; I left about half-past eight, leaving the prisoner thereâ€”I saw him with a coinâ€”I did not see what it was; I did not see him pick it up.

GUILTY â€”
Nine Months' Hard Labour

783.
WILLIAM HENRY FENELEY (25)
, Burglary in dwelling-house of
John Thomas Hart, and stealing a clock, and other things, his property; Second Count, receiving the same.

ALICE DOLTRY . I am maid-servant to Mr. Hart, of Queen's Road, South Hornseyâ€”on 15th September I fastened up the premises previous to going to bed; I pulled down the blind in the front parlour, but did not latch the windowâ€”the flower-box was in the usual place on the window-sill, and all the things were safe in my master's roomâ€”I went to bed between ten and half-pastâ€”I came down next morning at half-past sevenâ€”when I came down next morning the blind was up, and the box was taken away from the window, and was on the ground outsideâ€”this clock and certain articles which had been there the night before were missingâ€”some of the articles have since been shown to me by the police, and I have identified themâ€”the value of them is about Â£6â€”my master's

brother called in the policeâ€”on the morning of 12th September the prisoner called, and said, "Your window has been left open all night," and he said that he and the policeman shut it at half-past fourâ€”it had not been left open, but was fastened on that nightâ€”he then leftâ€”I had not seen him before thatâ€”after he had left on that occasion I missed a hairbrush that had been on the window-sill.
Cross-examined by the Prisoner. I did not pick you out from othersâ€”I saw you in Court, and knew you.

THOMAS FIELD . I am manager to Mr. Bowman, a pawnbroker, of 292, Holloway Roadâ€”I produce a table-cover and five silver teaspoons, which were offered in pledge about half-past eight on the morning of 16th September by Strattonâ€”I did not take them, but detained them, and gave information to the policeâ€”the articles have since been identified by Mr. Hart and Alice Doltry.
WILLIAM MORLEY . I am manager to Charles Coley, 286, Hollowly Road, pawnbrokerâ€”about half-past eight on 16th September Alice Stratton pledged this clock with us.

JOHN HITCHCOCK . I am assistant to George Fish, pawnbroker, of 46, Hornsey Roadâ€”this pair of sugar tones, butter knife, and two saltspoons wore pledged with us on 18th September in the name of Ann Martinâ€”I do not know who she is.

ALICE STRATTON . I am a single woman and a general servantâ€”I used to live at 10, Brand Street, Hornsey Road, with the prisonerâ€”on the morning of 16th September he went out about four o'clock, saying he was going to Queen's Road, and he came back about six with a parcel in his handâ€”he said, "I have brought the things here "â€”I said, "Where did you get them from?"â€”he said, "I got them from Queen's Road"â€”I said, "Won't you get in trouble for bringing these things?" and he said, "No; that will be all right"â€”he said, "Be quick and have your breakfast; I want you to go out for me"â€”he said he wanted me to pawn there things which he had brought inâ€”I did soâ€”I went with the clock to the pawnbroker's near the Holloway Road, and with other things to Mr. Field's, William Morley's, and John Hitchcock's.

Cross-examined. I said at the Police-court that you went out between five and six, and returned at six; I have said now you went out at four and returned at six because it is as near as I can guessâ€”we reached home at about two o'clock on the mornings of the 16th.

SUSAN JEFFREYS . I am the wife of John Jeffreys, a musical instrument manufacturer, of 309, Goswell Roadâ€”about the middle of last month the prisoner brought in a metronome, and offered it to me for sale, and wanted to know the value of itâ€”I declined to buy itâ€”as he left the shop there was a woman outside; I do not know who she wasâ€”some days afterwards the detectives came to me.

Cross-examined. You told me you had this instrument to sell for another party, who wanted 3s. 6d. for it, but you wanted to make a bit for yourselfâ€”the police came to me before I identified youâ€”I dictated this statement to the officerâ€”they said they had you in custody, and I told them what I knew about itâ€”I saw you before I signed it; I could not say whether you came to me before or after the 16thâ€”the constable did not tell me what man to identifyâ€”I identified you at Newgate; I don't think he made any remark.

ELIAS BARR (Detective Sergeant N). About four p. m. on 21st Sep
tember

I went, in consequence of information, to a room at 10, Brand Street, where the prisoner had livedâ€”there I found a white table-cloth and two knives, and a piece of wire fixed in a wooden handleâ€”the tablecloth and knives have been identified as the property of John Thomas Hartâ€”I was present when Mrs. Jeffreys identified the prisoner as the man who offered the metronome for saleâ€”she had no difficulty in picking him outâ€”I arrested Alice Stratton, but she Was afterwards discharged at the Police-courtâ€”the prisoner gave the address at 10, Brand Street, when he was charged.

ALICE STRATTON (Re-examined by the Prisoner). We took this room on the 14thâ€”on the night of the 15th I went with you round Queensland Roadâ€”on the morning of the 18th I went out, leaving you in bed; you had not been out that morningâ€”I could not exactly tell the day of the month.
By the COURT. The day I went out leaving him in bed was not the day that he had been out and come back.
JOHN LYNCH (Y 141). I took the prisoner into custody on this charge at 12.30 on the morning of the 17thâ€”I told him the chargeâ€”he made no answer.

p.hi: The prisoner, in his defence, said that Stratton had brought the things home, and that he never saw them till they were in Court.

div1.p: GUILTY .

He PLEADED GUTLTY** to a conviction of felony in June, 1889, in the name of
Henry Hill.

784.
CHARLES JOHNSON (13)
PLEADED GUILTY to unlawfully attempting to carnally know
May Batt, aged eleven years.â€”
Judgment Respited.

785.
HENRY WRIGHT** (67)
, To four indictments to forging uttering and cheques for Â£57, Â£22 10s., Â£19, and Â£34 15s., after a conviction of forgery at this Court in March, 1890, in the name of
James Henry Norman; also
to three indictments for obtaining Â£1 13s., Â£1 1s., 5s., and a jewel-case, by false pretences.â€”
Three Years' Penal Servitude.
[Pleaded guilty: See original trial image.]

786.
CHARLES BATE (43)
, To unlawfully obtaining goods, Value Â£105 0s. 7d., within four months of his bankruptcy.â€”
Two Months' Without Hard Labour.
[Pleaded guilty: See original trial image.] And

(787).
FRANCIS ELWOOD** (57)
, To forging and uttering an order for Â£5; also
another order for Â£5, with intent to defraud, having been convicted of felonious uttering on May 19th, 1890. Seven previous convictions of forgery were proved against him.â€”
Three Years' Penal Servitude.
[Pleaded guilty: See original trial image.]

788.
ALFRED COLLINS (21)
, Stealing a purse and 11s. 6d., of
Margaret Wagstaff, from her person.

MARGARET WAGSTAFF . I am assistant to my brother, who is in the refreshment department at Whitehallâ€”on December 12th I took an omnibus to the Bank, going eastâ€”I got inside, and sat on the left side, second from the door; there was a lady between me and the doorâ€”there were four persons on each sideâ€”the prisoner sat next me on my right, third from the doorâ€”he got indirectly after meâ€”I paid my fare, and. put my purse in my right pocketâ€”his

companion was next to him, and they kept pushing me aboutâ€”as one moved the other movedâ€”I afterwards put my hand in my pocket, and my purse was there, but when I got to the middle of Houndsditch they got out, and I felt in my pocket and it was goneâ€”I told the conductor, who went after the prisonerâ€”my purse had 11s. 6d. in silver in itâ€”this is it (produced).

Cross-examined. There was a ring in the purse that was not mineâ€”I carried my handkerchief and keys in the same pocketâ€”my pocket opens a little sometimes when I sit downâ€”the roads were all up, but they were not rather stonyâ€”the omnibus did not rock to and fro.
Re-examined. I looked round directly I missed it, and it was not in the omnibusâ€”there was no straw at the bottom.

GEORGE RICHARD STAMP . I am an omnibus conductorâ€”on September 1st I was on the omnibus which passed the Bank about 4.45 p.m., and saw the prosecutrix get in, the prisoner and another young man get on top, but two or three minutes afterwards they came down and got inside, and the prisoner sat next the prosecutrixâ€”I saw the prisoner pushing aboutâ€”they got out at St. Mary Axe, one after the otherâ€”they appeared to be togetherâ€”the prosecutrix made a communication to me, and I took the prisonerâ€”he said, "What do you want?"â€”I said, "A lady wants you in the 'bus," and took him thereâ€”he said, "It was not me, my work mate did it"â€”I detained him.

Cross-examined. There were two people on the left side and three on the off side; it would be wrong to say that there were four on each sideâ€”they got hitching up towards the ladyâ€”the prisoner had got two dozen yards when I stopped himâ€”he said, "My workmate might do it, it was not me"â€”I did not see the prisoner pass anything to anyoneâ€”I believe he gave a correct address.

WILLIAM PLACE (952 City). I took the prisoner; he said he did not steal the purse; I know the Other man as an old shopmateâ€”I took him to the station, and found on him 7s. 4Jd in a purseâ€”he had this ring on his finger.
Cross-examined. He gave his correct address in Brick Laneâ€”he said, "I did not steal the purse"â€”I found a small pipe on him.
The prisoner's statement before the Magistrate: "I don't know anything about the purse."
NOT GUILTY .

789.
HENRY BREADMORE
, for the manslaughter of
Esther Brinson.

ARTHUR BRINSON . I am a firewood-cutter, and live in Kentish Townâ€”on the night of 7th September, between nine and ten, I was returning from Barnet Fair with my wife in a little gigâ€”we had got past the Swan at Finchleyâ€”about that spot I saw two brakes being driven in the same direction as I was goingâ€”two brakes passed meâ€”the prisoner was driving a third brake, with four horses; it passed me on the near sideâ€”I was driving in the centre of the roadâ€”the third brake was trying to pass between me and the second brake, and came into collision with my

trap, striking on the wheel, causing the shafts to break; my wife was thrown out; I remained at the bottom of the gigâ€”there was no room for the prisoner's brake to pass between me and the other brakeâ€”I had gone a little distance alongside the second brakeâ€”the second brake had cleared me, and the third one came behindâ€”my wife was thrown on the road; she was carried to the station, and died the same nightâ€”I was breaking into a walking pace at the time.

Cross-examined. I had been to Barnet Fairâ€”I don't know where the brakes had beenâ€”it was a dark nightâ€”there was a lamp in the road opposite where the accident happenedâ€”I had no lights on my trapâ€”I saw the brakes at the Swan at Whetstone.â€”I saw Mr. Edmunds there, and shook hands with him, and bade him good-night; he was on one of the brakesâ€”I started before the brakes; I knew they were followingâ€”the Great North Road is a very wide oneâ€”I should say there was room for three vehicles to passâ€”I was driving in the middle of the road, and walkingâ€”I knew the pony well; I had only driven it once before; I have ridden behind it many timesâ€”it was not mine, it belonged to a friendâ€”two of the brakes bad passed meâ€”the prisoner's brake was not the fourth, to the best of my belief it was the third; I would not swear itâ€”the second brake had cleared me; the prisoner was trying to pass between me and the brake.

Re-examined. I did not see what happened with the brake that came into collision with me; he did not stopâ€”my trap was struck on the near side wheelâ€”all the spokes were scratchedâ€”I dont know what part of the brake struck me.

ERNEST EDMUNDS . I am a milkman, and live in Dickenson Street, Kentish Townâ€”I was a passenger on the brake driven by the prisonerâ€”there were about thirty persons on the brakeâ€”there were two brakes in front after leaving the Swan at Finchleyâ€”I saw the pony and gig with Brinson and his wife in itâ€”the brake in front of us went past it on the near sideâ€”the gig was more to the off side of the roadâ€”I was sitting on a seat behind the driver, on the right, facing the way we were goingâ€”I saw the brake catch the trapâ€”the prisoner was trying to pass the brake in frontâ€”when he caught the trap he pulled in againâ€”the front wheel of our brake ran into the wheel of the trap; the shafts seemed to break entirely away and the trap went upâ€”we did not stop, we never came to a standstillâ€”somebody in the brake remarked, "Drive on," and we did drive on.

Cross-examined. It was the off-wheel of the brake that struck the trapâ€”we were more to the near side of the roadâ€”I was soberâ€”I had had a glass or two before I startedâ€”I was only jollyâ€”I have said I was half intoxicated when I started in the morningâ€”I had to lie down on the grass all the afternoonâ€”I was perfectly sober when I came homeâ€”I remember stopping at the Swanâ€”I had a drink thereâ€”I had a girl half on my knee on the brakeâ€”there were two persons by the driver, one on each sideâ€”I did not notice any lamps on the brake.

WILLIAM ROBSON . I was on the prisoner's brake, on a back seat just behind the driverâ€”I saw the trapâ€”as we went to get in front of the brake in front of us we caught the wheel of the trapâ€”I saw the trap go up and the two people were thrownâ€”as our driver was going to pull up a voice on the brake halloaed out "Drive on," and we went on.
Cross-examined. I am a friend of Edmundsâ€”we live in the same

house; I was sitting next himâ€”I did not hear, anyone tell the driver to stopâ€”somebody said "Drive on" or "Ride on"â€”the trap was not in the middle of the roadâ€”we were going pretty fastâ€”I could not say whether there were any lamps on the brake.
Re-examined. I felt a shock from the collision.

WILLIAM SNELL (S 440). About 11 on the night of 7th September I was on duty in the Great North Road; I saw several persons stooping round a woman on the groundâ€”with the assistance of Brinson I took her to the station; she died the same nightâ€”the road there is 29 feet wide.
JAMES BARRINGTON BAKER . I am a medical practitionerâ€”I was called to see the deceased at the stationâ€”she died of the injuries she had receivedâ€”they might have been caused by a fall from a trap.

JAMES SANCTUARY (Inspector S). On 9th September at 9 in the morning I saw the prisoner at Finchley Police-stationâ€”I told him he would be charged with the manslaughter of Esther Brinson by reckless driving on the 7th September; he made no reply.
Cross-examined. I have made inquiries about himâ€”he holds a double licence as conductor and driverâ€”he is a respectable man.

WYNNE WESTCOTT , M.D. I am Deputy-Coroner for West Middlesexâ€”the prisoner was examined as a witness before me at an inquest on Esther Brinson on 10th September, after being cautionedâ€”I produce his statement which I took down. (Read: "I reside at 5, Flowers Mews, Archway Road, London. I am a coachman, employed by Harry Pope, of 5, Archway Road. I have held a coachman's licence since 1886. On 7th September I was driving a four horse brake from the Swan Tavern towards London. I had about thirty passengers. I was in a procession of brakes; I was the fourth as we went alongâ€”it was very dark; all the brakes were on the near side of the road. I was fifteen yards behind the brake in front of me; I saw this gig in front of me; it was in the middle of the road; the horse and gig stopped, and then ran back on to my off-side front wheel. I pulled up my horses as quickly as I could; I undid my safety brake, and was about to put my reins on the footboard of the brake to get down, but then my passengers shouted out to me, 'Go on;' I looked to see if there was anything wrong; I did not, and so I followed on in the fourth place as before.")
JOHN WOOD (Police Sergeant S R) produced and proved a plan of the road.

WILLIAM GEORGE PRICE . I was one of the party that went to St. Albans on the day in questionâ€”coming home I sat on the near side of the prisonerâ€”I am a teetotalerâ€”the brakes were following each otherâ€”we kept on the near side all the wayâ€”we were the fourth brakeâ€”there was no attempt to pass any other brakeâ€”I saw the pony and trapâ€”the third brake passed it on the off side, and then the pony backed into our brakeâ€”I can't tell what part of the brake came in contact with the trapâ€”I think it was the hinder partâ€”we were going slowly, between five and six miles an hourâ€”I did not know that any harm had been doneâ€”the pony trap was, I reckon, more to the off side of the road than the middleâ€”there were two rows of persons sitting behind me, and a number of others sitting facing each otherâ€”the brake had lights in front, one. on each side below the driverâ€”when the brake rushed into the trap
the driver went on about fifteen yards, and there was an alarmâ€”we went on at the same paceâ€”no one told the driver to stop.

Cross-examined. I did not think that anything had happened to the trap; I saw it back into the brake; I thought it had only just caught, and moved at onceâ€”I did not feel any shockâ€”the prisoner was going to get down, when someone behind him said, "Go on "â€”he had actually stoppedâ€”the brake in front of us went past the trapâ€”the pony was on the off side when this occurredâ€”I could not say whether the driver pulled the reins tight, or whether the pony jibbed; it was going nearly on the jig jogâ€”I did not see anything to make him pull up or so back.

ALBERT RICE . I am a licensed driver at Newtownâ€”I was driving the third brake, the prisoner was driving the fourthâ€”there was no racing on the way home, or trying to pass each otherâ€”I remember passing the pony trap, it had no lamps; I passed it on the near side; I holloaed out "Hi, hi," two or three times to the man in passing, because he was wandering all over the road; I passed him on the near side to save an accidentâ€”he did not answer; there was nothing to prevent his being on the near sideâ€”we were not going more than five or six miles an hour, we were both loaded with passengersâ€”after we had passed somebody called outâ€”I stopped, and was going to get down to see what was the matterâ€”I stood up and looked round, I could see nothing behind me; I heard some one call, "All right, go on," and I didâ€”it was a very dark nightâ€”we kept in the same order right through.

Cross-examined. I do not know on which side the brake passed the trap; you could not see above twenty or thirty yards aheadâ€”when I called out the man pulled further on the off side; I pulled on the near side, on to the pathway.

MARTIN SHEEN . I was a passenger on the third brake; the prisoner was driving the one behind, the fourthâ€”there was no racingâ€”my attention was called to the pony trap by his running all over the roadâ€”it was free between the middle and the right-hand sideâ€”when I passed the trap the fourth brake was close behind me, I could almost touch his horses' heads from where I was sitting; that was so all the way there and backâ€”I saw the pony and the man with the reins, and the pony deliberately ran straight back; the man tried to whip him up; it caught the fourth brake, either the front or hind wheelâ€”it was a dark nightâ€”I heard somebody call out, "Whoa!" and after that several voices called out, "All right!" and we then proceeded on our wayâ€”I could not say whether the trap had been upsetâ€”I knew there had been a collision; if it had been broken I should have got out.
Cross-examined. I saw the pony turn off, that was allâ€”I did not see the trap turn overâ€”I saw the pony run straight back into collision with the fourth brake.
NOT GUILTY .

790.
JAMES VAUGHAN was indicted
for, and charged on the Coroner's Inquisition with, the manslaughter of
Frederick Klein.
MESSRS. C.F. GILL and A. GILL Prosecuted, and MR. HUTTON Defended.

CAROLINE KLEIN . I live at 39, Robert Street, Hampstead Roadâ€”my husband, Frederick Klein, was a German, he was a cabinet-maker, and was 50 years of ageâ€”on the night of 19th September I was with him returning from my sister's at Clerkenwellâ€”at Farringdon Street Station we got into a third-class carriage to go to Gower Street, the

carriage was pretty full; I sat down on the same side as my husbandâ€”just as the train was starting the prisoner and some other men got in; there was not room for them allâ€”the prisoner was dressed very smartly, with a tall hat and an umbrellaâ€”he said, "I am a first-class passenger"â€”I said, "It's a pity you did not take a first-class ticket"â€”when we started he called my husband a b----and all manner of namesâ€”my husband said, "If you use such an expression as that again I would smash you like that," striking his own handâ€”at Gower Street we got out, and as we were about to cross Euston. Road, the prisoner and others came up; one of his friends said to my husband, "Are you going to b----well fight?"â€”the prisoner immediately came up and said, "Take that, you b----German bastard," and he up with his umbrella and struck my husband with it in the eye with all his force; he gave the blow over his friend's shoulderâ€”my husband said, "Oh, Carrie, my eye is gone, I am ruined for life "â€”I caught hold of the man who had challenged him to fight, by the neck; a constable brought the prisoner back, and we went to the stationâ€”my husband was in great pain, his eye bled, a doctor was sent for; we Went home, and on the 21st he was taken to the hospital; he gradually grew worse, and died on the 29th.

Cross-examined. The obscene expressions in the train were used by the prisoner and his companions, they assisted each other, but the word was said to meâ€”I could not say how many followed us from Gower Street, three or four, when the man asked my husband to fight he did nothing to endeavour to protect himself, he had not a chance, he did not put up his hand or make any motionâ€”I saw the umbrella come over the other man's shoulderâ€”I saw the prisoner's faceâ€”I don't remember my husband being able to say anythingâ€”we were just going to cross, and the man stopped him full, my husband stopped immediatelyâ€”I was very nervous when it happenedâ€”I did not know they were following us.

HARRY CALE . I live at the bamboo works, 122, Cleveland Streetâ€”on the night of 19th September I saw the prisoner and another man close to Gower Street Stationâ€”I also saw the deceased and his wife close to the side of the prisonerâ€”the row was not caused by him, but by one of his friends, who asked the deceased if he wanted to b----well fight, and before he could get a word out the prisoner drew his umbrella from his left side and struck over his friend's shoulder, and said, "Go away, you b----German bastard"â€”it was a thrustâ€”I saw blood come from the man's eye immediately afterâ€”the prisoner went into the Euston Road under the shade of the treesâ€”I saw the changing of hats with the people in the road, I don't know if it was one of his friendsâ€”I pointed the prisoner out to a constable, and he ran, and ran into a drunken man's arms.

Cross-examined. I was about two yards away when I first saw them; I was standing close by; there were a number of people round the prosecutorâ€”I did not hear him say anything; he was standing stillâ€”he did not make any motion as if to strikeâ€”the others were standing round; they were not threatening him; they said nothing.

FREDERICK CALE . I was with my brotherâ€”I did not see the blow struckâ€”my brother pointed out the prisoner to me, and I went and called him a cowardâ€”he said, "You never saw what was done in the train. "
JOHN DONOVAN (S 163). About half-past twelve on the morning of

20th September my attention was attracted to something going on close to Gower Street Stationâ€”I went up, and saw the deceased bleeding from a wound in the eyeâ€”he made a statement to me, in consequence of which I went after the prisoner; he was running away in Euston Roadâ€”I caught him, and brought him back, and told him he was accused of striking the man in the eye; he made no answerâ€”he was dressed in a very fashionable style, with a high hat and very nice clothes, with an Inverness cape across his arm, and an umbrellaâ€”I took him to the stationâ€”he gave the name of Paul Foby, but refused his address and occupationâ€”this is the umbrella.
Cross-examined. Mrs. Klein was holding another man when I came up; there was no struggle going onâ€”she said at first he was the man.

WILLIAM SMITH (Inspector D). I was at the station when the prisoner was brought in; I entered the charge for assaulting the deceased, by striking him in the eye with an umbrellaâ€”he replied, "Yes, I did strike him"â€”he gave the name of Paul Fob, but declined his address or occupation.

EDWARD CULLEN (Sergeant D 36). On 20th September, about four p.m., a man named William Brown, of 31, Tenter Street, Spitalfields, presented himself as bail for the prisonerâ€”the prisoner gave the name of Paul Foby.

GERALD MANSFIELD . I am resident medical officer of the London Temperance Hospitalâ€”the deceased was admitted there on 21st September, suffering from a wound in the upper part of the left eye; it had been stitched upâ€”he got worse, and died on the 29thâ€”I made a post mortemâ€”there was penetration of the roof of the orbit, large enough to admit the point of an umbrellaâ€”the cause of death was inflammation and softening of the brain, due to the woundâ€”fragments of bone were splintered towards the brainâ€”it must have required a fair amount of force to inflict the wound; the skull is rather thin there.

JOHN KAYNE (Sergeant D). I arrested the prisoner on 29th September at the Thames Police-court, after his committal on another chargeâ€”he was charged with assaulting and beating the deceasedâ€”he made no replyâ€”he was taken to Tottenham Court Road stationâ€”I then heard the man was dead, and I told the prisoner he would be charged with causing his deathâ€”he described himself as a general dealer, of 66, Westmoreland Place, City Road.
GUILTY .

He was also charged with committing wilful damage by breaking a window with a sticky
and found Guilty. â€”
Twelve Months' Hard Labour on the first conviction , and
One Day's Imprisonment on the second.

791.
JOSEPH BRESCHER (26)
, Feloniously wounding
Lottie Jones, with intent to murder; Second Count, with intent to do grievous bodily harm.

LOTTIE JONES . I am an unfortunateâ€”I live at 79, Pennington Street, St. Giles'sâ€”I have known the prisoner for the last three yearsâ€”I have not lived with himâ€”I have lived in the same houseâ€”on 19th September I went into the Swedish Flag public-house several times" in the eveningâ€”the prisoner was thereâ€”I had had two or three glasses of aleâ€”I was not very much the worse for drink, I might have been a littleâ€”I left when the house closed at twelve, and went homeâ€”I don't know whether the prisoner was homeâ€”I remember nothing after I got home.

JOHN MULLER . I am manager of the Swedish Flagâ€”I know the prosecutrix and prisoner as coming thereâ€”on the night of 19th September the prosecutrix was in the house three or four times, the last time was about a quarter to twelveâ€”the prisoner was there from about eight upwardsâ€”the last time the prosecutrix came in the mistress refused to serve her, and told her she had had sufficientâ€”previous to that, about ten, the prisoner asked her why she was spending her money with those who would give her nothing when she wanted itâ€”she told him to mind his own businessâ€”at closing time they left together, he went first and she followed, and he turned his head and said, "I will give you something when I get you home"

JOHN MILLER . I live at 79, Pennington Street, St. George'sâ€”the prisoner and the prosecutrix lived in the same houseâ€”on 17th September I saw the prisoner come in about one, and prosecutrix came in about half an hour afterâ€”I heard her go up to her own room, the second floor frontâ€”I did not see which room the prisoner went toâ€”about five minntes after she had gone up, the prisoner came down, and said, "Will you go up and see?"â€”he then passed out into the streetâ€”I went up into Jones' room, and saw her lying in a pool of blood on the floorâ€”I fetched the policeâ€”this chopper (produced) is mineâ€”about four that afternoon the prisoner had chopped some coke for me with itâ€”the wooden handle was then on it.

ROSE MCCARTHY . I am the wife of John McCarthy, of 1, Breeze Hill, St. George's; that is next to 79, Pennington Streetâ€”I know the prisoner and prosecutrix; I have often heard *****them quarrellingâ€”on 19th Septem
tember, between a quarter to one and one, I saw her come home; she was not sober; she bid us good-night at the cornerâ€”about five minutes after she had gone in I heard screaming and a crash, and the prisoner came running down the steps; he put his foot on one step, and turned back to the houseâ€”he said something in his own language, and ran up the streetâ€”I went in and saw Jones sitting in a chair upstairsâ€”the police were then there.

SARAH ANGELO . I live at 1, Breeze Hillâ€”on 20th September, about half-past one, the prisoner fetched me, and I went up to Lottie Jones' roomâ€”I found this chopper by the washstand, and the handle by the fire place; there was blood on the bladeâ€”I handed it to the police.

WILLIAM FLUISTER (H 373). I was called to the house early in the morning, and in the second floor front room I found the prosecutrix lying on the ground in a pool of blood; she was in a semi-conscious stateâ€”I bathed her head; she rallied, and I assisted her to the Police-stationâ€”Angelo afterwards handed me this chopper; there was blood on the head of it.

HERBERT REYNOLDS (H 291). At one in the morning of 20th September the prisoner came to Leman Street Station, and said, "I wish to give myself into custody for murdering a woman in St. George's; I don't know whether she is dead or not"â€”the inspector took charge of him.

WILLIAM CORSBY (Inspector H). I was at the Leman Street Station when the prisoner gave himself upâ€”he said he wished to make a statementâ€”I took it down, and he signed it. (Read: "I am going to give myself up to-night. I hit some woman, and very likely killed her, at 79, Pennington Street; I shall not say any more. ")â€”the prosecutrix also made this statement in the prisoner's presence: "I cannot account for

the injuries I received, but I suppose it was caused by some man who wanted me to go home with him, and I refused because he had no money. I know the man by sight; he is a tall fellow. I left home at ten, and I believe I stayed there till the house closed; I had several glasses of mild-and-bitter."

PERCY JOHN CLARK . I am assistant divisional surgeon of policeâ€”on 20th September I examined Lottie Jones at the police-stationâ€”I found her suffering from three contused wounds at the back of the head, two on the left side and one on the right, and one incised wound of the right eye down to the boneâ€”they were all serious woundsâ€”considerable violence must have been used to inflict them; they might have been caused by the head of this chopperâ€”I saw it at the Police-court there were bloodstains on it.

p.hi: The Prisoner, in his statement before the Magistrate, and in his defence, said that he teas drinking with four or five men in the public-house, and then sat down, and remembered nothing else till he was in the Police-station.

div1.p: JOHN MULLER (Re-called). I did not consider he was drunkâ€”I saw him up to near closing time; he was. there from a little after eightâ€”I served him five or six times with mild a'e.

GUILTY
on Second Count. â€”
Eighteen Months' Hard Labour.

792.
LEVY NICHOLAS DARLINGTON PICKETT
PLEADED GUILTY to sending a letter to
Mary Ann Margaret Mackintyre.â€”
To enter into his own recognisances in Â£500 to appear for judgment if called upon.

793.
FRANK HENRY BURTENSHAW (16)
PLEADED GUILTY to three indictments for stealing postal orders for the payment of 15s., Â£1, and Â£1; also
to three indictments for forging and uttering the same.â€”
Six Months' Hard Labour.

794.
JOHN BRINSON** (46)
to burglary in the dwelling-house of
William George Reynolds, and stealing a picture value Â£3.â€”
Fifteen Months' Hard Labour.
[Pleaded guilty: See original trial image.]

795.
CHARLES GREIT BURTON (29)
, to two indictments for forging and uttering cheques for Â£2 15s. and Â£3 10s., with intent to defraud.
[Pleaded guilty: See original trial image.] Recommended to mercy by the Prosecutor. â€”
Three Days Imprisonment.

796.
FREDERICK ALBERT STONIER (37)
, to two indictments for forging and uttering cheques for Â£80 and Â£25, with intent to defraud.â€”
Nine Months' Hard Labour.
[Pleaded guilty: See original trial image.]

797.
MARY GWENDOLINE SMITH (16)
, to unlawfully attempting to obtain Â£8 by false pretences; also
to stealing a cheque from
Kate Reece, her mistress.â€”
Six Months' Hard Labour.
[Pleaded guilty: See original trial image.]

798.
JOHN MAYCOCK (24) and
THOMAS GRICE (22)
, to burglary in the dwelling-house of
Matilda Milligan, and stealing a cup and other articles, her property.â€”
Twelve Months' Hard Labour each.
[Pleaded guilty: See original trial image.] And

(799).
CHARLES WETTON (37)
, to feloniously marrying
Caroline Murray, his wife being alive.â€”
Four Months' Hard Labour.
[Pleaded guilty: See original trial image.]

800.
ALFRED ORFORD (19)
, Forging and uttering an order for Â£54 8s. 6d., with intent to defraud.

CHARLES COOK . I am fifteen years old, and have been three months at Mr. Wheatley's home, Brook Street, Holbornâ€”I was employed as a crossing-sweeper in the Strand in Septemberâ€”I have known the prisoner's younger brother about three years, and knew the prisoner by sight about the same time; but my intimate friend was his brotherâ€”on 24th September, about 8.30 p.m., I was with a companion about my own age in Shoe Lane, and met the prisonerâ€”he said, "I hear you are on the letters; if you get anything, I will change it for you; I will see you in the morning"â€”I was sweeping in Shaftesbury Avenue next morning, and I and the boy with me went into a doorway next door to the Portugal public-house, Meet Streetâ€”I stayed outside, and my companion went inâ€”when he came out I went into the doorway, about 9.10 p.m., and saw that my companion had nearly wrenched off the top of the letter-box; I wrenched it right off, and took out about two dozen letters, and left the rest thereâ€”we then went down Bouverie Street opposite, examined the letters, and took out of them this cheque for Â£58 14s. 6d. on a Charing Cross Bank, drawn by Mr. Taylerâ€”there were no blots on it thenâ€”the prisoner came to me next morning in Shaftesbury Avenue and said, "How are you getting on?"â€”I told him I had a cheque, and gave it him from my pocket folded up, but not in an envelopeâ€”he did not open it; he put it in his pocket, and said he would be back at 3.30â€”he gave me a penny, and said, "That is all the change I have got now"â€”the cheque was not blotted thenâ€”I next heard that he was in custody.

Cross-examined by the Prisoner. I was at Sloper's in Shoe Lane trying to get letters out of the letter-boxesâ€”I had seen you before round Broad Streetâ€”you did not say to mo, "You will get yourself into trouble;" or that you had been watching meâ€”I was sent to Mr. Wheatley's for sleeping out, and I came as a witness because the boy who was with me told a boy at Mr. Wheatley'sâ€”I did not say that when you got the money I should have a share.

Re-examined. His brother showed me a newspaperâ€”I can read writingâ€”I did not give this letter (produced) to the prisonerâ€”I tore up the envelope in Bouverie Street; there was a bill with it, which I tore upâ€”I went to Messrs. Mullens' offices, but I did not know they were solicitors to the Bankers' Associationâ€”I made a perfectly voluntary statement to the detective.

ALFRED JOSEPH NOTTINGHAM . I am ledger-keeper to Mr. Carpenter, of the Charing Cross Bankâ€”this cheque for Â£58 14s. 6d. is drawn by Mr. Carpenter, on the Consolidated Bank, in favour of C. Tayler and Co., of Fleet Street, and sent to them by post on September 24th, in an envelope, with the accountâ€”I posted itâ€”I went next day to the Charing Cross branch of the Consolidated Bank and saw the prisonerâ€”I did not know him beforeâ€”I found he had presented the cheque, and having received information I took him to Mr. Taylerâ€”he said on the way that a man dressed in light clothes had given it to him to take to the bank, and as we passed the Windsor public-house he wished to go in and see the manâ€”we went in with a constable, but no one was thereâ€”I then took him to Mr. Taylor's, and Mr. Atkins gave him in charge.

SAMUEL DRIVER . I am employed by James Henry Atkins, an adver
tisement agent, of 154, Fleet Street, carrying on business as Tayler and Co.â€”we have a box at the street door, and I found the lid of it taken

away on the morning of the 25th, and took out the letters which were leftâ€”we knew that Mr. Carpenter was going to send a cheque; we had had cheques from him before, which were always crossedâ€”this cheque is Mr. Carpenter's writing; there are signs of an erasure of the crossing.

JAMES HENRY ATKINS . I trade as Charles Tayler and Co., advertise
ment agents, 154, Fleet Streetâ€”I do not know the prisonerâ€”this is not my endorsement to this cheque; it never came to my handsâ€”this letter, purporting to be by the payee of the cheque, is not mine.
Cross-examined. There is the name of the firm on the back of the cheque, but it is signed Taylor instead of Tayler.

HERBERT MURRAY TULLOCH . I am cashier at the Consolidated Bank, Charing Crossâ€”on September 25th, about 3.40, the prisoner brought this envelope, not fastened, and I took out a letter and a cheque, which had been stopped that morningâ€”I asked him to wait a minute or two, and went to Mr. Carpenterâ€”I took no steps to prevent his going away, but he did not see me goâ€”I went out of the side doorâ€”I came back in ten minutes or a quarter of an hour with Mr. Nottingham, and said to the prisoner, "You must come and see Mr. Tayler at his office"â€”we retained the envelope; this is the letter:â€”"Sir,â€”Please excuse ink on cheque; while being endorsed the ink was on the pad.â€”C. Taylor. "There are traces of the erasure of the crossing.

BENJAMIN MARTIN (City Policeman.) On 28th September I was sent for to 154, Fleet Street, and saw Mr. Atkins and the prisonerâ€”I asked the prisoner how he came in possession of the cheque; he said he was standing at the corner of Agar Street, and was going to see his mother, when a man, dressed in light clothes, asked him to take it to the bank and wait for an answerâ€”I took him to the station, and in answer to the charge he said, "I am innocent; the cheque was given to me by a man dressed in light clothes; his name is Taylor, and he keeps a shop at 24, Queen Victoria Street"â€”I went with Palmer to the prisoner's lodging in New Union Street, Tottenham Court Roadâ€”Palmer brought some clothes away, and these two bills were in the pockets.

WILLIAM PALMER (City Detective). I met the prisoner in Martin's cus
tody, going to the stationâ€”I afterwards went to 24, Queen Victoria Street; goods are sold there by auctionâ€”I found no one there answering to the name of Taylorâ€”I brought away some clothes from the lodging, and these two bills were with themâ€”he was dressed in the clothes he has on now, and a new overcoat and underclothing and new solitaires and a new watch and chain.

Cross-examined. I have seen the lad Cook at Mr. Wheatley's homo, and said, "I am a police officer; lam making inquiries about letter-stealing from Fleet Street; you have made a statement in this building"â€”he said, "Quite correct," and said that you met him in Shoe Lane on Thursday night, and said, "You are getting letters," and he said, "Yes," and you said, "If you get anything bring them to me. "

JOHN PARKINS . I am a tailor of Brixtonâ€”on September 21st I owed Dodson and Co., of 75, Fore Street, Â£20â€”I drew a cheque for Â£20, crossed it and enclosed it in a letter addressed to them, with a note asking for a receipt, but no billâ€”it was quite clean; there were no blots on itâ€”I gave it to my porter, Achwell, to post.
FRANCIS ACHWELL . I am Mr. Parkins' porterâ€”on 21st September I
received a letter from him addressed to Messrs. Dodson, of Fore Street; I posted it.

FREDERICK WILLIAM DODSON . I am a woollen merchant, of 74 and 75, Fore Street; Mr. Parkins is a customer of mine, and owed me Â£20 in Septemberâ€”this is not my endorsement to this cheque, nor that of any member of my firm, nor is it written by my authorityâ€”it did not come to me by post; this letter, signed F. W. Dobson, is not my writing nor that of any member of my firmâ€”Mr. Parkins made inquiries because I did not send a receipt; I had no knowledge that the cheque had been stolen.
Cross-examined. There is only one employe in our firm, and I know his writing.

HAROLD AUGUSTE SAUZE . I am a cashier at the Brixton branch of the London and County Bankâ€”on 22nd September, about 3.45 p.m., the prisoner, to the best of my belief, brought this cheque for Â£20 in an envelopeâ€”I paid it in goldâ€”these blots were on it, and I could not see the crossingâ€”I can see it now, but it was not so plain when it was presented.

Cross-examined. On 2nd October, Mr. Palmer told me to go to the Mansion House to identify the person who presented the chequeâ€”some
body said that when I saw the man I was to touch him on the shoulder; but I did not touch anybody, because I did not feel justifiedâ€”I was at the back of the court when you were put in the dockâ€”I thought it was you when I saw you downstairs; but I could not seize on any feature, you were very pale and differently dressedâ€”from the court Mr. Palmer and I went to the solicitors, and the cage was put in their handsâ€”Mr. Palmer had an overcoat over his armâ€”he asked me how you were dressed, and I said in a blue coat and billycock hatâ€”I could not recognise the coat Mr. Palmer had gotâ€”the Magistrate asked how you were dressed, and I said in a blue coat; he asked whether it was new or oldâ€”I said I could not sayâ€”I cannot remember whether the gas was alight in the Mansion House.

Re-examined. The men were in a line under the court at the Mansion House; it was very dark. The prisoner was very pale, and differently dressed, and I could not positively identify him, but I could see that he had on different clothes; when I heard him speak, that gave me a feeling that he was the personâ€”I do not say positively now, but I believe he is the manâ€”the letter said: "Sir,â€”Please excuse ink on the cheque; while being endorsed the ink was on the blotting pad this morning. Yours truly, Wm. Dodson. "I returned the letter.
WILLIAM PALMER (Re-examined). I was present under the Mansion House Justice Room when a line of people were thereâ€”there were two gas jets; at that time the prisoner was clad in new clothing.

Cross-examined. I told you, on October 2nd, to place yourself where you liked, and you stood against the wall. I said, "Point to the man you know, if you see anybody there you know"; nobody touched you on your shoulderâ€”after that I asked for a remand, which was grantedâ€”Mr. Sauze left the court with me on October 2nd, and we went to Lombard Streetâ€”I had not got the coat on my arm when I left; Martin had itâ€”I carried nothingâ€”we did not have the parcel on October 2nd.
Re-examined. The prisoner cross-examined me on 2nd October in Mr.

Sauze's presence, who heard his voiceâ€”this was a new coat; he was wearing it when he was takenâ€”he asked for it, and I refused to give it to himâ€”he asked the Magistrate to make an order for it to be given up, and he refused.
The prisoner handed a written defend to the JURY, with the notes he had taken during the trial, and asked them to compare it with the letter; he denied ever being at Brixton in his life.

GUILTY
of the uttering. ** There was another indictment against him.â€”
Seven Years' Penal Servitude.

801.
CHARLES AUGUSTINE KELLY (19)
, Stealing Â£5 and a watch and chain of
Edward John Gowan, from his person.

MR. SANDS Prosecuted, and MR. OVEREND Defended. FREDERICK MORGAN. I am assistant to Simpkin and Marshall, book
sellers, of 317, Strandâ€”on September 9 I was in Salisbury Court, Fleet Street, about 7.50 a. m.â€”I had been to the Barley Mow public-house with the prosecutor; I saw the prisoner there; he was sober, but the prosecutor was intoxicatedâ€”I saw them come out, and followed them to the front of St. Bride's Churchâ€”they hailed a cab; the prosecutor got in and the prisoner after himâ€”they stopped in it about three minutes; it was standing stillâ€”the prisoner got out first and the gentleman after himâ€”I could not see what passed in the cabâ€”they went back to the Barley Mow; I followed them in and had a drink, and came out and waited for themâ€”they came out shortly afterwards and went round St. Bride's Church again, and up the steps, where they engaged in conversation for a few minutesâ€”the prosecutor's coat was open, and the prisoner went like this to himâ€”when I first saw him he had a chain, and he had a black bag in his handâ€”I left them and went and found a constable, who brought two plain-clothes officers into Fleet Street, and saw the prisoner by the Punch office; he was joined by his father, and pulled something out and showed himâ€”I cannot say what it wasâ€”we followed them to a coffee-house in Fetter Lane, where they had refreshmentâ€”I and Ferguson went in and sat opposite themâ€”the prisoner pulled a watch out of his pocket and gave it to his father, who examined the works and said it was not worth muchâ€”we had our breakfast, and waited for them to come out, and followed them to Lincoln's Inn Fields, and the officers charged themâ€”this chain (pro
duced) is like the one the drunken man had on.

Cross-examined. I was coming from my business at 8 a.m.â€”I had been up all nightâ€”I did not see the prosecutor tossing for drinks in the Barley Mowâ€”five or six persons were with them there, but I did not see him standing drink to anybodyâ€”the prisoner was endeavouring to take his black bag from himâ€”when I saw the prisoner's hands go toward the prosecutor's chain he was not supporting himâ€”the prisoner helped him into the Hansom's cab, and out of itâ€”I did not see the prisoner take out a purse and look into itâ€”I saw no purseâ€”I did not see him give a cardâ€”when the prisoner was given in custody in Lincoln's Inn Fields he said he had lent the prosecutor 15s., and taken his watch and chain as security, and promised to meet him to-morrow in Fleet Street and return the moneyâ€”the prosecutor's printed name and address was not found on the prisoner.
Re-examined. The prisoner gave the black bag back to the prosecutor.

JAMES NOBLE (449 City). On the morning of 29th September I was on duty, and saw the prisoner and prosecutor get out of a cab and walk into St. Bride's Avenue, and stand face to faceâ€”the prosecutor had a black bagâ€”he took a pigskin purse from his right trousers pocket, looked into all the compartments, and the prisoner bent over it, touching him as much as to say, "Give me the purse"â€”the prosecutor handed it to him, and he opened a flap, put two fingers in, drew some papers out, examined them, and put them backâ€”I was twenty yards offâ€”he turned his head to the left, saw me, stooped down and picked up the bag, took the prosecutor by the arm, and walked down St. Bride's Avenue, carrying the bagâ€”they went into St. Bride's Court, and I informed a plain-clothes man.

Cross-examined. The prosecutor was not drunk, he could walk; he did not require the prisoner's assistance to keep him upâ€”I do not think he put his hand on the prosecutor's breast to prevent his fallingâ€”the prosecutor handed the prisoner his purse, not a card or memorandum out of itâ€”I do not know whether there was any money in the purse.
By the Jury. The prosecutor was sober; I saw him walk up and down St. Bride's Avenue.

CHARLES FRYERS (City Detective). On 29th September, about 8.30, I was on duty in plain clothes with Fergussonâ€”Morgan pointed out the prisoner walking along Fleet Streetâ€”I followed himâ€”another man joined him, and he took something out of his pocket and showed to himâ€”I did not follow them to Fetter Laneâ€”I afterwards stopped the prisoner in Lincoln's Inn Fields and said, "I am a police officer; where is that watch and chain you had from that gentleman in Fleet Street this morning?"â€”he looked surprised, and the man who was in his company said, "He is my son; he has lent 15s. to the gentleman on this watch; he is a friend of ours "â€”the prisoner handed me the watch and chain from his left waistcoat pocketâ€”I said, "Do you know this gentleman?"â€”he said, "I do not; we had been drinking together; he has promised to meet me in Fleet Street to-morrow, and return me my money"â€”I said, "This is not altogether satisfactory to mo; I shall charge you with the unlawful possession of it"â€”I searched him and found Â£1 6s. 5 1/2 d., some memoranda and letters; and cigars, but none of them gave the prosecutor's address; the prisoner gave mo no such memorandaâ€”when he was charged at the station he said to his father, "Father, you know I had Â£2 when I came out last night."
Cross-examined. I inspected all the papers found on the prisonerâ€”the watch had on it "B. C. Gowan, Highbury. "

Re-examined. The prosecutor came to the station next morning to re
port the loss of his watch.
----FERGUSSON (Policeman). I received a communication from Noble, and was with Morgan and Fryers till the arrest.

Cross-examined. I saw the prisoner show the watch to the person who is admitted to be his fatherâ€”he said at the station, "Remember, father, that when I came out last night I had Â£2"â€”the father assentedâ€”the father is employed in journalistic work, and the son as a builder's clerk or agent in Fetter Lane.

EDWARD JOHN GOWAN . I live at Canonburyâ€”I do not know the prisoner or his familyâ€”I am not used to taking much drinkâ€”I was in a cab at King's Cross, and was taken to Fleet Streetâ€”I remem
ber being pulled out of the cab by somebody on Tuesday

morning, and told I could sot go by the cab because had no money, and I took a cab by myself and went homeâ€”I had a purse with Â£5 in it, and papers in it of no value to anybody but myselfâ€”the Â£5 was not there when I got home.

Cross-examined. I did not begin drinking till ten at nightâ€”I do not remember seeing the prisonerâ€”I do not know what place I was drinking in, or borrowing money to pay for drinkâ€”I was taken out of a cab on the Tuesday morning because I had not the fare to give the cabman; I called the last cab myself.
NOT GUILTY .

802.
WILLIAM HEWSON (21)
, Unlawfully attempting to obtains Â£23 from the
City Bank by false pretences, with intent to defraud.

SIDNEY HERBERT COLLETTE . I am cashier at the City Bank, Sloane-Street branchâ€”on 6th October, about half-past twelve, the prisoner came in and presented an envelope containing this cheque for Â£23, signed and endorsed "George Scott"â€”we had such a customer, but he has transferred his account to our Bond Street branchâ€”the prisoner said nothingâ€”I opened the envelope and took the cheque out, and saw it was cancelled, and said, "What do you want with this?"â€”he said, "I want the moneyâ€”I said, "Where do you come from?"â€”he said so me firm; I did not catch the nameâ€”I went to see the sub-manager, and I Had hardly moved two yards when I saw that he was engaged; I could not leave the prisoner, because I was the only one at the counter, so I turned back towards him, and as I did so he ran immediately out of the placeâ€”I got across the counter, and went after him, and captured him in the high Street; he was running; a gentleman turned him-a constable came up and took him; I gave him in chargeâ€”he said he was innocent.

Cross-examined. There were no other persons in the bank; customers, clerks, or messengersâ€”the envelope he Wed to me was addressed to the City Bank, Knightsbridge branchâ€”when he handed me the envelope I said, "Do you know what it is?" and he said, "No";, and then opened itâ€”when he was stopped all he said was "I am innocent when he came inside with the constable ho said, "A man gave me the cheque outside "â€”he did not say directly he was stopped, I am innocent; it was given to me by a man"â€”he afterwards said he had mentioned to the policeman the man who had given him the envelopeâ€”I did not hear itâ€”he gave no description of the man in my hearing at the bankâ€”I was on one side of the counter, and the prisoner on the otherâ€”I did not hear him say he was a man 5 ft. 7 in, with dark hair and moustache, or that he had motioned with his. hand to the policeman across Sloane Street where the man was, but that at that toe traffic passed by and the policeman could not get overâ€”he kept saying, I am innocent"; and the manager said, "Lock him up. "

HENRY THOMPSON (B R 54). On 6th I was on duty at Knightsbridge, and about a quarter to one I saw the prisoner running, pursued by Mr. Collotte, who captured himâ€”I went up, and he was given into my custodyâ€”Mr. Collette said, "This man has attempted to pass a bad

Cheque at the City Bank, Sloane Street"â€”the prisoner said nothingâ€”he was taken back to the bankâ€”he said nothing to me on the way, nor did he point anyone out to meâ€”at the bank he said, "A man gave it to me at the corner of Sloane Street to change for him "â€”he gave the description of a man, 6 ft., with black coat and black moustache, and I looked round, but could not see anyone answering the descriptionâ€”he did not point to anyone and say, "That is the man," or anything of that sortâ€”I only found a cutting from a newspaper on himâ€”I took him to the station.

Cross-examined. When Collette said the prisoner had attempted to pass a bad cheque the prisoner did not say, "I am innocent"â€”I must have heard it if he had said itâ€”I did not see him whisper to Mr. Colletteâ€”as we walked back to the bank the prisoner did not indicate by a motion someone on the other side of the streetâ€”he did not say at the bank, "I pointed out and motioned to the policeman someone who gave me the document"â€”all he did say was, "A man gave it to me at the corner of Sloane Street to change for him"â€”when I came out of the bank I looked round and could not see the man; we were in the bank no time; we just walked in and out againâ€”he did not say the man had some rolls of paper in his hand.

GEORGE SCOTT . I am proprietor of the Duke of Albemarle public-house, Stafford Street, Bond Streetâ€”at half-past twelve on the morning of the 6th I fastened up my houseâ€”I had in my bar a small cupboard in which was this cancelled chequeâ€”about three a. m. I was awoke by the policeâ€”I examined my premises, and found there had been a breaking, and afterwards I found that this cheque and other things were goneâ€”I had changed my account to another branch of the bank, and this cheque was in the pocket of the old pass-book.
NOT GUILTY .

803.
There was another indictment against the prisoner
for burglary in the dwelling-house of
George Scott, and stealing Â£30 5s., cigars, and other articles. Upon this indictment MR. SANDS offered no evidence.
NOT GUILTY .

804.
WILLIAM JOHN CHEVALIER LOOMES (27)
PLEADED GUILTY to marrying
Elizabeth Ann Wickens during the lifetime of his wife. The prisoner received a good character.â€”
Three Months' Hard Labour

805.
GEORGE WILLIAM BEACH (17)
, to burglary in the dwelling-house of
Matthew Lyons, and stealing a quantity of salmon and other articles; also to a conviction of felony in February, 1888.â€”
Four Days' Imprisonment.
[Pleaded guilty: See original trial image.] And

(806).
THOMAS KENNEDY (19),
to stealing two pairs of boots, the goods of
William Witham; and also, with
THOMAS JONES (21)
, to burglary in the dwelling-house of
Lewis Samuel Woolf, and stealing an overcoat and other articles. KENNEDY also PLEADED GUILTY to a conviction of felony in March, 1888, and JONES** to one in December, 1890.JONASâ€”
Fifteen Months' Hard Labour ; and KENNEDYâ€”
Twelve Months' Hard Labour.
[Pleaded guilty: See original trial image.]

807.
REBECCA JESSIE SMITH, Feloniously
setting fire to the dwelling-house of
William Stephen Baker, he and others being therein.

WILLIAM STEPHEN BAKER . I am employed at the General Post Office, and lire at 17, Glasgow Terrace, in which house the prisoner lived and was the landladyâ€”on the evening of 6th October, about nine, I heard her saying that she would set fire to the b----houseâ€”she was in the habit of using expressions of that sortâ€”about half-past nine my sister called meâ€”I came downstairs and I saw a lot of fire, and when I got to the bottom I saw that a counterpane was burning and a strange man trying to tread the fire outâ€”I got water and put it outâ€”the prisoner was then leaving the house.

Cross-examined.
