I lived with my mother on the first and second floorsâ€”the prisoner occupied the basementâ€”I had been there since Aprilâ€”the prisoner used such expressions so frequently that I took no notice of themâ€”I saw Mrs. Howard at the street door as the prisoner was going outâ€”I threw some water over the prisoner in my temper.

By the COURT. The prisoner was always in drink, more often than not, and talking to herselfâ€”there had been no quarrelâ€”she had never done anything of the sort beforeâ€”there was no damage done, there was no timeâ€”her bedroom was a back room level with the streetâ€”the counterpane was a large oneâ€”it was in flames, very nearly burnt outâ€”it burnt the staircaseâ€”the street door was open.

DAVID JOSEPH RICE . I am a member of the fire brigade stationed in Francis Streetâ€”on 6th October I was called to 17, Glasgow Terraceâ€”I found that a counterpane at the bottom of the stairs had been burnt it was out when I got thereâ€”I saw the prisoner, and asked her the cause of the fireâ€”she said she was lighting a lamp, and threw the match on the counterpane, which was in the passageâ€”the stairs were slightly damaged by fireâ€”I produce the counterpane.
Cross-examined. I did not notice a lamp outside the kitchen, there was one inside on the table.
By the COURT. The prisoner did not appear to be affected by drink she was quietâ€”if the counterpane had been well alight it would have set the staircase alightâ€”it was in a dangerous situation.

FREDERICK BARFOOT . I live in Lupus Street, and am a clerk in the Army and Navy Storesâ€”I was at 17, Glasgow Terrace about nine on 6th Octoberâ€”I saw the prisoner, and heard her say she would set fire to the bâ€”â€”curtainsâ€”about five afterwards I smelt the fire.
Cross-examined. She was mumbling to herself as she was wandering about the house.

ANNIE BAKER . I live on the first and second floors at 17â€”on 6th October, about half-past nine, I was sent for, and when I got to the house I saw the prisoner in the passageâ€”I knew there had been a fireâ€”I called her a wicked womanâ€”she told me she had dropped a match.
Cross-examined. This counterpane was used as a coverlet to her own bed, on the ground floor.

CAROLINE HOWARD . I live next door to the prisonerâ€”between nine and ten she came to me and said, "I have dropped a match and set some things alight; it is blazing"â€”she looked very agitated, distressed and worriedâ€”I went in with her and took a pail of waterâ€”I saw something on fire at the bottom of the stairs.
Cross-examined. I have known her four years as a good respectable neighbour, except when she took a little drinkâ€”I did not see any sign of drink on her on this occasion.

GEORGE JEFFRIES (Inspector B). The prisoner was brought to the stationâ€”when the charge was read to her she said, "I am not guilty of what I am charged with"â€”I went to the house next morningâ€”the lower step of the stairs was slightly burnt, and two other steps were slightly scorched.
FREDERICK LARKIN (B 485). I took the prisoner into custodyâ€”she said, "Nobody saw me do it; I am innocent of the charge. "

W. S. BAKER (Re-examined). There was usually a tin lamp on a small wooden ledge at the bottom of the stairs leading to the kitchen, but it was not alight that night; I could not say even that it was on the ledge; it was near the counterpane.
NOT GUILTY .

808.
GEORGE HOFFNER (43)
, Feloniously wounding
John Praunsmandell, with intent to murder; Second Count, to do grievous bodily harm.

JOHN PRAUNSMANDELL . I am a commission agent, of 111, Edgware Roadâ€”on 30th September I was at the German Exhibitionâ€”I had an information office there for the benefit of the exhibitorsâ€”Mr. Bargin was with me from three in the afternoon up to the time this occurredâ€”I saw the prisoner in the groundsâ€”he was not an acquaintanceâ€”I knew him by sightâ€”I was walking; along, and all at once the prisoner came in front of me; Le put his finger in my collar, and knocked my hat off with his umbrella, and said, "I will kill you, you cur"â€”he put his hand in his pocket and pulled out a knife, about five inches longâ€”I stooped down, or else it would have come right at my throat; I ran awayâ€”I felt blood running down my neckâ€”I fetched a constable and returned with him; the prisoner came at me again and aimed a second blow, but I kept away from himâ€”he used bad languageâ€”I left him in the hands of the policeman and a foreign manâ€”I went to the police-station; the prisoner there said, "I am sorry I have not killed you, you cur, but I shall do for you when I come out again"â€”it is not true that I have had any improper intercourse with his wifeâ€”I never saw the woman in my life.

Cross-examined. There is no reason for his making any attack upon meâ€”he is a cook, not at the Exhibition; he takes employment when he can get itâ€”I have seen him there occasionallyâ€”I never had any words with himâ€”I could not tell whether ho was in drink; the affair was like a flash of lightningâ€”when I saw the knife I was so nervous and excited I ran away.

GUSTAVE BARGIN . I am a restaurant proprietorâ€”on 30th September I was with the prosecutor at the German Exhibitionâ€”I was a caterer there; I have known the prisoner many yearsâ€”as I went through the grounds I saw him and said, "How are you?" and offered my hand; he refused itâ€”I thought it strange, as I had never done him any harmâ€”he is a professional cookâ€”he said, "I want you; you must give me some work to do"â€”I said, "The Exhibition is over now and there is nothing to do; will you have a glass?" and we had a glass of whisky eachâ€”he seemed rather strange and very much excited; all at once the prosecutor

came and tapped me on the shoulder and said a person wanted to sea me; as soon as the prisoner saw him he was all fire and flame, and he said, "Oh, you know that vagabond?" and gave him all sorts of namesâ€”I said, "I know him as a gentleman, that is all"â€”there were a few words between me and the prisoner, and I said, "You must not use such bad language here"; the prosecutor said to me, "I don't know the man"â€”the prisoner then said, "That man has ruined my home and made a whore of my wife," and all sorts of things, and then all at once he knocked his hat off and had him by the neck, and then the prosecutor ran awayâ€”I did not see a blowâ€”the prosecutor came back with a policemanâ€”the prisoner made no attempt to run away when he saw the policeman; it took three men to keep him; I then saw the knife in his hand for the first time, and I said to the policeman, "Take care, he has got a knife"â€”he tried to stab the prosecutor againâ€”he was in an awful state.

Cross-examined. I have known him for some timeâ€”I never knew any
thing against him; only when he has had a glass he is not worth anythingâ€”I think he had had a good deal on this occasionâ€”I do not know that he has suffered from delirium tremens, but when he is in that state he is not worth anything for months.

Re-examined. I won't say that he was exactly drunk; he might have had something to drink; he was excited; he could drink more, and then he would be more drunkâ€”I asked him to have a glass of whisky, because I wanted to know why he refused my hand.

GEORGE SMITH . I was a porter at the lager beer stall at the German Exhibitionâ€”on 30th September I saw the prisoner and prosecutor and Mr. Bargin there standing talking; the prisoner was talking in rather a high tone of voice for a few seconds; I did not see any blowâ€”I heard him say, "I will kill you, you cur!" or "you hound!" "I am sorry I have not done it now"â€”I saw this knife in his hand.

HENRY ALLEN . I was a fireman at the German Exhibitionâ€”I was present when the prosecutor pointed out the prisoner to the constable; they were a few yards from each otherâ€”I saw the prisoner make a second attempt to stab him; it was not a very serious attempt; he reached over my shoulder; the prosecutor was behind meâ€”the constable took hold of him, and I took the knife from him; I did not notice any blood upon itâ€”if I had not been in the way the blow might probably have struck him.

Cross-examined. I don't say it would have struck him; I could not see how far the prosecutor was behind meâ€”the prisoner clasped the knife very tight in his handâ€”there was no difficulty in getting itâ€”the constable and I seized him togetherâ€”he did not attempt to strike me; I caught him by the wrist, and held his arm with both my hands.

MAITLAND COFFIN , F. R. C. S. The prosecutor was brought to me on the evening of 30th September; he had a slight incised cut at the back of the neck, about two inches longâ€”from the description I had I should say the knife went over the shoulder, and the side of the blade nicked the back of the neck and sliced it, and made a slight woundâ€”I put a piece of plaister on it; I did not see it afterwardsâ€”the knife had probably slipped; it just cut the skinâ€”it was only enough to draw a few drops of blood; if it had gone in straight it might have caused a severe wound;
it would have caught him somewhere in the cheatâ€”it might have been caused by a weapon similar to this knife.

WILLIAM PASCOE (J 401). I was on duty at the Exhibitionâ€”the prosecutor came up to me and made a statementâ€”he had blood running from a wound at the back of the neck; not a great dealâ€”he had a handkerchief on itâ€”I accompanied him to the prisoner, and told him I should take him into custodyâ€”he said nothingâ€”he put his hand in his pocket and pulled out a knife, and rushed at the prosecutorâ€”I did not hear what he saidâ€”I called the fireman to my assistance to take the knife out of his hand; he was violentâ€”I caught him by the left arm when I came upâ€”the knife was in his right-hand pocket, and when he came up to the prosecutor he took it outâ€”the prosecutor was standing behind me, a little to the leftâ€”the prisoner rushed by me to him, but I seized him by the right arm then and so prevented himâ€”I took him to the station; he went quietlyâ€”he had been drinking; he was not drunk, he was very excitedâ€”at the station he said, "I am sorry I did not kill the b----hound; I will do him yet, the first chance I get. My wife is a whore, and it is he has made her one" pointing to the prosecutor.
Cross-examined. The knife was open when he pulled it out of his pocketâ€”it is an ordinary cook's knifeâ€”it will not shut.

GUILTY
on the Second Count. â€”
Eighteen Months' Hard Labour.

p.hi: The prisoner's wife stated that he had lately suffered from delusions, and had acted strangely, but teas very kind to her. The
recommended that he should be watched, and the state of his mind be attended to.

div1.p:
809.
HENRY BENJAMIN SAMUELS (31)
PLEADED GUILTY to a libel on
Charles Saul Comer.

p.rs: To enter into his own recognizances of Â£500 to come up for judgment when called upon.

div1.p:
810. The said
HENRY BENJAMIN SAMUELS was again indicted
for feloniously sending to
Charles Saul Comer a letter demanding money, with menaces.
MR. BURNIE, for the prosecution, offered no evidence.
NOT GUILTY .

811.
ANNIE DAVIS, Feloniously
killing and slaying
Grace Sunman.
MR. HUTTON, for the prosecution, offered no evidence.
NOT GUILTY .

812. The said
ANNIE DAVIS was again indicted
for unlawfully neglecting
Grace Sunman, a girl aged about six months, in a manner likely to cause unnecessary suffering and injury to her health.

ELLEN SARAH SUNMAN . I am a laundress, of 30, Luke Streetâ€”I am a single womanâ€”Grace Sunman was my daughterâ€”she was born on 29th Marchâ€”a person, I. cannot say the name of, in Doynton Street, had it to nurse at about eight or nine weeks oldâ€”then it was at home with meâ€”my landlady looked after it in the daytime while I went to work, till I came home at nightâ€”then I placed it with Mrs. Keel for six weeks, and on the 20th July with the prisonerâ€”it was then a beautiful, fat, healthy babyâ€”during the first three weeks I used to go very often to see itâ€”I only saw it about twice,

every Tuesdayâ€”it was always asleepâ€”I did not think the mother of seven children would deceive me over my child, and she said it had just gone to bed, or had just been put to bedâ€”a week or two after that I complained about not seeing itâ€”then it was brought to meâ€”to look at its face I would not have thought there was anything the matter with itâ€”I noticed it looked so stupefiedâ€”I did not examine itâ€”on Monday, 24th August, having been there and not seen it on the previous Saturday and Sunday because it was asleep, I took it to the doctor'sâ€”the prisoner said she had had one child die in her house, and would not have my child die there, because of her husbandâ€”when I saw it on the Monday I used the expression, "Good God! this is my child; if sixpence was all I had in the world, I will take it to a medical man this night," and bounced in front of herâ€”she said on the Saturday it wanted a doctorâ€”I said, "If you think so, take it to a doctor, and I will pay you as soon as I earn the money," but she did not do soâ€”on the Monday I took it to Mrs. Wiston, of 13, Schofield Roadâ€”the prisoner did not say she must have the money for the doctorâ€”I had paid her five shillings a week up to this dateâ€”the same night I took it to Dr. McAusland from her house; she went with meâ€”the doctor examined itâ€”the prisoner was in the next roomâ€”she must have heard what was saidâ€”the door was openâ€”the doctor said it was dying, "I am afraid the mother is not in time to save its life"; then I took it to Mrs., Wiston'sâ€”it stayed there till 5th September, when it died.

Cross-examined. I have had two other childrenâ€”they are still alive, with the fatherâ€”I suckled this seven weeksâ€”I went to my employment daily, occasionallyâ€”I was out from about 9 till about 6, 6.30, or 7â€”the child had my breast at nightâ€”I went out in the eveningâ€”my child was put to bed or went with meâ€”I came home when I thought I would, not later than 10 or 9.30â€”I knew the child was fed on condensed milk and biscuitsâ€”I asked advice and studied my baby; I changed its clothes in the evening when I came homeâ€”it had condensed milk in a bottle, because it agreed with the breast milk, those were the doctor's ordersâ€”I gave my child the breast when I thought I would, as mothers doâ€”now and then I went to my employmentâ€”I have not seen Mrs. Maddox, of Doynton Street, here to-dayâ€”from Doynton Street the child was taken for a week to Mrs. Tichinerâ€”that is the same houseâ€”one week it was downstairs, the next it went upâ€”I did not complain to the neighbours of Mrs. Maddoxâ€”I found a louse upon it, but it was not dirty, it might have gone out in the street and picked it up, when close to other peopleâ€”the child's clothes were not dirtyâ€”my landlady never had the chance to complain of the child crying, she might do so to do me an injuryâ€”both landladies bear me an ill-willâ€”I have not had a dispute with Mrs. Ellen this morning outside this courtâ€”I have not spoken to her, nor as much as looked at her; I should notâ€”the child was not placed with a woman in Colver Streetâ€”I know there is a midwife thereâ€”I never left the child there while I went to work, and took it back at nightâ€”Mrs. Tichiner never said it was constantly crying, and not thrivingâ€”she is one who bears me ill-willâ€”when the prisoner had had the child two days she said her husband would not allow her to have the baby, would I take it away; I said I certainly would not allow my child to disturb any woman's homeâ€”she said it disturbed her husbandâ€”I said, "I have someone coming to take it"â€”then she sent word I was not to trouble,
as her husband said she could keep itâ€”I did not suckle the child after it was seven weeks oldâ€”I did not take it back to the prisoner after it had. seen the doctor.
Re-examined, I was going to fetch the child the same night when the message came not to take it away.

ELIZA KEEL . I am the wife of Thomas Keel, of 67, Emden Road, Upper Hollowayâ€”I had care of the child six weeks up to 20th Julyâ€”it was a fat, plump, healthy little thingâ€”I saw it again on 24th Augustâ€”it was then a perfect little skeletonâ€”it was always quite healthy when with me.

Cross-examined. I gave the child up at 12.45 a. m.â€”the mother took it at a moment's noticeâ€”I fed it with Nestle's tinned milk and Robb's biscuitsâ€”I never gave it ordinary milk and sugarâ€”it was not because the child was unhealthy or the mother dissatisfied that the mother took it awayâ€”it was a week with Mrs. Tichiner to mind for me, my husband was ill, and I could not take it that week.

MARY WHITE . I am the wife of Charles White, of 28, Newlop Street, South Highgate; I had the child four hours on 20th Julyâ€”it was in good conditionâ€”very healthyâ€”quite plumpâ€”I next saw it in Schofield Road the same monthâ€”about three days afterwardsâ€”it was very emaciatedâ€”Mrs. Wiston had the child thenâ€”I do not know when it died.

Cross-examined. I am no friend of the prisonerâ€”I am not relatedâ€”the child was merely brought to me to mind while the mother went to workâ€”I had it in my arms about an hour, and then it went to sleepâ€”it was a remarkably plump, healthy childâ€”I never saw such a remarkably fine child beforeâ€”I never saw such a thin emaciated child as it was afterwards.

CHARLOTTE WENT . I am the wife of Robert Went, of 30, Newlop Street, South Highgateâ€”Miss Sunman was a lodgerâ€”I saw the child two or three times before it was put out to Mrs. Keelâ€”it was a nice healthy, strong baby when it was removedâ€”I did not see it afterwards.
Cross-examined. The mother called me to see what a beautiful child it was.

JANE WISTON . I am a widow, of 13, Schofield Road, Upper Hollowayâ€”when the child was brought on the 24th August I undressed and washed itâ€”its clothes were very dirty from its diarrhÅ“aâ€”it was dreadfully thinâ€”I took it to the doctor the next dayâ€”the doctor saw it the day I had itâ€”I continued to nurse it, and the doctor to attend it till the 5th September, when it died.

Cross-examined. It suffered very badly from diarrhÅ“aâ€”there was nothing dirty except what you would expect from diarrhÅ“aâ€”while with me it had corn-flour, Nestle's milk, and loaf sugarâ€”it was too ill to eat biscuits, or to take anything moreâ€”it improved a littleâ€”it ate its food very ravenouslyâ€”it also had beef-tea and brandy.

ANDREW MCAUSLAND . I am a medical man, of 68, St. John's Road, Upper Hollowayâ€”I attended Grace Sunman on 24th August, about eight p. mâ€”the mother brought it with Mrs. Wiston, and the prisoner was in the other roomâ€”I examined the child; it was in a very dirty conditionâ€”the lower part of the trunk and thighs were covered with excoriations in a raw state; it was in great pain, and cryingâ€”I

should say the excoriations were due to the want of cleanliness and proper attentionâ€”the child was wet and dirty, and steaming when broughtâ€”that caused the excoriationsâ€”it vomitedâ€”I prescribed for itâ€”it was brought to me on the 26th; it had improved a little, and its skin had improved considerablyâ€”I attended on the 5th, when it diedâ€”I did not weigh it when brought to meâ€”it was weighed in the mortuaryâ€”it weighed 7lb. 13oz.â€”I was present at the post-mortem examinationâ€”I attribute its death to exhaustion, arising from want of proper care and attentionâ€”I attended the prisoner's house on the 23rd; a Sunday eveningâ€”the evening before the child was brought to meâ€”I went to attend another childâ€”no mention was made of this childâ€”I saw Mrs. Davis.

Cross-examined. I do not think it would be correct to say that diarrhÅ“a and improper food accounted for the death of this childâ€”diarrhÅ“a coming from improper food in a child of that age would very likely cause deathâ€”I should not recommend sopped biscuitâ€”in some children it would produce diarrhÅ“aâ€”I do not know that diarrhÅ“a is more common in children in August than in any other monthâ€”I say that death was accelerated by the want of proper care and attention, and the child suffering great painâ€”the diarrhÅ“a would not have produced inflammation if it had been kept cleanâ€”excoriation is not uncommon, if there is want of cleanlinessâ€”diarrhÅ“a and vomiting were from improper feedingâ€”that would account for death; but I said before the Magistrate that death was acceleratedâ€”I said: "I made a. post-mortem examination; I found no organic disease whatever; diarrhÅ“a and improper feeding would account for death"â€”in this case it wouldâ€”(Read: "And the post-mortem fortified and corroborated my opinion ")â€”I never said that I said, after speaking of weight, "A child of this age should have nothing but milk and water"â€”feeding a child on sops and biscuit is a very common cause of diarrhÅ“aâ€”I was of opinion that its death was accelerated by its previous pain from excoriation of the thighs and the lower part of the body.

AUGUSTUS JOSEPH PEPPER . I practise at Wimborne Streetâ€”I assisted Dr. McAusland to make a post mortem examination of this childâ€”from the evidence I heard before the Coroner and my observations at the examination, I came to the conclusion that death was accelerated by diarrhÅ“a, and that the primary cause of death was either improper feeding or an insufficient amount of foodâ€”the excoriations were very slight, nearly goneâ€”it would be difficult to keep a child free from excoriations if it had contracted diarrhÅ“a.

Cross-examined. Even under a mother's eye such excoriations as I saw might ariseâ€”Robb's biscuits and condensed milk would be improper dietâ€”that would very likely produce diarrhÅ“aâ€”death, if not caused, was accelerated by diarrhÅ“aâ€”if the child was nursed by the mother night and morning the ill-effects of feeding on farinaceous food and condensed milk would be very much greater than if it was entirely fed on it.

Re-examined. The diet would not have such a rapid effect unless it caused diarrhÅ“a quite early, and that continued from 20th to 24th Julyâ€”I found no sign of organic disease; it was clearly a case of improper feeding.
ANDREW MCAUSLAND (Re-examined). I should say the excoriations were not due alone to diarrhÅ“a, because they extended over the buttocks,
and were not confined to the anus and genitalsâ€”excoriations may last three or four daysâ€”they resulted from the child being left in a wet condition.

The prisoner's statement before the Magistrate: "The baby was in that condition when I first received it, and I did my best to try and bring it round, but I could not. Nearly all the evidence that is brought here is false. I will call my witnesses at the trial."

JANET DAVIS . I am the prisoner's daughterâ€”I fetched the childâ€”it was very thin, except its face, and had sore eyes, and a spotty rash on it, and was extremely weakâ€”I took care of itâ€”fed and washed it, and so onâ€”it slept with meâ€”it was fed en condensed milk and Robb's biscuits first, but it did not get on, so mamma tried Ridge's food; and the last part of the time it was fed on cows' milk and barley-water, with a little brandyâ€”mamma spoke to the mother about the rashâ€”she replied, "Oh, take no notice of that, Mrs. Davis, her brother was like it"â€”I did not notice any diarrhÅ“aâ€”on 24th August I had it all the afternoon in my careâ€”I had the principal care of it down to the 24th of Augustâ€”I did not wash it, but I used to get the bath ready for it.

Cross-examined. It slept in my bed every nightâ€”I never noticed diarrhÅ“a, only as an ordinary child should beâ€”it was not very ill when taken away; it was not wellâ€”it was always very thinâ€”it was not more thin when taken away than when we had it; not so thinâ€”it was not very ill on the Sundayâ€”my mother said several times it wanted a doctor, but the mother said there was no necessity, but that something was the matter with its headâ€”Dr. McAusland was not asked to see the child on the Sunday he came to the houseâ€”I saw the child thenâ€”mamma undressed itâ€”I slept with itâ€”it was not dirtyâ€”I saw it bathed the morning it went awayâ€”I did not notice the excoriations round its buttocks.

ELIZABETH HARRIET ELLEN . I live at 9, Doynton Street, Highgateâ€”I am the landlady of Sarah Sunman, the child's motherâ€”it was a fortnight and three days old when it came to my houseâ€”the mother suckled it from three to four weeks afterwardsâ€”she went to work two days one week, and three days anotherâ€”I took care of the child in her absenceâ€”I fed it on Robb's biscuits and Nestle's milkâ€”it had skin disease and the thrushâ€”it was not a healthy plump child; it was always pining and cryingâ€”I spoke to its mother about thatâ€”when the mother went out in the evening the child was not left with me; she used to put it to bed and go out and leave itâ€”I heard it crying, and used to go up and fetch it down, feed it, and change it.

Cross-examined. It was emaciatedâ€”I think it was pining for the breast milkâ€”it gradually fell offâ€”it was all red on one sideâ€”I washed itâ€”I saw sores on the buttocks; the skin would come offâ€”it was not dirtyâ€”I have had three children.

MARY ANN TICHINER . I live at 1, Mortimer Terrace, Highgateâ€”I had the child from the 25th May till the following Mondayâ€”I handed it to Mrs. Keel in the same houseâ€”it came from Riden Street, Highgate New Townâ€”Mrs. Ellen lived there thenâ€”it had skin disease and the thrush, and if you laid it in a certain way it would come out in red spots wherever you laid itâ€”I fed it, by its mother's advice, on Robb's biscuits and condensed milkâ€”I am a nurse, but I do not feed babies on Robb's biscuits and Nestle's milk, and I have brought a great many children upâ€”the

mother brought me the biscuitsâ€”thrush is not skin disease; it comes in the mouth, and you have to carry it throughâ€”it goes from the bottom part of the tongueâ€”I saw it every day whilst in Mrs. Keel's careâ€”she fed it on Robb's biscuitsâ€”the mother said Mrs. Keel did not treat her baby properlyâ€”she fetched it away about a quarter to one at night through meâ€”I did not like the treatmentâ€”the baby was never healthy; it was flabby, never got on, and was continually crying.
Cross-examined. It was not skinny, but had fallen away at the bottom part; not in the face.

ANNIE DAVIS (the prisoner). When I received the baby it had a rash, was sore, extremely weak, had very little fat, was flabby; and the reason given to me was it was sadly neglected, and I took it out of kindnessâ€”I fed it, as the mother wished, on condensed milk and biscuits for nearly three weeks, when she refused the foodâ€”I thought the milk was not sufficient, and tried Dr. Ridge's foodâ€”in a few days it refused thatâ€”then I tried cow's milk and a little brandyâ€”it did not suffer from diarrhÅ“a before she left meâ€”I always kept it clean; I bathed it in the morning or in the evening; I changed it, and laid it on my couch, where the mother found itâ€”simply spite has brought me here because I made the mother take the baby away.

Cross-examined. I say the evidence is falseâ€”it might be dirty from diarrhÅ“a on 24thâ€”it never missed its bath with me, because after its bath was the only time it sleptâ€”I agreed to take the baby till I could get one from the Home, and on' the Monday the mother promised to retch itâ€”it was not more ill on the Sunday, but it never seemed to repay the trouble I took with itâ€”the mother always expressed gratitude, and said I did my duty till I suggested she should take it awayâ€”the child suffered from diarrhÅ“a on the Sunday afternoon; it had not suffered from it for some days; it had a touch of itâ€”when I changed it on Sunday at tea-time it was not soreâ€”the doctor told me there was nothing the matter with the baby when we took it to him.
ANDREW MCAUSLAND (Re-examined). Robb's biscuits are in favour among the London poor as food for babies, but that is a popular delusion.
NOT GUILTY .

813.
SAMUEL KEMP
PLEADED GUILTY to feloniously marrying
Florence Fanny Offer, his wife being alive.â€”
Four Months' Hard Labour. And

(814).
EDWARD GREEN
, to an indecent assault upon
Alice Maud Watson, a girl under thirteen.â€”
Three Months' Hard Labour.
[Pleaded guilty: See original trial image.]

815.
JOHN HENRY ROSEWARNE (35)
, Forging and uttering an order for the payment of Â£5 5s., with intent to defraud.
NOT GUILTY ,

816.
JOHN HENRY ROSEWARNE was again indicted
for. burglary in the dwelling-house of
William Latham, and stealing twenty cheque forms and other articles, his property.
HUGH LATHAM . I live with my father, William Latham, at 18, Harley

Gardens, Kensingtonâ€”I have an account at the London and County Bank, Kensington branchâ€”I last used my cheque-book on 11th December, 1890â€”I then left it at 18, Harley Gardens, with twenty unused cheques in itâ€”the two cheques produced are part of the property I missed after a burglary there when I was out of town.

RACUEL SOPHIA FOX . I live at 37, Radnor Street, Shepherd's Bushâ€”I was in charge of 18, Harley Gardensâ€”on 7th September I went to bed about eleven p.m.â€”I was the last person upâ€”the doors and windows were all closed and fastenedâ€”I went downstairs about eight the next morningâ€”I noticed the young ladies' dressing-room door open, which had been closed when I went to bedâ€”several drawers had been disarrangedâ€”two coats were lying on the floor in the hallâ€”I sent for Mr. Harrisâ€”after the police had been sent for I missed a cheque-book from a drawer in the drawing-roomâ€”the catch of the kitchen window had been tampered withâ€”a small piece had been broken out so that a person could get inâ€”the window was all right when I went to bed.

PAUL ALMARK (Police Sergeant F). On 9th September I was fetched to 18, Harley Gardens about 9.30 a. m. by a Mr. Harrisâ€”the area window catch was broken, and a small hole made, big enough to insert something close to the catchâ€”the glass had been brokenâ€”there were marks corresponding with this chisel (produced)â€”there would be no difficulty in opening the window; the marks were both inside and outsideâ€”a cupboard in the front room downstairs had been broken open, and there were marks corresponding with this chisel on the doors of the cupboardâ€”an upstairs room was in great disorder, drawers being pulled out and things strewn about.

ROBERT DAY (Police Sergeant T). I arrested the prisoner on 23rd Septemberâ€”he said nothing in answer to this chargeâ€”he was arrested for another offence and remandedâ€”I searched him and found this cheque.

Cross-examined by the Prisoner. I called you out of a public-house in King Street, Hammersmithâ€”I was told you were staying at a lodging-houseâ€”I made inquiriesâ€”I was told you had been there two or three weeks.

HENRY BLYTH BOTTING . I am a corn broker, at 147, Leadenhall Streetâ€”the prisoner came to me, I believe, on 23rd Septemberâ€”I knew himâ€”he asked me to cash a cheque (produced)â€”I gave him Â£2 on accountâ€”it was returned from my bank marked "No account"â€”the prisoner wrote his name on the back of it in my office.

Cross-examined. We were friends seventeen or eighteen years agoâ€”we lost sight of each other for about ten yearsâ€”I believe you went to the Cape and enlistedâ€”I believe you came into some money thirteen or fourteen years agoâ€”my sister married your fatherâ€”if I had doubted the cheque was genuine I should not have sent it to my bankersâ€”I assisted you.
Re-examined. I cannot say I am acquainted with the prisoner's writingâ€”I saw him endorse the chequeâ€”I cannot express an opinion on the writing in the body of the cheque.
EDITH ROSEWARNE . I am the prisoner's sisterâ€”I live at 85, St. Dunstan's Road, West Kensingtonâ€”I cannot say for certain that the writing on this cheque is his.
Cross-examined. You were thirty-five last Juneâ€”I was only a child when we came into mother's property; I do not know

what you hadâ€”I believe you went abroadâ€”I know you went into the army, because I visited you at Aldershotâ€”I was not seven years without seeing youâ€”I have not seen you for three yearsâ€”I do not think that I had not previously seen you for seven yearsâ€”you have told me so many untruths I do not remember what you have said.
PAUL ALMARK (Re-examined). Mr. Harris handed me this chiselâ€”he is in Courtâ€”that was in the house.

WILLIAM HARRIS . I was sent for to this houseâ€”I found this chisel on the table in the servants' hall, with some clothes, and this small knifeâ€”I am a builderâ€”one of the men told me something, and I fetched the policeâ€”I gave the chisel to the sergeantâ€”I do not know anything about it.

The prisoner, in his defence, said that the cheque he gave to Botting was paid him by Edward Claude Arkell, to whom he had lent Â£25 about fourteen yean ago, and had met in a public-house on 22nd September; that the cheque for four guineas and other cheques Arkell asked him to cash for him, saying, when asked his address, he would be sure to meet him again if he was staying in London; that he knew nothing of the forgery, and was expecting the balance, when he was arrested for a crime he was innocent of.
NOT GUILTY .

817.
STEPHEN F. BROWNE, For
a libel on
Herbert Standing. No evidence was offered.â€”
NOT GUILTY .

818.
GEORGE GOODALL (51)
, Robbery with violence on
Bryce Boyd, and stealing a watch and chain, his property.

BRYCE BOYD . I live at 15, Manchester Streetâ€”on October 5th, about 9.15, I was standing by the church in Argyle Squareâ€”the prisoner came up with another man and covered me all over, and put his face about two inches from mineâ€”he knocked me downâ€”I got up and ran after him, and kept within two yards of him, and saw him pass a watch to his accomplice, who turned to the left and pretended to be very drunk; the prisoner turned to me and said, "Go away; it is no good now"â€”he walked to Derby Street and again said, "Go away; go away"â€”he retraced his steps, and I told a policeman to take him, which he didâ€”he said nothingâ€”I am certain he is the man, he was never more than two yards from me.

Cross-examined by the prisoner. I did not come up and say, "I shall charge you with stealing my watch, nor did you say, "Go away; I know nothing about your watch"â€”the watch was not mentionedâ€”you did not walk with mo to the policeman, he came from a side streetâ€”there was only five minutes from the robbery to your arrestâ€”I was not with any woman.

CHARLES EMERICK (E 285). I was on duty in Argyle Squareâ€”Mr. Boyd spoke to me, and I saw the prisoner leaning against some railings looking away from me towards Boyd, who said, "I want to give this man in custody for stealing my watch"â€”I said, "Is that right?"â€”the prisoner said, "No"â€”I took him to the station, he was charged and said, "I know nothing about it"â€”I found 7s. 6d. in silver on himâ€”the watch has not been found.
Cross-examined. You and Boyd did not walk across the road to meâ€”you did not walk to meet meâ€”you went quietly with me.

Prisoner's Defence. Two men asked me the way to the Underground Railway station; I told them, and the prisoner came up and said, "You have stolen my watch. "I said, "I know nothing of you or your watch. "I was walking about with him five or six minutes, up one street and down another. I had plenty of chance to get away if I wished.

GUILTY .â€”
Nine Months' Hard Labour.

819.
GEORGE GILLHAM (35)
, Feloniously wounding
John Allen Hammond, with intent to do him some grievous bodily harm.

JOHN ALLEN HAMMOND . I live at 40, Britannia Street, St. Pancrasâ€”the prisoner was a lodger of mineâ€”May West was also there, and my motherâ€”on October 9, about eight o'clock, the prisoner came slowly into the kitchen without his bootsâ€”I was sitting by the fire reading the paper, and he made a rush at May Westâ€”I got up and said, "This is not your room"â€”he said, "You b----f----, you have been committing adultery with my wife"â€”I told him to go out of the kitchenâ€”he made a blow at me, but I ducked my head, it passed over my shoulder, but his chest came against me, and I fell on the sofaâ€”I got my foot behind him and tripped him up, and threw him into the washhouseâ€”in trying to shut the kitchen door to shut him out, he caught me by my shoulder, and I saw some instrument coming down shining; I did not knock his arm sufficiently, and it struck me on my templeâ€”I threw him down and got away from himâ€”him said, "You----, I will do for you"â€”I ran up and threw him and his brother outâ€”there were ten or twelve lads with himâ€”he rushed at me, but I got on one side and he fellâ€”I followed him up the street to a public-house, and met a friend who had two coats, one of which I put on, as I was in my shirt sleeves, and they did not know meâ€”I lost the prisoner, and went to the hospital and had my eye done, and then went to Bagnigge Wells station and gave information.

Cross-examined. I was not on the bed with any womanâ€”I do not know the woman you are living withâ€”I did not say I would knock your brains outâ€”you came there as a single man eight weeks before; I saw no woman there.

MAY WEST . I have lodged eight months at the prisoner's houseâ€”on this Friday night I was sitting in the kitchen at a table opposite the windowâ€”the prosecutor was thereâ€”the prisoner came down and took something out of his pocket with his right hand and made a rush at meâ€”the prosecutor got up and warded off the blow from me, caught hold of the prisoner and threw him on the table, and then into the washhouse, and then over a washstandâ€”the prisoner had something shiny in his right hand, and it cut my finger when I went to ward off the blowâ€”he struck Hammond on his temple and I saw blood runningâ€”I ran upstairs and called for helpâ€”the prisoner said to me, "I will do for you"â€”previous to that, in the afternoon, I had been in the kitchen twice, and the prisoner said he would knife me; in fact, he said he would not mind hanging for me, and he was going to his brother to get a bit of steel put in to meâ€”I have never lived with him.
Cross-examined. I have not been there five weeks with youâ€”I first knew you when you came to lodge thereâ€”I know nothing of you except
that you were a lodger in the houseâ€”I slept with the landlady, who is a widow; the grievance is because I would not have anything to do with you.
By the COURT. He made proposals to me; he wishes me to live with him, and I won't.

JOHN ALEXANDER MILLER . I am surgeon to the policeâ€”I live at Clerkenwellâ€”I was called to the station and found Hammond suffering from an incised wound on his right temple, half-an-inch long, penetrating to the bone, and dividing the cartilageâ€”ho had also an incised wound on the back of a finger of his right handâ€”I dressed the woundsâ€”they must have been caused by a knife or sharp instrumentâ€”I sent him to the hospitalâ€”he is quite well now.

WILLIAM BLYTHE (Detective Sergeant G). On Saturday evening, October 10th, the day after this, the prosecutor gave the prisoner into my charge at Euston Tavern for stabbing himâ€”going to the station he said, "Last night when I came home I found this man" (meaning Howard) "having connection with the woman I am living with. I struck him and we had a fight. I never used a knife. "

The prisoner's statement before the Magistrate: "I met this young woman five weeks ago; she asked me to take her home. I took her home to my place and lived with her five weeks; on Friday night I went home, and through the area I could see the prosecutor having connection with her. I got a stick and struck him; he hit me and out my nose. That is all I have to say. "
WILLIAM BLYTHE (Re-examined). The prisoner had a slight mark on the right side of his nose.
Prisoners Defence. I am guilty of fighting with him, but am not guilty of using the knife.

GUILTY .â€”He then
PLEADED GUILTY** to a conviction at Middlesex Sessions on 29th January, 1879, in the name of
William Youngâ€”
Nine Months' Hard Labour.

820.
ALBERT ISAACS (26)
PLEADED GUILTY** to stealing a chain, the goods of
James Cromarty, and
to two other indictments for stealing chains, the goods of other persons; also to a conviction of felony in July, 1887.â€”
Judgment respited. And

(821)
ALICE NELSON (32)
to burglary in the dwelling-house of
John Tuck, and stealing an ulster and other articles; also
to stealing five sheets and other articles, the goods of
Herbert James Barratt, and
to stealing a cloak, the goods of
Margaret Stevenson , and to a conviction** of felony in July, 1891.â€”
Three Years' Penal Servitude.
[Pleaded guilty: See original trial image.]

p.hi: For cases tried in this Court this day, see Essex cases

div1.p:
822.
WILLIAM ALEXANDER WYNNE (39) was indicted
for the wilful murder of
Clara Elizabeth Wynne.
MESSRS. CHARLES MATHEWS and BIRON Prosecuted, and MR. C. F. GILL Defended,

After MR. MATHEWS had opened the case, MR. JUSTICE WEIGHT expressed an opinion that the evidence would scarcely be sufficient to support the charge of murder. MR. MATHEWS accepted the suggestion and offered no evidence.
NOT GUILTY .

823.
WILLIAM ALEXANDER WYNNE was again indicted
for feloniously wounding
Clara Elizabeth Wynne, with intent to murder. Second Count, with intent to do grievous bodily harm.

CHRISTINA CAMPBELL . I am the wife of Robert Campbell, of 11, Marl
borough Street, Harrow Roadâ€”the prisoner and his wife came to me in June, and lodged with me nearly seven weeks; they lived on very unhappy terms, they were always quarrelling; I have heard him threaten herâ€”on a Monday morning I was present when he gave her a black eyeâ€”he took some money out of her pocket and was going away with itâ€”she said she would follow himâ€”my daughter said, "If you go he will kill you, because he has said so"â€”they went and got some meat to put to her eyeâ€”he said, "If you follow me I will kill you"â€”he has called her dreadful names; this went on during the six weeks they lodged with meâ€”they left about the end of June or in Julyâ€”her shoulder was bleeding as she was getting away from him; it might have been by his nailâ€”I don't remember hearing threats on any other occasionâ€”they continued to live on unhappy terms to the very day they left.

Cross-examined. I lived at the top of the house, the prisoner lived in the back partâ€”I was a great deal in his wife's companyâ€”she used to run to me for refugeâ€”I don't know that the prisoner disliked meâ€”he never complained to me that I made his wife drinkâ€”she was not in the habit of drinking to my knowledgeâ€”I once saw her under the influence of drinkâ€”I saw her trying to get into her bed; she was staggering a little, she did not fall.

MALVINA MAYHEAD . I am the wife of Thomas Mayhead, of 42, Goulbourn Roadâ€”the prisoner and his wife took a furnished room at my house; the first floor backâ€”I heard no quarrelling until Friday, 7th Augustâ€”the deceased was brought home that night by two females a little after twelve, the worse for drinkâ€”the prisoner let her in, and he pushed her down on the stairs when she was half-way upâ€”she screamed and said, "You beast, you want to strangle me"â€”she sat on the stairs for half an hourâ€”she afterwards went into the room, and then there was quarrelling and screaming again from ten minutes to a quarter of an hour; then it was over till the next morning, Saturday; they had words and then left together at half-past eightâ€”at half-past twelve on Saturday night the prisoner came home very drunkâ€”he and his wife occupied the same room that nightâ€”about eight on the Sunday morning there were words, and he turned her out of the room; she went back and he turned her out again, and raced downstairs after her, and when he got to the bottom of the stairs he fell down; he had nothing on but his day shirtâ€”the woman left the house and sent him a note to meet herâ€”he met her at half-past nine, and they went away together; they seemed to be having words as they went down the road togetherâ€”she came back that night alone, and she remained there alone until the Tuesday about half-past twelve or oneâ€”he was not at home on Sunday or Mondayâ€”

about half-past twelve on Tuesday he came in and asked if his wife was at homeâ€”I said yesâ€”he asked if he could go to his roomâ€”I said yes, provided there were no words or quarrellingâ€”he was very drunkâ€”he had no sooner got into the room than there was quarrelling, high words; I was downstairsâ€”I heard the breaking of crockery and the window was brokenâ€”I went up to the room, they would not open the doorâ€”I forced it open with my knee, and saw the prisoner sitting on a chair in the room, and the woman was lying on the ground in her dressing-gown, all in strips, and she was bleeding from the back part of her 'headâ€”she put her hand to her head and said, "You see what he has done for meâ€”I told him he ought to do better than to ill-treat the woman, and I would fetch a policeman and give him in chargeâ€”not finding a policeman, I came back again and went on the stairs and spoke to Mrs. Wynne, persuading her to put on her things and have some adviceâ€”she did put on her things and came on to the stairsâ€”she was bleeding from the nose and the back part of her head, very muchâ€”she had got her dressing-gown partly on; it was torn right from the waist, one half on and one half off; the body of it was on her backâ€”I think she had had a little drink in the morning, but was not much the worse for itâ€”about this time Mrs. Prosser came down; she lodged at the top of the house, and she and Mrs. Wynne went upstairs togetherâ€”I had to go into my shop to a customer; they came down stairs to my parlour door and went up again, and that was the last time I saw Mrs. Wynne aliveâ€”after I had been in my shop about a quarter of an hour I heard a heavy fall, or a heavy sound, as if some one had been pushed down, or off the bedâ€”that was about two o'clockâ€”I heard no quarrelling at that time, nothing beyond the sound of a fall; I think all remained quiet till about a quarter to five that afternoon; then I heard some one walking backwards and forwards about the roomâ€”I went out awhile and stood on the pavement, and the prisoner came out and left; he turned his back to me, but he saw me, and walked quickly over the bridge; I went back and remained in the house till about nine o'clock, and then I went with Mrs. Prosser to the room; I knocked at the door, I thought I heard some one say, "Come in"â€”I opened the door and my two cats came out of the roomâ€”when I got in I saw the room was in great confusion, crockery broken, a large brown jug and the window broken, and I found the body of the woman lying on the floor, and the dressing-gown put under her head or tucked under both sides of her head, her face upwardsâ€”she was dead, her eyes and mouth were partly openâ€”I at once communicated with the police and sent for a doctor.

Cross-examined. From the time they came to lodge until the 7th, to the best of my belief, they were on good termsâ€”he used to go out in the morning, but as a rule they went out together; sometimes she would come home about a quarter of an hour before himâ€”I did not know that they had agreed together to give up drinkâ€”I did not see a memorandum hanging up in their room to that effectâ€”I don't know what time the prisoner came home on the Friday night; I did not see him; his usual time was about half-past eight or a quarter to nineâ€”she came home between twelve and one a little the worse for drinkâ€”he came home afterwards without his hatâ€”I heard him say she was a drunken beastâ€”that was the first quarrel I heardâ€”on the day of her death he was very drunk indeed, but he knew what he was doing; he looked as if he had

been drinking for daysâ€”a cup had been thrown from the windowâ€”he asked me if my husband was at home, I told him that was my business, not his; I called him a bad man, and asked him why he had been ill-treating his wifeâ€”I threatened to give him into custody for breaking my chinaâ€”he did not answer meâ€”I heard no dispute or quarrelling after two o'clockâ€”when I went up I did not hear her say that he was asleep.
Re-examined. He told me that he was at work at Now Cross up to the Saturday night,

CATHERINE PROSSER . I occupied the top room front at 42, Goulbourn Road from the 7th to the 11th Augustâ€”the prisoner and his wife lived under meâ€”on Tuesday, 11th August, I came out of my room about twelve or half-past in the dayâ€”I saw the prisoner come up to his roomâ€”he knocked very loud and called, "Clara, open the door," three times, and he used most abusive language because she did not open the doorâ€”as soon as she opened it he caught her by the throat and threw her back into the room; and when he went inside the screams of the poor woman I shall never forget to my dying dayâ€”I did not see what the effect of that violence was upon herâ€”he went in and shut the door, and there they remained for a little timeâ€”about half an hour or three-quarters of an hour after I heard the breaking of crockeryâ€”I went down to the flats and saw a teacup coming through the glass of the prisoner's back window into the back yard, and it broke in pieces down thereâ€”after that Mrs. Wynne came downstairs and sat in the w.c.â€”I spoke to her; there was some talk between us, and she went up to her room doorâ€”I waited on the stairsâ€”she went and looked in at the door and said, "He is asleep on the bed"â€”she came away from the door and we went downstairsâ€”we returned a second time and I stood on my stepsâ€”she went in again and said, "He is still asleep"â€”she went into the room and I went upstairsâ€”I heard nothing more till between half-past four and five, when my attention was attracted by someone falling down the stairs leading to the shopâ€”I went to the window and saw the prisoner leave the houseâ€”he walked out sideways, turning his back to Mrs. Mayhead.

Cross-examined. Friday night was the first night I heard any disturb
anceâ€”on the Tuesday, when I saw the prisoner knock at the door, I was coming out of my roomâ€”I was on the landingâ€”from there I could see the prisoner catch hold of his wifeâ€”I stated so at the inquest, and one of the jury, who lived in the house, said it was utterly impossibleâ€”I did not notice how far I could see into the room; I never tried thatâ€”when she went back the prisoner did not object to her coming into the room; there was something heavy up against the doorâ€”she did eventually go into the room; I don't know whether she locked the door, she shut itâ€”my door was open the whole afternoonâ€”I heard no quarrelling or noise during that time.

JOHN COOMBES (Inspector). On 11th August, about a quarter to eleven, I went to 42, Goulbourn Road, and in a back room on the first floor found the dead body of the deceasedâ€”I noticed a wound at the back of her headâ€”a number of things in the room were stained with blood, among them a sheet under the woman's head, a rug hanging on a dress behind the door, a blood stain on one of the bolsters and a jacket bodyâ€”there was a quantity of blood on the hearth-rug, which had soaked through the carpet on to the floorâ€”the room was in great disorder, a

pane of glass was broken in the right-hand corner of the bottom sash, and the remains of a teacup was found in the area below; a broken earthenware jug was also found in the room, some blood was found on the blade bone and about the face of the deceasedâ€”I found no instrument with which the blow had been inflicted.

GEORGE ROBERTSON , M.D., of 150, Kilburn Park Road. I am a divisional surgeon of policeâ€”on 11th August I was called to 42, Goulbourn Road about a quarter to elevenâ€”I went into the back room first floor, it was in great confusionâ€”I saw the body of a woman lying between the bed and the fender, not against itâ€”she had been dead for five or six hours at the least, it might have been moreâ€”there was froth coming from the mouth; she had a black eye, a wound on the top of the back of the head, an abrasion under the jaw, and marks of an old abrasion on the spineâ€”the black eye was evidently of old dateâ€”there were no injuries that I could see of very recent dateâ€”on the back of the head was a small cut, half an inch in length, barely penetrating the skin, from which blood had flowed freely, and that was such a wound as might have been inflicted by a teacup thrown at the headâ€”I saw a number of articles stained with blood; one was a sheet under the back of the head, under which was a small pool of bloodâ€”I made a post-mortem on the 13thâ€”I found effusion of blood under the small cut, and a little blood about the nostrils, but I saw no other external marksâ€”there was no indication of a sufficient loss of blood to cause death; in fact, on opening the body I found the internal organs gorged with bloodâ€”the brain and membranes were congested in patchesâ€”it is very difficult to say with certainty how the congestion was brought aboutâ€”I don't think it was the cause of the injury to the back of the headâ€”it might be due to chloroform or chloral hydrateâ€”there were indications consistent with excitementâ€”it is very difficult to say if the excitement was occasioned by offered violence.

Cross-examined. I made a very careful examination of the body; the only sign of recent violence was the small wound, it barely penetrated the skinâ€”there are no large arteries thereâ€”the effect of alcohol is to send the blood to the head.

GUILTY
of Unlawfully Wounding. â€”
Six Months' Hard Labour, including ten weeks during which he had been in custody.

824.
ANNIE MAHAGAN' (32)
, for the manslaughter of
Annie Mahagan the younger .
MR. HUTTON, for the Prosecution, offered no evidence upon this indictment.
NOT GUILTY .

rs.hi: There was another charge against the prisoner, for unlawfully neglecting and ill-treating her child, under sixteen years of age,

div1.p:
825.
JOHN HOLLAND (42)
, manslaughter of
Olaf Jensen on the high seas.
MR. CHARLES MATHEWS , for the Prosecution, offered no evidence.
NOT GUILTY .

826. The said
JOHN HOLLAND
was further indicted for unlawfully assaulting Olaf Jensen, and occasioning him actual bodily harm.
MESSRS. C. MATHEWS and C. F. GILL Prosecuted, and MR. BIRON Defended at the request of the COURT. The learned counsel on the prisoner's

rs.hi: To enter into his own recognisances of Â£5 to come up for Judgment when called upon.

div1.p:
827.
ALFRED MARTIN (21) and
ALFRED SMITH (22)
, Rob
bery with violence on
Annie Foxall, and stealing a purse and two shillings, her property.

ANNIE FOXALL . I am the wife of George Foxall, a timber merchant, of 28, Knutsford Place, Maryleboneâ€”on Sunday night, August 3rd, between 11.30 and 11.45 I was in Edgware Road with Mrs. Taylorâ€”I had a purse and a letterâ€”four men came up to us, pushed against us, and one of them said to me, "Will you have a cup of coffee?"â€”we were near a coffee stallâ€”I took no notice and went onâ€”they asked me the question again; I said, "No thank you, I don't care for coffee"â€”they made my parcel fall, and two of them took hold of me and nearly pulled off my capeâ€”they pushed me against the shutter of a shop and wrenched the purse and letter from me, and struck or kicked me twice on my legâ€”I was so frightened I could not call out, and they ran awayâ€”I called a policeman, and on the following Tuesday I pointed Martin out at the stationâ€”I had two shillings and a key, in my purse.
Cross-examined by Martin. You are not the one who kicked me; I charged you with stealing my purse.

ERNEST MORLEY . I am a cabman, of 28, Newcombe Street, Notting Hill Gateâ€”on Sunday night, October 3rd, about 11.45, I was having some coffee at a stall in Edgware Road, and the prosecutrix cried out, "This man has stolen my purse"â€”I saw her struggling with Martinâ€”four other men were there, but I cannot identify them.
Cross-examined by MR. HUTTON. I was four or five yards from them, but the other men were in shadow.

FREDERICK JAMES KIEHL . I am a coffee-house keeper, of 26, Circus Street, Maryleboneâ€”on Sunday night, October 3rd, I saw Martin and some others struggling with a woman at a turning before you get to my stallâ€”they asked her if she would have a cup of coffee, and directly she got past the stall they pushed her against a shutter and stole her purseâ€”I saw them make a rush at her.
Cross-examined by Martin. I saw you rush at her.
Cross-examined by MR. HUTTON. I was not more than four yards away.

MARGARET TAYLOR . I am the wife of George Taylor, of 2, Croydon Street, Maryleboneâ€”I was with Mrs. Foxallâ€”I have heard her evidence; it is correctâ€”two of the men took me by my neck and pulled me into the middle of the roadâ€”Smith is one of them; I am quite sureâ€”I was about a yard from Mrs. Foxall.
Cross-examined by Martin. I saw you there with two other menâ€”I could not identify you at the station, because I could not see your face.

Cross-examined by MR. HUTTON. Smith was placed with othersâ€”I gave a description of him to the policeâ€”I did not say he was dressed in grey clothesâ€”I said he was dressed similar to what he is now, in a brown

check suit and an overcoatâ€”he had an overcoat on when ho was placed with othersâ€”I did not tell the police he had an overcoat on; I was not sureâ€”he had a round hat when he was with the othersâ€”the struggle was momentary; two made off, and the other two overtook us again five or six yards off, and Smith took Mrs. Foxall by her arm and held herâ€”the cab
man and coffee-stall-keeper did not come up; they had not timeâ€”Smith struck Mrs. Foxall on her back, and took her by her shoulders, and held her as she was crying for the police, and then he struck herâ€”I was taken to the station to identify the man who kicked her, and I identified him; and ho is the man who had hold of meâ€”I was indignant, but did not call out because there was no time.
Re-examined. These men were coming one way and we the otherâ€”I struggled with Smith, and am positively sure he is the man.
WILLIAM F. MORGAN . I am a surgeonâ€”I examined Mrs. Foxall, and found a very severe contusion on her right thigh, which, I think, was caused by two kicks.

THOMAS THOMPSON (Police Sergeant). On 9th October I found Martin detained at Paddington Stationâ€”he was placed with others, and immedi
ately picked out as the man who stole the purse; he was then charged, and made no answer.

JAMES JELLER (S 181). I took Smith in High Street, Notting Hill, on Saturday at 8.30; I was in plain clothesâ€”I said I was a police officer, and should take him to the station on suspicion of being concerned with another in a highway robbery in Edgware Road on Sunday eveningâ€”he said, "Very well, then, I must go with you"â€”he was placed with a number of men at the station, and identified by Mrs. Taylor; he was charged and made no reply.

Martin's Defence: I am innocent of the charge. I have not been in Edgware Road for the last ten months, and Smith was never in my com
pany, but I know him by sight.

MARTIN
GUILTY . SMITH received a good characterâ€”
NOT GUILTY .MARTIN then
PLEADED GUILTY
to a conviction at West London Police-court of larceny from the person, in the name of
Herbert Martinâ€”
Six Months' Hard Labour.

828.
HENRY BAZLEY (29)
, Unlawfully taking
Elizabeth Morey, a girl under eighteen years of age, out of the possession of her parents, with intent, etc.
Upon the opening speech by MR. ELDRIDGE, the COURT considered that there was no evidence.
NOT GUILTY .

829.
GEORGE BRYCE GIRVAN FINLAY (37)
, Unlawfully obtaining a cheque for Â£25 from
Walter Bates by false pretences.
The JURY being unable to agree were discharged without giving any verdict. (See New Court, Wednesday, October 28th.)

830.
CATHERINE MITCHELL (38) and
WILLIAM CHARLES MITCHELL (38),
Stealing a ring, the property of
Harry Joel, the master of Catherine Mitchell.

MARIA JOEL . I live at 21, Middlesex Street, Aldgate, and am the wife of Harry Joelâ€”on Saturday, 12th September, when I was going to bed, I missed this diamond ring, worth Â£7, which I had last seen on the previous Tuesday in the dressing-table drawerâ€”on the following Tuesday I spoke to the female prisoner about it, after I had found out her addressâ€”she said she knew nothing about the ringâ€”she ought not to have gone to the room from which the ring was taken; she was a charwoman, and had to clean the scullery and stairs; she was not per
manently employed on the premisesâ€”it is not my own house; I was staying with my mother and father thereâ€”the room was open, not lockedâ€”the ring was loose in the drawerâ€”I employed the female prisonerâ€”I am not certain of the day, I cannot say whether it was the 11th or 12thâ€”on Friday, 11th, I employed her; she came in about three o'clock, and remained about an hour cleaning the scullery and stairs; she had nothing else to doâ€”I knew nothing of the male prisoner.

JOSEPH GEORGE BUSBY . I am a licensed victualler, and keep the Swan, in Mansel Street, Aldgateâ€”on Sunday, 13th September, the male prisoner came inâ€”he told me he had found a ring two or three weeks ago on the wool warehouse floor where he was workingâ€”he asked if I would see whether it was gold for him, and I tried it with the stuff I try silver withâ€”it was very black and dirty; I found it was goldâ€”I had known him as a customer for some timeâ€”he said, "I am distressed for a little rent, would you give me 15s. for it?"â€”I gave him 15s. for it, out of charity; I did not know it was a diamond ring, the stone was so black and dirtyâ€”I never did such a thing beforeâ€”on the following Sunday, 20th, I saw Sergeant Abbott, and gave him the ring, and made a statement to himâ€”I know the female prisoner as an occasional customerâ€”she was not with her husband on this occasion.
Cross-examined by Charles Mitchell. I did not offer you 15s. for the ring; you asked me what the value was.

THOMAS ABBOTT (City Detective Sergeant). On 20th September I went to 84, Mansel Street, and saw the two prisoners in a room on the top floor, where they lodgeâ€”I said, "I am a police-officer"â€”addressing the male prisoner I said, "I want to ask you a few questions about a gold ring that you alleged you found, and that ring you have sold"â€”he said, "I know nothing about a ring"â€”I then produced this ring and said, "This is the ring you sold to Mr. Busby, a publican, for 15s."â€”he said, "Yes, it is quite right; it is no good denying it"â€”the female prisoner said, "I picked up the ring; it was wrapped in a piece of paper outside 21, Middlesex Street," that is Joel'sâ€”I told them both they would be charged with being concerned together in stealing and receiving this ring, well knowing it to have been stolenâ€”I conveyed them to the stationâ€”they made no answer to the charge.

p.hi: William Charles Mitchell, in his statement before the Magistrate and in his defence, said that his wife gave him the ring when he came home from work, saying, "I have picked up this ring;" that on Sunday he took it to Mr. Busby, and told him he had picked it up.
Catherine Mitchell, in her defence, denied that she had stolen the ring.

div1.p: THOMAS ABBOTT (Re-examined.) I believe the prosecutrix took a
constable to the place and wanted to give the female prisoner into custodyâ€”on the following Sunday I went to Busbyâ€”the ring was not discovered till Sunday, 20th.

CATHERINE MITCHELL,
GUILTY .
Six Months' Imprisonment
WILLIAM CHARLES MITCHELL,
GUILTY of receiving . Recommended to mercy by the JURY on account of his previous good characterâ€”
Judgment respited.

831.
RICHARD WHITE, Robbery
with violence on
Alice Richardson, and stealing 5d. from her.

ALICE RICHARDSON . I live at 111, Kingsland Roadâ€”at a quarter to twelve on Saturday night, 17th September, I was standing outside the Potato Can public-house, opposite to where I liveâ€”the prisoner was by my side, and I turned and saw his hand in my left pocketâ€”I asked him to give me what he had taken outâ€”I had no sooner said it than he hit me with his fist in the face, which was swollen and bleeding when I got to the station afterwardsâ€”I had had 5 1/2 d. and two buttons in my pocket when I came out of my house, just before this occurrenceâ€”the blow did not knock me downâ€”I held him till a constable came, and then I gave him in charge; I never let go of him.

HENRY GILLINGHAM . I live at 61, Green Street, and am a coat makerâ€”on Saturday night, 17th. September, I was outside the Potato Can at a few minutes to twelve, and I saw Alice Richardson holding the prisoner, and accusing him of taking the money from her, and he said he had not taken any money from herâ€”he wrestled himself away, and struck at her, and hit her on the side of her jawâ€”a constable came up, and she gave him in charge.

ALBERT ANDERSON (G 157.) On the night of 17th September I went up to the Potato Can, where the prosecutrix had hold of the prisonerâ€”she gave him in charge for stealing 5d. from her jacket pocket, and also striking her in the face, which was swollen and bleedingâ€”I took him to the stationâ€”only a pawn-ticket was found on himâ€”five or six persons, I should say, were round there when I came upâ€”they were helping him; when I took hold of the prisoner they got round me.

p.hi: The Prisoner, in his defence, said he was standing there with twelve others, when the prosecutrix accused him of taking her money, and caught hold of his arm, and that he pulled his arm away, and she said he had hit her.

div1.p:
GUILTY . He then
PLEADED GUILTY* to a conviction of felony in November, 1890.â€”
Twelve Months' Hard Labour.

832.
FRANK ARTHUR PAGE (44)
, Feloniously marrying
Florence Minter during the lifetime of his wife.

JOHN COOKE . I live at 35, Havanna Street, Millwall, and am verger at the Millwall Churchâ€”in 1879 I was verger of St. Peter's, Regent Squareâ€”I produce a Certificate, which is a true copy from the original register there. (This was a certificate of the marriage of Frank Arthur Page to Annie Gillett, on 11 th March, 1878.) I signed the registers as a witness, but I cannot identify the prisoner.

GEORGE CRACKNELL (Detective T). On 2nd October I went to 20, Gil
lingham Street, Pimlico, in company with Mr. Jenksâ€”I saw the prisoner

there, and I said to him, "I have received information, through Mr. Jenks, that your wife Florrie, whom you married about a month since at Fulham, has been to 32, Great St. Andrew Street, and has there seen a photo, which she recognises as you; she also saw a Mrs. Page, who stated that it was her husband"â€”he said, "That is false"â€”I conveyed him to South Fulham Police-station, where I showed him a copy of the certificate of 11th March, 1878â€”he said, "I am not the man"â€”I went to 32, Great St. Andrew Street, where I saw Mrs. Page, who accompanied me to the Police-station, and said, in the prisoner's presence, "That is my husband," and produced the certificate; the prisoner said to me, "Yes, it is true; I am sorry I gave you so much trouble"â€”he was looking at this certificate when he said itâ€”he was subsequently charged before the Magistrate.

Cross-examined. One of these copies of the certificate was handed in at the Police-station by the first wife, and the other I got from Somerset Houseâ€”the inspector was present when the prisoner made the statement.

FLORENCE MINTON . I am living at 11, Grimston Road, Fulhamâ€”on 1st September, 1891, I was married at All Saints' Church, Fulham, to Frank Arthur Pageâ€”this is the certificateâ€”I had known him thirteen months; I believed he was single; he had always represented himself to be soâ€”I subsequently lived with him as his wife at 44, De Noyser Street, Fulhamâ€”I then went to Great St. Andrew Street, and saw a photo there of Mr. Frank Page.

Cross-examined. I am prosecuting, and I have instituted these pro
ceedings against him because I consider I have been deliberately deceived by himâ€”I have not been married beforeâ€”I had a child before this by Ernest Jamesâ€”I was called in the certificate of birth Florence Minton, formerly Scott; my maiden name was Minton; my mother's name was Scottâ€”my name is Scott-Mintonâ€”I have not changed my name; it has always been Mintonâ€”I did not put Scott on the certificate; I don't know who did, and I don't know why it was doneâ€”I was never marriedâ€”I never lived in the name of Scottâ€”before I married the prisoner in Sep
tember this year I was staying at my sister's, 11, Grimston Roadâ€”I was in business before thatâ€”I have known the prisoner four or five years; I lost sight of him for a few months, but, with the exception of that, I have seen him constantly for four or five yearsâ€”I was seriously ill this time last yearâ€”I did not write to the prisoner and ask him to look after the child after my deathâ€”I did not writeâ€”he did not come and see meâ€”I have no child by himâ€”I saw him nine or ten months before the birth of the childâ€”I think the child was eight or nine months old before I saw him again, I met him by accident last Februaryâ€”I did not ask him to look after the child; he did not suggest marrying me and adopting the child, and going to a colony; he asked me to marry him the second time, and I told him all the circumstances of the caseâ€”he never supported the childâ€”it was not living with us when we lived togetherâ€”we were only together three weeks.

Re-examined. He is a theatrical manager; I and my sister met him in February last, and he renewed his attentions to me, and I told him all about the child, and he said it would make no difference, and that he thought all the more of me for having had a child and still living a straight lifeâ€”he then renewed his offer of marriage a second timeâ€”he wished the child to take his name, but I would not allow thatâ€”I had
other offers besides hisâ€”I decided to marry himâ€”he was not deceived in marrying meâ€”he knew everything.

MARY ANN CALLAGHAN . I am a widow, of 32, Great Saint Andrew Street, Bloomsburyâ€”the prisoner, in last May, came with his wife and little girl and lodged with meâ€”the wife is still lodging thereâ€”I saw the prisoner there in September, and believe he and his wife lived as man and wife there.
Cross-examined. He engaged the rooms with Mrs. Pageâ€”I have seen him there.

p.rs: GUILTY.â€” The prisoner's wife desired to recommend him to mercy.

div1.p:
833.
NAOMI SOPHIA WESTWATER (21)
, Unlawfully obtaining, by false pretences, from
Alice and
Thomas May, certain food, liquors, and 18s., with intent to defraud; Second Count, For unlawfully incurring a debt and liability to the same persons; Third Count, Obtaining, by false pretences, from
Marian and
William Powell, certain food, liquor, and money, with a like intent.

ALICE MAY . I am the wife of Thomas May, of 9, Westferry Road, Millwallâ€”on 27th July the prisoner came and asked if I would take her in as a lodgerâ€”she said her father had died and left her several thousand pounds, and after everything was over she would compensate me for her board and lodging; she also said that her mother was killed on the rail
way at Tunbridge Wells; she was left houses and property, and she would compensate me after the funeral was overâ€”she made the representation about her father first, on the 27th July; and the other representation about her mother on 2nd Septemberâ€”I did not think on the 27th July that her statement was true; nor did I on the 2nd September believe that that one was trueâ€”I lent her eighteen shillings in July and September, two shillings at one time, and half-crown at another, because she told me that after everything was settled and signed she would compensate me for what I had doneâ€”she was in my house five weeksâ€”I put down the value of the board and lodging she had at ten shillings a week.
Cross-examined. I expected a little increase in the future on the money I lent her as compensation.

Re-examined. The only compensation I expected was the value of her board and lodgingâ€”she was having eight shillings a week from her husbandâ€”I never received a farthing of thatâ€”I know she is married; she came to me with a deplorable story, and said she was starving, which was not true.

MARIAN POWELL . I live at 132, Bow Road, and am the wife of William Powellâ€”at the end of May the prisoner came to meâ€”I had seen her twice previouslyâ€”she said she was very faint and tired; she had been to St. Paul's Churchâ€”I was going to have tea, and I asked her to have a cup, and I boarded her for a fortnight after thatâ€”she did not lodge with meâ€”on the first evening she came I lent her three shillings; she said she wanted to pay a bill for food; would I lend her three shillings as she had a mantle to make, and she would pay me backâ€”on the following Friday week she said she had Â£905 coming to her, and would I lend her five shillings for the probate stamp; she wanted ten

shillings for two stamps, but she thought she could get one for five shillings, and on the Saturday she came again, saying they would not allow one stamp without the other, and I lent her the other five shillings, so that she had ten shillings for the two stamps; she said her father had left her this moneyâ€”she left my house just a fortnight after she cameâ€”I parted with my money because she was with me for a fortnight every day, and I believed what she said.

Cross-examined. She told me about the Â£905 after she had been with me a week, on the Wednesdayâ€”she said nothing about the Â£905 until about the Thursday, when she said, "I have got my money"â€”on the first day she had a cup of tea and some bread and butter and went homeâ€”next morning she came and stayed all dayâ€”she told my friends she had money previouslyâ€”I believed all she said, and it was believing that that I lent her the ten shillings, believing that she was coming into Â£900, solely thatâ€”she had no luggage or anything when she came to meâ€”she asked me to mind a few pictures and a parcel when they were moving, and she left me the duplicate of what she said was a diamond ring to sellâ€”my husband gave it back to herâ€”she owed me thirteen shillings when she left, and about ten shillings for food; twenty-five shillings would cover it allâ€”the ring was pledged for fifteen shillingsâ€”I should not like to give more than sixpence or eight pence for all the picturesâ€”I suppose no one would give more than three shillings for the pictures, photos, fans, and everythingâ€”I did not know I could keep those as security; she asked me to mind them, as they were movingâ€”I did not ask her to leave them.
Re-examined. I did not want the thingsâ€”she told me her father had left these things.

NAOMI DAVIS . I live at 134, Clarendon Street, Harrow Road, and am a widowâ€”the prisoner is my daughterâ€”my husband died in Paddington Workhouse Infirmaryâ€”he did not leave my daughter Â£900â€”it is not true that I was killed in a railway accident.
Cross-examined. The prisoner is twenty-threeâ€”she was in service, and was seduced and had a child, and then married another man some time after.

WILLIAM DOE (K R 30). On 18th September I arrested the prisoner at the instance of Mrs. Mayâ€”I read the warrant and cautioned herâ€”she said, "I am innocent; you can take me anywhere you like as long as you don't take me to my husband"â€”I arrested her in the workhouse, where she was an inmate.

MR. HUTTON submitted that there was no case to go to the JURY; as to the first and second Counts, if any false representations were made, they did not operate upon the mind of Mrs. May; and as to the last Count, no existing false pretences had been made, but only future promises. After hearing MR. ELDRIDGE, the COMMON SERJEANT considered that under the circumstances the safer course would be to direct an acquittal.
NOT GUILTY .

834.
JOHN BALFOUR HUTCHINSON (23) and
ALEXANDROS JEANUI (29)
, Feloniously having in their custody and possession, without lawful authority, certain plates upon which were engraven undertaking for the payment of money of the
Empire of Russia.
MESSRS. CHARLES MATHEWS and HORACE AVORY Prosecuted; MESSRS. C. F. GILL and A. GILL defended Hutchinson; MR. HUTTON defended Jeanui.

ALFRED SAMUEL BACON . I am an engraver, at 5, Gough Square, Fleet Streetâ€”in May last Hutchinson came to me and said that he had succeeded to the business of Mr. Sison, an ornamental engraver at Birm
ingham, and he brought me a rough drawing in pencil of a piece of work which I executed; this (produced) is the plate, numbered 2â€”he said it was not satisfactory, not the pattern he requiredâ€”on June 3rd he called again, and by his instructions I made, this plate, No. 13; it is an ordinary everyday pattern, of which we keep a large quantity in stock, it is a diagonal line plate, used for tints and backgroundsâ€”the next order he gave me was some time in June, this is the plate, No. 10; I executed that from a drawing he brought me; it is a border with a black centre; he came and fetched the plate after I had worked it outâ€”I said to him, "This looks to me like a coupon, do you know for whom you are doing it?"â€”he said, "A stranger called on me and asked if I could draw," he replied, "Yes, I can draw anything"; that he gave him a little square and said, "Will you make a drawing from that and engrave it?" and he said, "Yes. "Subsequently to that I did another plate, No. 3; I did that from a drawing which he brought; that was to go inside No. 10â€”I afterwards executed plate No. 12, that was in July; that was done from a pattern, the same as the outside of No. 10, but worked in a different direction, longitudinallyâ€”I did No. 12 from verbal instructions by Hutchinsonâ€”f also did this plate, No. 11, in August, I don't know the exact date; I did it from a drawing supplied by Hutchinson, because plate No. 3 carried too much colour for his customer; he wanted it more open, to print lighter; these papers marked "G" and "J" have been printed from these plates.

Cross-examined by MR. GILL. Hutchinson told me that he had been at Waterlow's and at Taylor and Co.'s; those are two of the best known firmsâ€”he did not say how long he had been at Sison'sâ€”since he has been in business for himself I have been to his place on different occasions after I had this order from himâ€”I had no reason to suspect that this was not an ordinary transactionâ€”it might have been a label, or a season ticket; these things are used for those purposes, and for companies, and some for ink labels; there is nothing remarkable about itâ€”Hutchinson told me he had this order from a stranger; his work is that of a picture engraver, he would not do this kind himself; the principal part of our business is trade workâ€”persons who get orders come to us to do the work; there are not many persons who do it; it is done by machineryâ€”I have been in business forty-seven yearsâ€”I did not consider that there was anything improper in what I was doing; I only had drawings to work fromâ€”it was only when I was working it out I thought it might be a coupon, and I said to him, "Do you know what you are doing it for?"â€”there was nothing peculiar about the work he asked me to doâ€”he made no secret about itâ€”he told me the man had gone to Bristol and he could get no reply from himâ€”I regarded it throughout as a bond fide transaction.
Re-examined. I have not had such work before, knowing it to be for coupons, but we do all sorts of patternsâ€”I have repeatedly done such
workâ€”it was when I finished No. 10 that I said, "This looks like a coupon; look after your money "â€”this was in June.

JAMES HART TAYLOR . I am an engraver, and live at St. Augustine's Roadâ€”I am employed at Messrs.
