Waterlow'sâ€”I knew Hutchinson when he was employed thereâ€”since November last we have lived togetherâ€”some time in July last he asked me to do some work for him; it was plate No. 7 (a seal), the lettering round the ring at the back; he brought me this (marked L) to copy fromâ€”I then executed this plateâ€”at the end of July he brought me this paper (A), from which I made this plate, No. 14; he simply asked me to do it as an ordinary job; I could not say what he said exactlyâ€”I understood it was for Jeanui, but his name was Collier at that timeâ€”he did not tell me that the first timeâ€”he did not know any name at first; the only name he knew him by at that time was "The Frenchman"â€”I saw the man at Hutchinson's office during the time the work was in progress, three times, I thinkâ€”it was after I had done the plate that I knew his nameâ€”I was asked to make an alteration in the date from 1891 to 1892, I think, by Jeanui, at Hutchinson's office; Hutchinson gave me the order, but Jeanui was thereâ€”this was quite at the end of Julyâ€”I can't say exactly how long it took me to do the plate; I did not do it at one sitting, it was done about three weeks or a month after the order was given.

Cross-examined by MR. GILL. I am a Scotchman; most of my fellow-work
men are Scotchmenâ€”I have been an engraver about twelve yearsâ€”I have been about eighteen months in Messrs. Waterlow's employ, before that I was employed at Glasgowâ€”I work out of hours for Hutchinsonâ€”he is about 23 years of ageâ€”he has been a few months in business for himself, he is a Scotchmanâ€”I did not think that there was anything wrong in this, I could not tell; I had no suspicion about Jeanui, he appeared to be a respectable manâ€”I did not know what the wording on this thing wasâ€”we talked about it, and could not tell; we did not know what language it was in, whether it was Hebrew, Greek, or what.

Cross-examined by MR. HUTTON. I saw Jeanui there on two or three occasionsâ€”I only had conversation with him onceâ€”I understood most of what he said; I understood the sense; he spoke very broken English; I cannot speak French.
Re-examined I first knew Hutchinson about eighteen months ago; he was then in Waterlow's service; he came a short time after me.
By the COURT. I cannot read Frenchâ€”Hutchinson does not understand French that I know ofâ€”I did plate 14â€”I see the word "coupon" there; I did not notice it when I was making the plate.

GEORGE GORDON . I am an engraver, and am employed at Messrs. Waterlow'sâ€”I have been living in the same house with Hutchinson for the last two yearsâ€”I did some work for him this year; I believe the first was some time in May or June, and until his arrest I was doing work for him nearly every weekâ€”I did this plate, No. 6, at his instructionsâ€”he gave me a small label like this to copy from; I returned it to himâ€”he said nothing particular about it; he asked me to do it, the same as I have done for other personsâ€”he said it was for some gentleman, he did not know his name at that timeâ€”I also did this plate, No. 5, partly, the alterations; he gave me for that a similar copy to the other oneâ€”I also did plate No. 4, for which he gave me a copy like this (marked K)â€”I could not say whether this was the oneâ€”I had not finished that at the

time of his arrest; I was still at work on itâ€”I once saw Jeanui in Hutchinson's office when I was working there; he was merely standing there, looking on and talking to Hutchinson, and he looked on me while I was doing this workâ€”nothing was said about his name thenâ€”later on Hutchinson said he had received a letter from him, inquiring about some workâ€”he showed me the letter; it was signed "Collier," and after that I understood his name to be Collierâ€”I believe I saw him there three times on occasions when I called on Hutchinson, as I very often did after business.

Cross-examined by MR. GILL. I am a Scotchmanâ€”I have been an engraver about twelve years, continuing my. apprenticeshipâ€”I have been at Waterlow's about five yearsâ€”I have seen an enormous amount of work done thereâ€”they do a large amount of company work, and a great deal of ornamental work, and all sorts of engravingâ€”I knew Hutchinson when he was there as an ornamental engraver; I knew of his starting for himself a few months agoâ€”there was not the slightest concealment between us with regard to the work that was being doneâ€”I did not know what the thing was that was given me to copyâ€”I am twenty-seven years of ageâ€”I thought the language was Hebrew, because I saw a Hebrew copy one day, and I thought the letters were something likeâ€”I do not understand much about this coupon work, except copying the letters, and so on; doing it mechanicallyâ€”I don't understand what it meansâ€”when I saw Jeanui at the office I spoke to him; I do not understand French, nor does Hutchinson, as far as I knowâ€”I thought Jeanui was a Frenchman; we always spoke of him as such, till Hutchinson received the letter signed Collierâ€”I told Jeanui that I could not copy this exactly, and he said it did not matter, and he gave certain instructions to alter themâ€”I have never had an imputation on my characterâ€”I did not know what this coupon was.

Re-examined. As to this coupon, I could see that one side of it was not in the same language as the front; but I have no knowledge either of French or Russianâ€”I did not take that to be in Hebrewâ€”I do not observe the word "coupon" thereâ€”I do the work mechanically, and perhaps after I have done the job I could not tell what the writing was; it did not strike me that it was in the nature of bank notes, or securities of any kind, or I should not have done itâ€”the things done for the Government are not the same kindâ€”the paper shown me to copy from I call very common work; I could not say what they would be used for; they may be used for labels, admission tickets, or anything like that.

WALTER CHARLES HOLDER . I am an engraverâ€”I formerly carried on business at 4, Newgate Streetâ€”Hutchinson came there about the beginning of June last, and asked me to do some work for himâ€”I did part of the plate No. 8, the border, by Hutchinson's instructions; he gave me a drawing to work from; he said it was for a customer in the countryâ€”he subsequently brought me a tracing of a background on gelatine, and by his instructions I made a copy of it on a plate, and he took it awayâ€”he afterwards came and gave me instructions to engrave another plate (No. 1), I did this from this coupon (marked B)â€”I gave him the plate on a Saturday just before his arrest, about 5th Septemberâ€”I mentioned the matter to my father, and he communicated with the policeâ€”I put the coupon with the plateâ€”I know Jeanuiâ€”I have seen him twice at 4a, St. Paul's Churchyard, Hutchinson's officeâ€”the first time he was sitting

there in the easy-chair, and on the second occasion he was in an office leading from thatâ€”there was no discussion in his presence about the work I was doing, I had no conversation with himâ€”Hutchinson told me he was one of his customers from the countryâ€”he never told me whether he had anything to do with this business.

Cross-examined by MR. GILL. I have been four years in business; before that I was an apprenticeâ€”I have seen a great deal of all class of. workâ€”when I first saw this coupon I did not know what it wasâ€”I did part of this plate, and my father did the rest by machinery, he is a man of great experience, he has had some experience in bank forgeriesâ€”the price at which I did the work was the ordinary priceâ€”I saw Jeanui twice, once when Hutchinson was there and once when he was not.

p.hi: David Taylor was called on his recognisance and did not answer.

div1.p: JAMES LYALL . I am an engraver, at 7, Nicholas Street, Bristolâ€”in the spring or summer of this year I became acquainted with Jeanui, I think it was about June Mr. Spriggs, a printer, introduced him to me; they came to my place of business together; upon the instructions of one of them I engraved a portion of these two plates, Nos. 8 and 9â€”I did the lettering on No. 8, that had the date on it 1892; No. 9 was altered from 1891 to 1892, the plate was knocked up from the back, then levelled and then re-engraved; this was done under Mr. Spriggs' instructionsâ€”Jeanui was not present when the order was givenâ€”I received from Mr. Spriggs these three couponsâ€”when he and Jeanui came together Jeanui wanted to know what style of work I could doâ€”I showed him different sorts of work I had doneâ€”he was very well satisfied with it, and he wanted to employ me; he would not tell me for what; it was to do general engraving work for himâ€”nothing more was said on that occasion as to the character of the work to be doneâ€”after that Mr. Spriggs came with these little jobsâ€”he gave me the coupon and gave me instructions, and when it was done he called for itâ€”I gave him the plates and the couponâ€”I only saw Jeanui once.
Cross-examined by MR. GILL. I never saw Hutchinson till I came here.

FREDERICK JOHN SPRIGGS . I am a printer, at the City and County Chambers, Bristolâ€”I first made Jeanui's acquaintance in March, I believe at my officeâ€”he came there to look at an office in the same chambers, the key of which I hadâ€”he paid me several visitsâ€”on one occasion he said he thought he could give me some printing work to doâ€”then I lost sight of him for several weeks; then he visited me again, and brought some platesâ€”I don't know how many at firstâ€”these are the plates (Nos. 5, 6, 8, and 10)â€”these are the first four he broughtâ€”my instructions were to take impressions from them and place them together for him to see how they appearedâ€”I did so; he then brought me these four other plates, 7, 11, 12, and 14, and gave me the same instructions with regard to them, and I executed them in the same mannerâ€”he afterwards gave me an order to print 3,000 impressionsâ€”I did so, and he called for them and took them awayâ€”he afterwards told me that the first lot, dated 1891, was wrong, and I did him a second lot of 4,000, dated 1892â€”after I had finished the first lot he brought me these three coupons as patterns for the second impressionsâ€”it was in April, I think, that he first spoke to be about the printingâ€”I did not commence printing them till the latter part of Juneâ€”the last time I saw him in relation to this

transaction was on the Saturday previous to his arrest; he was in my office that dayâ€”he said he was going to London next Mondayâ€”there was left on my premises a number of these plates and a number of the printed impressions, as well as the three couponsâ€”I remember going to Mr. Lyall, and taking him instructions to engrave some platesâ€”Jeanui told me to do that; he told me to get them done for him, because they were to go in place of the others, dated 1891.

Cross-examined by MR. HUTTON. The whole of the conversation was I between Jeanui and myself, not with any of my assistantsâ€”I have been in business about six yearsâ€”he called the things labels for friends abroadâ€”I was satisfied with the information he gave me; he appeared to be a respectable manâ€”the coupons I printed I took to be some kind of drawings for lottery ticketsâ€”I did not believe them to be imitations of bonds; it is obvious to me that they are not imitations of real couponsâ€”the price I received for the work was a fair price.
Re-examined. I received the genuine coupons, and from them I was to do the work as nearly as I couldâ€”I do not snow French.

EMMA ALLEN . I am a clerk in the office of St. Bartholomew's Hotel, in College Green, Bristolâ€”Jeanui came to lodge there on 16th July last; he occupied room 45â€”he gave the name of Alexander Jeanuiâ€”he left on Monday, 7th Septemberâ€”he said he was going to London, and would return the same evening; he did not give up possession of his roomâ€”that was the room into which the police went when they came to Bristol to make a searchâ€”a telegram came for Jeanui on 4th September; I gave it to Mr. Collins.

WILLIAM WRIGHT (City Inspector). On 5th September, about noon, I was with Sergeant Lowâ€”I saw Hutchinson in Newgate Street; I stopped him, and said we were police officers, and asked what he had in his pocket; at the same time I took from it this packet, containing plate No. 1 and coupon Bâ€”I asked from whom he had received itâ€”he said from Holderâ€”I said we should charge him with the unlawful possession of that plate, and we conveyed him to the stationâ€”Holder was with him at the timeâ€”at the station Hutchinson asked if he could be allowed to go till Mondayâ€”I said, "As you have given no explanation with reference to this plate you will have to be charged"â€”he then said that he had been doing some work for a man at Bristolâ€”I asked if he knew his nameâ€”he gave his name as Collierâ€”I said, "What address?"â€”he said, "40, Park Street, Bristol"â€”afterwards he said he had changed his address about three weeks ago, the last address he had was some hotel, he thought on College Green, and he thought I should find his address in a letter at his office, and also some proofs of the work he had doneâ€”I asked him how many transactions he had had with this manâ€”he said nine or tenâ€”on searching him I found two letters among other things, and also the receipt of a registered letterâ€”the two letters are marked C and D, and both of them appeared to be signed "Collier"â€”they are very indistinctly writtenâ€”he Said he had sent a plate in the registered letter to Collier at Bristol, and this was the receipt for itâ€”it is dated 19th August, 1890â€”that is the Post Office stampâ€”t asked for a description of Collierâ€”I went to Hutchinson's office, at St. Paul's Churchyard, 4a, on the fourth floor, and there found plates 2 and 3, and these proofs taken from plates 2, 5, 3, 6, 7, 10 and 11, they were all together in a drawerâ€”I also found a little drawing of the border in plate 8, and another letter from Jeanuiâ€”on

7th September I went to Bristol, to St. Bartholomew's Hotel, and there made inquiries for Jeanui, but did not find himâ€”on Tuesday, 8th, I went to room 45 at that hotelâ€”I there found 198 sheets signed Low, in a letter-boxâ€”when at Hutchinson's I found these two books, one called a ledger and the other apparently a cash-bookâ€”I found entries under the head of "French," the name of Collier does not appearâ€”in the address-book there is the name of Collier, College Green; I got the correct name from that book. (MR. MATHEWS stated that there were certain items in the account-book of sums received and paid.)
Cross-examined by MR. GILL. Hutchinson at once gave his correct name and address.
RICHARD LOW (Detective Sergeant), I went to Hutchinson's, and found plate No. 4, and this genuine coupon.
Cross-examined by MR. HUTTON. I went to Bristol with the last witnessâ€”I searched the trunk there; I happened to have a key in my pocket which fitted itâ€”the prisoner was absent at the time.

FREDERICK DOWNES (City Detective Inspector). About eleven in the morning of 8th September I saw Jeanui go to 4A, St. Paul's Churchyard; he went up to Hutchinson's office and tried the door, it was lockedâ€”I followed him to the White Swan in Carter Lane, and afterwards to the Albion; I instructed two other officers to watch himâ€”about three in the afternoon I went up to room 15 and there found Jeanui in bedâ€”I said, "Your name is Collier"â€”he said, "Me no Collier"â€”I said, "I know it is, get up; what have you got in your clothes here?"â€”they were hanging up on the door and on the bedâ€”I searched his clothes and found the plate No. 14 and eight different coupons; one is a fac simile of plate 14, it is for twenty-five roubles; I also found seven other coupons and a one hundred rouble noteâ€”I said, "You will have to go to the station with me, and you will be charged with having a plate in your possession for the purpose of forging Russian coupons, and you will be further charged with forging this plate"â€”I took him to the City, and he was charged with being concerned with Hutchinsonâ€”he said, "I did not make any engraving"â€”I found on him this passport, dated that same day, 8th September, for Constantinople.

Cross-examined by MR. GILL. In St. Paul's Churchyard, where Hutchinson had two rooms, there was a written notice on the door, "J. B. Hutchinson will be back in a few days," and in the street there was "Hutchinson, Engraver. "

Cross-examined by MR. HUTTON. I believe I have stated all the conversation with Jeanuiâ€”he made some demur to my taking possession of his propertyâ€”I have made one omission, I said to him, "You know Hutchinson, and you have just come from Bristol"â€”he said, "Yes"â€”I think he speaks English wellâ€”the whole thing occupied probably an hour.
By the COURT. I believe he understands French; he said at the Guildhall he could speak four languages; he did not say which they wereâ€”his passport describes him as a Greek.

ROBERT ROBINSON (Bristol Detective Sergeant). On 9th September I went to Mr. Spriggs' office at Bristol, and there found the nine plates marked 5 to 13, also 59 sheets of coupons, eight on each sheet, 58 other sheets of coupons of 4 roubles 32 copecks, and 123 sheets of coupons of 32 copecks printed on one side only.

WILLIAM WBIGHT (Re-examined). The letters found on Jeanui from Hutchinson are in French and Russian, some of them have been translated; I found this bundle of letters in Jeauni's room, there are none from Hutchinson but these.

ARTHUR NADERNI (assisted by an interpreter), I am chief of the engraving department of the Imperial Expedition of St. Petersburgâ€”from that department all rouble notes, stamped billets, coupons, and obligations of the Imperial Government are issuedâ€”I have seen all those that have been produced here to-day; they are genuine coupons for the sum which appears upon them, and they would be obligations which would be met in the ordinary course of things on presentment by the Government of Russia. [Referring to coupons A, B, C, D, E, F, and H 1, H 2, and H 3 passed by Jeanui to Spriggs, and by Spriggs to Lyall]â€”I have seen the fourteen plates which have been put in evidenceâ€”they could all be used for the purpose of printing coupons purporting to resemble coupons which would be made by the Russian Governmentâ€”plate No. 7 purports to bear upon it the impress of the Imperial Government sealâ€”that seal is placed upon the back of the coupons issued by the Imperial Govern
mentâ€”these coupons [another bundle of coupons for 2 roubles 16 copecks each] are spurious and forged coupons of the Russian Savings Bank Depart
mentâ€”that is a department of the Imperial Bank, and the obligations are met by the Imperial Government, those obligations being issued in the first instance by the Imperial Expeditionâ€”a rouble is of the value of two shillings in English, and equals 100 copecksâ€”these coupons of the value of 4 roubles 32 copecks are forgeriesâ€”some of these papers are printed on one side onlyâ€”the bulk of them are printed on both sidesâ€”the latter are finishedâ€”of the others one side is finished, the other side is not finishedâ€”we have on our billets a second printingâ€”this is light yellow, and their paper is light yellow, but has only one impression; the other is not taken, though it is yellow paperâ€”the seal on No. 7 is on the back side of the four coins in the billetâ€”during the adjournment I have looked at some of the letters found on Jeanuiâ€”one is in Russian, the others are in Greekâ€”none are in Frenchâ€”the letters and figures upon the alleged forgeries before me, which are not in French, are in Russianâ€”these billets are all in Russianâ€”the Russian characters correspond with no other language, we have different lettersâ€”the French is a translation of the Russian, it is the same meaning.

Cross-examined by MR. HUTTON. The alleged forged coupons are not upon the same paper that the genuine coupons are printed onâ€”we have on our paper a water-markâ€”the others are on ordinary paperâ€”you can see that at onceâ€”some are finished and some are notâ€”some have seals and some have not.

Re-examined. To see the difference between the genuine and the false it is necessary to use a magnifying-glassâ€”seeing these at first sight I could not directly say they were forgedâ€”Nos. 13 or 14 plates may be used for printing coupons for 2 roubles 50 copecks, and for 55 roublesâ€”Nos. 2 and 4 are experiments or proofs in relation to the same subjec
tmatterâ€”Nos. 3, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, 10, 11, and 12 are plates used for the pro
duction of the savings bank couponsâ€”Jeanui had no authority from the Russian Government to issue, print, or engrave plates for any such obli
gations as these.
Jeanui's statement before the Magistrate: "The plate was found upon

me, but not for coupons, but for a commercial purpose, as labels. There is the difference. The plate found upon me I do not know what is written there, as the lettering is backwards, and I brought it, as it was not done according to my wish, to give back and tell him what letters ought to be done on it, because I told him when I left the genuine coupon to engrave not exactly the same, because this one which I leave is a Russian coupon. I cannot say if I said Russian, but I said 'It is a coupon, and cost money.' I explained to him to make some alterations there, as the order as a label, and as not to answer the same purpose as the genuine. Well, he said I will try to make some alterations in it, but I tell him (I mean Mr. Hutchinson) not to forget about the alterations, and in order to prevent any mistake I proposed Mr. Hutchinson to engrave it if it is possible in my presence, in order to indicate what alterations have to be done in my order. He answer me that you can leave the genuine coupon and go to Bristol to have quiet, and without any doubt that the alterations you require will be done as far as possible. I asked him if he did understand me what I told him. He told me, although you do not speak so clear English, and I cannot understand you distinctly, I see that you want alterations, and I will do them. Before going away where I left the genuine coupon, where is written twenty-five roubles in two languages, in Russian, which he could not understand, and in Latin characters; letters, I mean, on the back, which letters can read every Englishman, as they are English, although I told him before that it was a coupon; but I repeated him that he don't want to make for me a coupon. I left the coupon and went to Bristol. This is for the last plate found on me on the date of my arrest. I wish to reserve my other defence. Of the plates found on me on the day of my arrest I saw one alteration, as I could as I thought that the letters were back
wards, and I could not see distinctly if there was any other alteration is engraved instead of 1891 as is the genuine and the plate is 1892, and I consider that it is not the same, and cannot answer the purpose of any coupon, but everyone can see that it is a label, because who could take it and pay money for it. It is impossible to take it as a coupon and be changed. "

HUTCHINSONâ€”
NOT GUILTY .

JEANUIâ€”
GUILTY â€”
Seven Years' Penal Servitude.

rs.hi: Upon three similar indictments against Hutchinson no evidence was offered.

div1.p: NOT GUILTY .

835.
JOHN CULYER (37),
WILLIAM POOL (20), and
HERBERT KAPPS (29)
, Unlawfully conspiring to steal a case of silk, the property of the
London, Tilbury and Southend Railway Company, and inciting
John Franklin to steal the said case. Other Counts, for conspiring to steal cheeses from the said Company.
MR. BODKIN and MR. TRAVERS HUMPHREYS Prosecuted, MR. SINCLAIR Cox Defended Pool, and THE HON. BERNARD COLERIDGE Defended Kapps.
HENRY WILLIAM JACKSON . I am a foreman to the London, Tilbury

and Southend Railway Company at their depot in the Commercial Road, which is undergroundâ€”there is an avenue down the centre for carts to driveâ€”on either side of the avenue are arches containing goods consigned to the companyâ€”about three-parts down the avenue is what is called the short dockâ€”the place is lighted on the banks by gas; there is not much daylightâ€”on 29th June some cheeses were consigned to the companyâ€”I counted them that day; the right number were in the parcel, 688â€”I counted them again on 6th July, and found 687â€”there was one shortâ€”the value of each cheese was about 85s., and the weight 74 lbs.
Cross-examined by MR. COX. There is a roadway down to the arches for the vans to drive down.

ALFRED WOOTTON . I live at 46, Lucas Streetâ€”I am a checker for the Tilbury Railway Companyâ€”on 20th August I was checking goods com
ing from the docks on the Continental Sank, as it is called, about 7.40â€”I checked the last truck of that particular train; the goods came from the ship Violaâ€”among those goods was a case of silk, marked "J. H. "â€”this is the railway note, "J. H. 2653"â€”I signed the note for the goods at 7.50â€”the case of silk was in good conditionâ€”it had not been tampered withâ€”it was put in the short dockâ€”that is about twenty feet from Moore's officeâ€”I went off duty at eight a. m.â€”the case was then safe.

Cross-examined by MR. COX. There were about seven or eight or a dozen carmen that time of the morn
ingâ€”there might be twenty.

Cross-examined by MR. COLERIDGE. I had not seen Franklin that morn
ing before I leftâ€”he had not been to the depot that morning, to my knowledgeâ€”he would not come to meâ€”no orders are received before eight on the Continental Bankâ€”I am satisfied that up till eight the silk was thereâ€”I saw the foreman installed that morning.

WILLIAM SMITH . I live at 215, Devons Road, Bromleyâ€”I am a checker for the Tilbury Railway Companyâ€”on 20th August I went on duty at eight a. m.â€”I relieved Woottonâ€”Franklin came to me about 8.15â€”he showed me this document. (A request to station master to deliver to Kapps, the carman, the case of silk marked "J. K 2653")â€”I searched for the case; I could not find itâ€”I looked in the short dock and several placesâ€”I wrote on this document "Not to hand" in pencilâ€”I spoke to Moore about itâ€”I gave the paper back to Franklin and instructions what to doâ€”a little afterwards I got this paper back from himâ€”I then signed, "W. Smith, 20/8/91"â€”the case has not been foundâ€”that morning I saw Pool and Kapps between 30 ft. and 40 ft. from the short dockâ€”I did not notice any vansâ€”they were standing in conversation at the corner about 9.30.
Cross-examined by MR. COX. I am pretty sure I saw Poolâ€”to the best of my belief they were there.

Cross-examined by MR. COLERIDGE. There were three or four carmen talking togetherâ€”I had known Kappsâ€”no one is in charge of the short dock; the foreman stands against his box about 20 ft. away; no one particular is in chargeâ€”there might be someone checking.
Re-examined. There was nothing to arouse my suspicion that Kapps and Pool were there for any unlawful purposeâ€”I said before the Magistrate, "I saw Kapps and Pool.
JAMES BARRON . I live at 138, Devonshire Streetâ€”I am manager to Messrs. Gibbs and Co., carriersâ€”on 20th August I gave this document

to Franklin for delivery of a case of silk at my office in Baker's Bow about seven a. m.â€”his duty was to take it to the depÃ´t, and to collect and deliver the case of silkâ€”he returned with it marked, "Not to hand"â€”I then gave him some instructionsâ€”he brought it back signed "W. S."â€”about seven or half-past seven I saw Culyerâ€”I told him to take his horses to the depot, attach them to the van, and bring from the Metropolitan Wharf twenty-eight bales of cotton to the depotâ€”the van was at the depÃ´tâ€”I told Pool to go with himâ€”they then left Baker's Rowâ€”I saw Kapps at Baker's Row about seven a. m.â€”I told him to take the load he brought back the previous day, and deliver itâ€”it was in the depÃ´t, where he had left it on his vanâ€”he should have left the depÃ´t by eight o'clockâ€”the other men would leave the depÃ´t about eightâ€”I followed them to the depÃ´tâ€”I got there about half-past sevenâ€”I saw the three prisoners and Franklinâ€”Franklin was not with the prisoners, he was in the archesâ€”I saw the vans and horses in the archesâ€”the prisoners were sixty or seventy yards from Franklin, in a different part of the archesâ€”I again saw Franklin when he brought me back the paperâ€”Franklin said something about the case of silk on 22nd Augustâ€”on 24th August I discharged the three prisoners, partly in consequence of what Franklin said Franklin was not at work on 21st August.
Cross-examined by Culyer, You were attaching your horses underneath the arches when I came down to the depÃ´t.

Cross-examined by MR. COX. Franklin made a statement to Mr. Gibbs and meâ€”I only discharged the prisoners partly in consequence of what he saidâ€”I discharged them for keeping bad timeâ€”I gave them that reasonâ€”they came that morning at nearly seven o'clock instead of six o'clock.

Cross-examined by MR. COLERIDGE. "We received a County-court sum
mons after we discharged Kappsâ€”these proceedings were taken before thatâ€”the summons was a week or a fortnight after the men were dischargedâ€”Mr. Gibbs may have had a letter before that, I do not know.

Re-examined. Not Gibbs, but the Railway Company prosecute in this caseâ€”Messrs. Gibbs contract to deliver Perlbach's goodsâ€”I cannot say whether a warrant was applied for five days after the summons was issuedâ€”Franklin left of his own accord.
By MR. COLERIDGE. I cannot say if there was, as I have not seen any letter from Kapps' solicitors prior to the action being taken in criminal proceedingsâ€”I know of none.
Re-examined. Before I discharged the men I heard from Franklin about this matter.

HENRY CHARLES LEGG . I am a clerk at the Commercial Road DepÃ´tâ€”it is my duty when carmen have to leave the depot to give them a passâ€”no permit or pass is made out when empty vans go out because there would be no delivery orderâ€”on 20th August Kapps, about 9 or 9.30, came to me for a pass and I made out this permit for five bales and two cases; Kapps' name is on itâ€”it is dated 19/8/'91, because I made a mistake; I had not altered the movable calendar in the officeâ€”I noticed that he was flurried and excitedâ€”I examined the delivery notes and found them correctâ€”he would ask me for a pass for the proper quantity as shown by the delivery notesâ€”I afterwards saw Mr. Munro, the superintendent, and made a communication to him in reference to Kapps; that
was after I heard of the loss of the silkâ€”Franklin also came to me that morning.

Cross-examined by MR. COLERIDGE. My duty is to see that what appears on the document which the carman brings, is compared with what appears on the permitâ€”these five bales and two cases do not include the silk.

Re-examined. It is the rule to make out the pass according to the delivery order, but he would not have any delivery orderâ€”this pass would not allow the carman to leave with goods not mentioned on itâ€”it is not my duty to search the vans as they leave the yardâ€”the pass was to be given to the constable on duty, whose duty it was to see that only seven parcels left the yard.

JOSEPH CHEEK . I am a gatekeeper in the employ of the Companyâ€”on 20th August I was on duty part of the day at that particular gate; I went on duty at 8 a. m.â€”a carman came up with a van about 10.35, and gave me this pass with the name of Kapps on itâ€”I looked round the van, counted the packages, and saw nothing which did not correspond with the passâ€”I marked the time on the pass and signed itâ€”a case of 25 lbs. of silk, flat and lone, might have been in the van without my seeing it, especially if the tarpaulin was up and it was a wet morning.

Cross-examined by MR. COX. I do not know the size of the package, but I should say it could be put in the bag with the horses' foodâ€”I heard it described as about two feet longâ€”I. believed at the time that nothing went out except what was on the pass.

Cross-examined by MR. COLERIDGE. I was not a new broom; I only went from one gate to anotherâ€”I counted the packages in the van, and failed to find any more than were on the passâ€”there were five packages and two bales.

Re-examined. I do not look in the bait bag unless I have any sus
picionâ€”I lift the tarpaulin up and examine itâ€”two or three vans sometimes come out together.

JOHN HAMPDEN . I am examining officer of Customs at Tilbury Dockâ€”on 8th August the steamship Viola discharged her cargo, and I noticed a case marked J. H. 253; it was opened by the dock officials in my presence, and contained silk in the pieceâ€”the box was fastened up again; it was about two feet six inches long, eighteen inches deep, and about the same width.
Cross-examined by MR. COLERIDGE. A bait bag must be rather large for the package to go into it.

JOHN FRANKLIN . I live at 42, Ellen Street, Back Church Laneâ€”on 24th August I was a carman to Gibbs and Co; I entered their service on June 29thâ€”the three prisoners were sometimes employed by Gibbsâ€”on July 1 I saw Pool carrying a cheese, he put it on his empty van in the archesâ€”Culyer was there, his van was loadedâ€”in each arch there is a platform or bank where cheeses were storedâ€”Pool came from the cheese van to the other sideâ€”Culyer went outâ€”I did not hear them say anythingâ€”I was forty yards away; I did not notice them speakâ€”the cheese was put in the van in the middle of the loadâ€”next morning I saw Culyer at Gibbs' stable, and said, "What time did you get home last night?"â€”he said, "About 12.30"â€”I said, "Bid you get rid of the bowler?" that is the cheeseâ€”he

said, "Yes, somewhere in Fuller Street, and got fifteen shillings for it; Pool had eight and I had seven"â€”some little time after that I was at the depot again and saw Pool there with his vanâ€”I had my van there, it was larger than hisâ€”he said, "Will you take a couple of cheeses out on your van, as your van is bigger than mine? "â€”both prisoners have spoken to me about cheesesâ€”Kapps said, "We had intended to get a bowler or two when we got the chance"; and Culyer and Pool have spoken about it on many occasionsâ€”on 20th August I received this delivery note, for a case of silk, from Mr. Barron, and went with it to the depot, with my horse, and lodged the note with the foremanâ€”I then harnessed my horse and went to breakfast at a coffee shop, taking this paper (produced) with meâ€”Culyer went in with meâ€”I sat down and looked at the sheetsâ€”he looked over me and said, "Oh, you have got that sheet for the case of silk?"â€”I said, "Yes"â€”he said, "Can you manage to lose that?"â€”I said, "No"â€”he said, "It would be very enjgy to lose it in the City; Gibbs shall find boys to look after the goods in the City"â€”he said, "It will be no trouble, it can be sent by Carter, Paterson's down to the Lane;" that is, Petticoat Lane; and as soon As it has got to its destination we shall get a sure Â£10"â€”I would not agree to itâ€”we finished our breakfastâ€”he came out with me and said he would see me again before I leftâ€”I went to my van at the depot, and Pool came up and said, "Have you got it on?"â€”I said, "No"â€”he said, "Will you change loads with me, so as to get the silk on my van inâ€”I said, "No, I cannot change loads with you; I cannot chop the work up just as I like"â€”he left me, but he was hanging about for some time afterwardsâ€”I then met Kapps, who asked me if I had, got the sheet for the case of silkâ€”I said, "Yes," and he said, "Haveyou got it on?" I said, "No, I believe they are going to make it not to hand"â€”this was about 9.30 or 10 o'clockâ€”Kapps asked me to let him look at the note; he did so, and, mentioning the marked number, he said, "I will have that silk; if I set my eyes on it I will have it"â€”my van was loaded after that, and I passed out at about 10.40â€”when the case of silk could not be found I took this note to Mr. Barron, who sent me to Smith, who put his name on the bottom of the noteâ€”Kapps had gone then, I don't know whether the others hadâ€”on August 26th, two days after the prisoners were discharged, I met Pool and Culyer outside a public-house in Baker's Rowâ€”I said, "What do you reckon you got sacked for?"â€”Pool said, "I reckon it was over the case of silk "â€”the others heard the conversation but said nothingâ€”a day or so before August 20th Pool showed me a note for the case of silk when we were waiting to load; he said he knew what the load was, silk handkerchiefs, and he would have one for himselfâ€”a little while after
wards he said he could not get it, it was not to hand.

Cross-examined by Culyer. I put a cheese on my trolly about dinner-timeâ€”I believe I had a load of glass; I do not think it was twelve or fourteen feet high, or I could not have seen him nor the cheese in the middle of the loadâ€”I am sure it was a cheeseâ€”I told you the company had lost the case of silk, and that it looked black against youâ€”you did not say, "What do you mean by looking black against me?" nor did I say. "They have sent a man to my house"â€”that conversation did not passâ€”I did not say that a man had been to my house you did not say, "You are all in a shake," nor did I say, "It would

make you shake if they sent a man to your place to turn your place over"â€”I said that I had not been to work that dayâ€”I did not say that they would not let me go to work; I did not go to work, because it was the day that I swore the information against you.

Cross-examined by MR. COX. I left Messrs. Gibbs of my own accord on the Monday after the prisoners were arrestedâ€”I am in regular employment, but if anyone knows it, it will not be to my benefit as regards intimidationâ€”I did not tell Messrs. Gibbs that I saw the cheese stolen the day before; I told one of the workmenâ€”I did not go to work on the day after the silk was lostâ€”I stopped away for two daysâ€”I went to see the foreman in the afternoonâ€”I thought I, or anyone else, might be accused about the silkâ€”I was not afraid my lodging would be searched by the police, but I expected they would come, and told Culyer soâ€”it would be possible to change loads, because if I did the parcels would be made out in his name; because at the time he spoke to me I had nothing in my vanâ€”the checker would know it, but he would not interfere, because it had nothing to do with himâ€”the pass notes are made out at the office after they are loaded.

Cross-examined by MR. COLERIDGE. About twenty persons are in Messrs. Gibbs' employ; sometimes there are twenty vans thereâ€”when I met Kapps I had seen Smith, and he had told me that it was not to handâ€”the note was then in Smith's handsâ€”I am not sure Kapps was at Baker's Bow, but I am sure about the other twoâ€”I absented myself for two days from Messrs. Gibbs, though I was earning regular wages, because it was not safe.

Re-examined. I absented myself for two days because I got sopping wet and got a nasty cold, and next morning, when I got up, I was unwell and did not like to put my wet clothes onâ€”I saw Mr. Barron, the manager, on August 22nd, and repeated this conversation to himâ€”I could have changed loads with one of. these men if I had chosen.

CHARLES SNOOKS . I am a porter at the Commercial Road DepÃ´tâ€”on August 31st I was at the Barley Mow public-house and saw the three prisoners thereâ€”I knew them all beforeâ€”Kapps said, "I reckon we shall all get pinched"â€”I said, "What for?"â€”he said, "Over the case of silk"â€”I said, "What are you running away with that idea for?"â€”he said, "Well, they lost the case, and we expect to get pinched for it"â€”I told him not to run away with that idea if he knew nothing about the case.

Cross-examined by MR. COX. I had no employment then; I had got discharged from Mr. Gibbs; I was loafing about to see what I could get, to get a drink of beerâ€”one of the prisoners said he thought I was a policeman watching the depÃ´t.
Re-examined. I was discharged from Messrs. Gibbeâ€”I got a character from them.

STEPHEN WHITE (Police Sergeant H). On 2nd September I received a warrant for the prisoners' arrest, and on September 5th I arrested Kapps, about 8 a.m., at his house in Baker's Rowâ€”I read the warrant to him; he said, "All right; on the 25th I was at Brondesbury; it rained hard and I got a load of feathers wet; I never saw Franklin that day"â€”about three on the same morning I took Pool, and said it was for being concerned with others in inciting a man to steal a case of

silkâ€”he said, "Have I got to stand to all of it?"â€”I said, "I don't know"â€”he said, "If you want Kapps, I suppose you know he has moved "â€”Kapps' name had not been mentioned by meâ€”Pool was taken to the station, and after being charged, he said, "All right, Sir Garnet"â€”I think he meant the inspector, who was reading the charge to himâ€”I took Culyer between three and four the same morningâ€”he said, "All right; this is a new thing"â€”at the station, when the charge was read, he said, "I did not see Franklin that morning; lean prove where I was"â€”I came into communication with Franklin about August 28th; I went to himâ€”I had been consulted by Mr. Barronâ€”an information was prepared, and I swore it on September 2ndâ€”on the night I saw the two prisoners in the beer-house; I saw Snooks firstâ€”I saw him go in and come outâ€”I am frequently about the depÃ´tâ€”some of tne sacks used for carrying bait are very large, and plenty of carmen carry them for this express purpose.
Cross-examined by MR. COX. I did not ask Pool any questions, or caution him before he made the statementâ€”it is not usual to caution prisoners before reading a warrant.

Cross-examined by MR. COLERIDGE. There had been considerable in
vestigation at the Tilbury Docks to find out what had become of the silk, but I do not think the matter had become common talk, I do not think it was known to any one except the officials; I was the person who was making inquiries of certain officialsâ€”I do not think they made any inquiries, they left it in my handsâ€”nothing was heard of the silk after it arrived at the depÃ´t.

Culyer's Defence. On the Monday morning when I went to work, Mr. Gibbs told me he had got no orders; I went again on Tuesday and Wednesday, and he said the same, and said my horses were not strong enough for the work, and I had better look for another job. I went to him on Saturday night for the week's money; he said, "You think you are clever, you are going to summons me for a week's money, but you will find I can be as clever as you. "

GUILTY .â€”
Judgment respited.

836.
ALBERT GORMAN, Unlawfully
conspiring with
JAMES DAVIS (not in custody), by false pretences, to defraud
John Farnell; Second Count, Conspiracy to steal his money.

JOHN FARNELL . I am an accountant, of 38, Summerfield Road, South Hornsoyâ€”on 22nd April, at 3.30 or 4 o'clock p.m., the prisoner came to me in Seven Sisters Roadâ€”he had his shirt-sleeves tucked up and was without hat or coatâ€”he offered me a paper and a sovereignâ€”I told him I did not know him, and did not take money from strangersâ€”he said, "I have come from Coleman the writer, down the road"â€”I knew Coleman, and I then took the sovereign for a bet and this paper, on which was "Florence St. John, 20s. to win, Harris"â€”I asked him what race it was forâ€”he said, "The last race"â€”the last race that day was run about 4.30 or 5; it had not been

run when he spoke to meâ€”they were the Bath and Somerset Racesâ€”I kept the paper in my hand as I was going home to dinner, and I gradually saw the name Florence St. John disappear, and in its place appeared "Far Niente," as it is nowâ€”that appeared as I was looking at it, with
out my touching it; it was a little damp when it was handed to me, and as it dried "Far Niente" appearedâ€”the "20s. to win; Harris" re
mained the sameâ€”"Far Niente" had won the first race of that day at 1.45, some two hours before I took the paper; I had known the winner a long timeâ€”the paper had not opened at all then; as it dried it gradually openedâ€”next day I was in Seven Sisters' Road when the prisoner came, with Davis, and asked me for Â£5 10s. for a winner that he had backed the previous dayâ€”I told him he would not get it; he asked me why, and I said, "I detected the paper as soon as you had gone"â€”he said, "It does not matter what was on the paper, we mean having the money"â€”I told them what had occurred as I went home, about the name fading awayâ€”I said, "If you molest me in any way I shall give you into custody"â€”then I walked away and they followedâ€”the prisoner said again, "I want Â£5 10s. for a winner that I backed yesterday. Are you going to pay?"â€”I cannot exactly remember the wordsâ€”I said, "No"â€”he said, "Then we mean to b----y well have it"â€”I called a police sergeant from the other side of the road, and told him that the prisoner and the other man had threatened me; he advised them to go away; they refused and tried to trip me up in his presence; both the prisoner and Davis threatened to rip me upâ€”the prisoner said, "We will stand you on your head and shake it out of you," and they both tried to trip me up, and spat on meâ€”I gave them in custodyâ€”they were charged at the station, and taken to North London Police-court the same dayâ€”the prisoner was fined Â£3 or one month, and Davis Â£2 or a monthâ€”I then applied to the Magistrate for a summons for attempt
ing to obtain money by fraudâ€”it was granted, but not gone into.

Cross-examined. Two days before I gave evidence at Marylebone Police-court a plain-clothes officer had seen me, not Inspector Bannisterâ€”I told the Magistrate the truthâ€”the prisoner was alone when he brought me the piece of paperâ€”I have met other people there and had slips of paper given to me many a timeâ€”on the day Gorman came and asked for Â£5 10s. I had not met anyone else there that morningâ€”I do not know that any other bookmaker was there besides myself; there might have been, but I don't believe there wasâ€”Cooper was a bookmaker, I believe; I cannot tell you if he receives papers in this road; if he does he is a long way off from and has nothing to do with meâ€”for the assault on me both the prisoner and Davis were punishedâ€”I had not seen either of them before.
Re-examined. I have not the slightest doubt who the man was who gave me the paper.

WILLIAM LEONARD (Sergeant L). On 19th April I searched the prisoner. (MR. PURCELL objected to evidence being given as to what was found on the prisoner some days before this alleged offence teas committed, and the evidence was not given.)
NOT GUILTY .

837.
JAMES GORMAN (24)
, Feloniously, with menaces, demanding money of
George Overall, with intent to steal the same.

GEORGE OVERALL . I live at 248, Great Portland Street, and am a hairdresserâ€”in April last I used to do bettingâ€”on 16th April I was in Euston Road when the prisoner came and backed a horse called Garnish, which won, and the prisoner was entitled to Â£2 10s. on thatâ€”on that day the Ashley Plate was won at 1.30, by Daintyâ€”about 2 o'clock the prisoner gave me a paper for the 2.30 race, with the "King of Diamonds" on it and a sovereignâ€”I took the bet and he went awayâ€”I looked at the paper, and the words "King of Diamonds "were fading away, and "Dainty" was coming upâ€”I should not have taken the bet on "Dainty" thenâ€”I spoke to one of the prisoner's friends; the prisoner was not there thenâ€”next day I saw him with a friend at one o'clock in Buckingham Street; I asked him how much money he wanted, because he had made previous betsâ€”he said, "Â£8 "â€”if the bet had been made on "Dainty," he would have been entitled to Â£8â€”I said, "I shan't pay you; you are only entitled to Â£3 10s.; I knew you took me on because I know all about these papers; I have seen them for years"â€”he said he knew how he could get it, and said, "I am sure to have it"â€”the other man said, "Why don't you pay the money you owe him?"â€”I walked into the George and Dragon public-houseâ€”someone spoke to me there, and I offered to give the prisoner into the custody of Sergeant McDowell who was there, because I expected a botherâ€”about twenty minutes afterwards I went to the Lord Nelson because the landlord fetched meâ€”I saw there the prisoner and two men, one of whom was the man who had come to me previously that morning with the prisonerâ€”the prisoner said, "I want Â£8"; and one of the other men said, "Yes, and we mean having it"â€”there were a lot of threats; I was going to be ripped up, and kicked, and one thing and another, and have my * kicked if I did not payâ€”I cannot swear to who said itâ€”I said I should only pay what was dueâ€”they repeated the threats; I think they all spoke together, one made one remark and another made another; they were all going to do this, that, and the other; going to rip me up, and all that kind of thingâ€”eventually I paid the Â£3 10s., and a sovereign over, and stood some drinks to get rid of themâ€”I parted with the Â£1 over and above the bet most unwillinglyâ€”they went away, and I did not see them afterwardsâ€”I took this piece of paper to a chemist, who damped it, and there came up the "King of Diamonds"â€”I put the paper on the dresser, thinking it was no use to me, and it is lost; I did not destroy it.

Cross-examined. I have had about twenty-five years' experience of betting and betting-menâ€”on 10th October I gave evidence before the Magistrateâ€”a police officer, Bannister, communicated with me the day before thatâ€”it was in the middle of the day when I went to the George and Dragon; I had been there thousands of times before and knew the proprietor well, and his servants knew meâ€”the prisoner followed me inâ€”he said, inside there, "I want my money"â€”there were other people in the house I knewâ€”I did not introduce the prisoner to McDowell; I offered to give him in charge, and still he kept on asking for the moneyâ€”he left the George and Dragon firstâ€”I had known for some time the landlord of the Lord Nelsonâ€”he came for me and I followed him round thereâ€”he was with me there when the prisoner was there; I don't know if McDowell was thereâ€”I think we were the

only occupants of the barâ€”the observations were made in the landlord's hearing; I could not swear I paid the money in his presenceâ€”I said before the Magistrate, "The landlord saw the money paid "â€”the Lord Nelson is ten minutes' walk from the police-stationâ€”after paying the Â£4 10s. I stood them drinks; that was the manner of settling itâ€”I did not see McDowell afterwards that dayâ€”before I was robbed of the extra Â£1 communicated with the policeâ€”the prisoner's stake and winnings on Garnish came to Â£2 10s., and he had deposited Â£1 on Dainty, making Â£3 10s.â€”I made no communication to the police from the evening the Â£4 10s. was paid until Mr. Bannister called on me.

Re-examined. I said to McDowell, whom I knew, that if he could make it convenient I should be pleased if he would come roundâ€”the prisoner had followed me, and I said, "I will give this man into custody if you will take him"â€”I gave drink to the men to get rid of them; I was afraid.

By MR. PURCELL. I cannot say whether I have drunk with the prisoner since 16th Aprilâ€”he came to me with a paper one morning and asked for a subscription for some one in trouble, and I gave him 1s. or 2s.

FREDERICK DAVEY . I keep the Lord Nelson in Upper Charlton Street,â€”I have seen the prisoner beforeâ€”in April last he and two others came into my barâ€”one of them said, "Do you know George Overall?"â€”Â£ said, "Yes"â€”they said, "We have got a bet to come off him; it is a crook bet"â€”that is a slang term meaning that they had bested himâ€”I said, "No, certainly not; wait a minute"; I went to Overall and told him what they had paid, and he came back with me into my barâ€”I said to him, "Yes, these are the men; they have done you "â€”the prisoner said, "God blind mo, he has turned copper on us"â€”that referred to me, and meant policemanâ€”I said, "Certainly, if you think I am going to help such thieves as you, I am not going to"â€”I saw Overall speaking with the men in the bar, but could not hear what was saidâ€”he said, "You can have your money back if you like"â€”they threatened him and said they meant having itâ€”they said, "If we don't get the money we will rip your guts up," or "rip your* up," something of that sortâ€”I saw no money paid; I believe Overall gave them some, but I cannot say whatâ€”they went out after about five minutes.

Cross-examined. This was my uncle's house; I have had the manage
ment of it about eleven yearsâ€”there is a police-station in Tottenham Court Road, and a police-officer on fixed duty in Fitzroy Square, not far offâ€”I think there were three or four persons in the private bar where the prisoner was; they were my customersâ€”persons whom I could rely on certainlyâ€”I could see some money was passing, after about five minutes, to the prisonerâ€”they did not make much noiseâ€”if people make a noise I should communicate with the policeâ€”I told them, "If you make a noise there I shall send for the police, and have you all turned out"â€”I did not send for the policeâ€”I sometimes have betting men in the house, but I have not had a great deal of experience among themâ€”they use the same language as other customers; we are accustomed to this sort of language; I have been used to it all my lifeâ€”I cannot say if Overall stood drinkâ€”on the Monday after Overall gave evidence, and before I did so, Bannister called on me; and in consequence of his visit I went to
the Court and gave evidence on the 15thâ€”I had not communicated with the police before that.
Re-examined. The two men with the prisoner were not customers of mine; I don't think they had been in the house before or since, but there were two or three other customers in the bar.

GEORGE WILLIAM BENSON . I am a chemist at 157, Great Portland Streetâ€”in April last Mr. Overall showed me this piece of paper, on which was written, "20s. to win," and underneath, "Dainty"â€”he told me something about it, and I applied a little mutilated starch to the back of the paper, when gradually the words, "King of Diamonds "came out and entirely obliterated the word "Dainty"â€”it was written with iodine, on paper containing starchâ€”I gave the paper to Mr. Overall.

THOMAS BANNISTER (Police Inspector), I arrested the prisoner on 3rd October in Drummond Streetâ€”his brother Albert Gorman and Price were with himâ€”I found on him, at the station, this ticket for backing a horse with a slipping four; the ticket when dabbed lightly on makes the ticket read as if for a 4.20 race, and then when the four is dry, it drops off, and then it reads 2 o'clock raceâ€”he was taken to the station and charged.

Cross-examined. The Director of Public Prosecutions is not prosecuting; several prosecutors areâ€”Mr. Overall is the moving spirit in this indictmentâ€”the Magistrate committed the-prisoner for conspiracy and attempting to obtain by false pretences, and stealing, I believeâ€”I did not understand that he refused to commit for attempting to obtain money by menaces; I understood him to intimate that he scarcely thought it was a case in which he should commit for that, but that the solicitor could prefer that indictment if he thought rightâ€”I have been in the force 25 years.

Re-examined. The Magistrate who committed the prisoner was not the same who sat on the first day, and had not heard all the witnessesâ€”he only heard the chemist and Daveyâ€”he heard all the evidence read over, but did not hear it given.
GUILTY . (See page 1221.)

838.
LOUIS ALBERT BENNEZON (37)
, Feloniously shooting at
Marie Claes, with intent to murder her.

MARIE CLAES (Interpreted). I am a servantâ€”I was living at 24, Neil Street, with a man named Monfelsâ€”on the morning of September 24th a man named Jules, a friend of the prisoner, came to fetch meâ€”I had seen the prisoner before, but did not know himâ€”we joined the prisoner at eleven a.m., and went to the Naval Exhibition; we had our meals and drank togetherâ€”we had supper together in the evening in Greek Street, and then went to the Alhambraâ€”the prisoner was a little bit touched, but not quite drunkâ€”at eleven o'clock we were in the gallery at the Alhambra, and when the ballet was over I asked him for my money, and his friend, who was near by, frightened himâ€”he said he would not pay, and I said I would not remain thereâ€”I was on the point of going away, but going down
stairs the prisoner got hold of meâ€”the performance was not overâ€”he pulled

my arm back, and then a shot went offâ€”Monfels was not there; I did not see him that eveningâ€”the revolver was aimed at ma, and it went into the stairsâ€”he was not holding my arm at the time the shot was fired; he was a yard and a half from meâ€”he took the revolver from a red belt he was wearingâ€”he said nothingâ€”after the shot had gone off Jules struck him on the arm; I went downstairs crying, and Charley Baker seized hold of him and handed him over to the police.

Grots-examined. Charley Baker is not a friend of mine or of Monfelsâ€”I did not see Monfels that night; he told me that he had been there, but at another part of the houseâ€”I did not hear that he was in the gallery where I was, and did not know he was going there, it was a coincidenceâ€”that was the first time I had been to the Alhambraâ€”he does not go there every nightâ€”I was not standing at the bar drinking, with Monfels standing close by me at the time I asked for the sovereign; there were only three of usâ€”the prisoner had promised me a sovereignâ€”Monfels did not tell me to ask for a sovereignâ€”I do not sometimes give him money I receive by prostitution; I get the money which he receives every month from Belgium, and when he is short I sometimes give him someâ€”it is not what I receive by prostitution, it is what I receive every monthâ€”I did hear Monfels tell the prisoner that he had better give me a sovereignâ€”Monfels was not on the staircase; there was no one else on the staircaseâ€”I was standing below himâ€”the pistol was pointed at my chestâ€”he was not holding me when he fired, but I had hardly succeeded in pulling back my arm.
Re-examined. My statement was "When I was about two yards from him he fired a revolver"â€”there was one second between his letting go of my arm and the time he fired.

----MONFELS (Interpreted). I am a coachman, but am not in service for the momentâ€”I live with Claes at 47, Neil Streetâ€”on 24th September I went alone to the Alhambraâ€”I had not seen Claes since eleven a. m. till I saw her thereâ€”I did not speak to herâ€”I was down
stairs alone, and when I was on the second step, before coming to the street, I heard a detonation, just at the time the ballet was finishedâ€”I went out then.

Cross-examined. It was a considerable reportâ€”I could not turn back, as I was on the low step to go outâ€”I was in the gallery, but on the opposite side to the prisoner and prosecutrix; it is the same galleryâ€”I had nothing to drinkâ€”it was a mere coincidence that I found myself in the same part as the prosecutrixâ€”I did not go up and say to the prisoner, "you will have to give me that sovereign which you ought to have given the woman," nor did I say that I was the proprietor of the woman or the landlord of the house where she livedâ€”I did not speak to himâ€”I do live with her as my wifeâ€”she goes out on the streets from time to time when we are short of money, but I keep her when I get money from homeâ€”I have not worked at all in London as a coachman; I have a certificate here from Belgium as a coachmanâ€”I know Baker; he speaks Flemishâ€”I saw him at the Alhambra after the shot was firedâ€”I did not know that he was in the galleryâ€”he does not live in the same house.
Re-examined. I have been in London five or six monthsâ€”I work for people I know, on jobsâ€”there were many people in the gallery.
CHARLES BAKER . I am a kitchen porter, but was out of employ at this

timeâ€”I had left work two weeks beforeâ€”I was then living at 47, Neil Street, the same house where Claes and Monfels liveâ€”on 24th September, about 10.30 I went to the Alhambra by myself; I was in the gallery and saw Claes and the prisoner and Jules drinking at the barâ€”she was cryingâ€”they all three had another drinkâ€”I did not see Monfels speak to them or in their society at allâ€”they went to the staircase; the prisoner was above the prosecutrix, she was about two steps lower; I heard a woman scream, and saw the prisoner presenting a firearm towards Claes' bodyâ€”she was about a yard and a half from him; Jules struck his arm and the bullet struck the staircaseâ€”he was about to fire a second short but I took him downstairs and gave him in custodyâ€”I cannot say whether Jules struck the prisoner's arm before or after he fired.

Cross-examined. Monfels was waiting about outside the theatreâ€”I was living in the same house with him; if he says that I was not, that is incorrectâ€”I know the prosecutrix, I have seen her in the house and have said, "Good morning," and so has she; she knows me by sight, that is allâ€”I did not see Monfels speaking to the prisoner any part of the eveningâ€”I met him by chance, at 8.30, in Old Compton Street; I did not see him in the Alhambraâ€”I only said "Good evening"â€”I did not have a drink with them, and I did not speak to Claes or to the two men.

FREDERICK ATKINS . I am an attendant at the Alhambra, in charge of the galleryâ€”on September 24th I saw the prisoner and another man there with a femaleâ€”the other man was not Monfelsâ€”they were very friendly and quiet for an hour or an hour and a half, and then they became noisy and excitedâ€”I saw Baker there, but not in their companyâ€”they went downstairs, and I heard a shot fired, and Baker, I think it was, shouted out, "He has got a revolver"â€”I held the prisoner till the police came and took away the revolverâ€”he had been drinking, but was not drunkâ€”when I ran down he was just towards the bottom of the stairs; it is a very long staircase, about eighty stepsâ€”Monfels was below the prisoner when I went down.

Cross-examined. Directly I went down they all came outâ€”before I left the gallery I saw Monfels and Bakerâ€”I saw them speaking once; they were walking about, and the prisoner and the girl were at the barâ€”the hot attracted my attention; I heard no struggle or scream. Re-examined. I am sure I never saw Monfels. or Baker with the pri
soner, but I could not watch them, I had other business to look afterâ€”I cannot say that they were talking together; the gallery is a very large place, and I have to walk round the whole building.

WILLIAM CLARK (C 90). On September 24th I was outside the Alhambra, and heard a report; the prisoner came out with five or six other menâ€”I searched him, and found this five-chambered revolverâ€”I think he had been drinkingâ€”he went quietly to the station.
Cross-examined. I heard him muttering, but could not understand what he said.

EDWARD MCKENNA (Inspector C). Clark brought the prisoner into Vine Street station about 11.30, and handed me a revolver loaded in four chambers: one chamber had been dischargedâ€”I went to she Alhambra examined the staircase, and found an exploded bullet on the stairsâ€”I could not see whether it had struck anything, because there were a good many marks on the stairsâ€”when the prisoner was charged he made a statement which I wrote down, through an interpreter.

By the COURT. This revolver would take lifeâ€”(it was very small)â€”it is what would be used for killing or disabling a human beingâ€”I should not like it tried on meâ€”the underpart of the staircase is stone, heavily plasteredâ€”if the pistol was fired by the man it would have struck the wall, which is stone with plaster on itâ€”the bullet is quite flattenedâ€”I have looked for marks, but cannot see anyâ€”the statement was read to the prisoner by the interpreter, and I saw him sign itâ€”he gave an address which I found correct; he had been staying there about three weeks.
Cross-examined. This bullet was found on the stairs; there was no mark on the wall where it would have gone if it had been presented at the woman's head.
Re-examined. The bullet must have struck some hard substance.

HENRY SHOWERS . I speak Frenchâ€”I was at Vine Street when the prisoner was brought inâ€”he made this statement; I interpreted it, and the inspector took it down. (Read: "I met Monfels this morning, and had a drink with him; I never saw him before. I then went away with this woman and the man Jules. When he got to the Alhambra Monfels said he was the proprietor of this woman. Monfels then asked me for the money to pay for my lodgings with the woman. I went downstairs and Monfels seized me. When he caught hold of me I lost my head, and we both rolled down the stairs together. I pulled out my revolver and fired, but not at the woman. I fired it down, I did not fire at anybody. ")

GUILTY .â€”
Three Years' Penal Servitude.

839.
WILLIAM JONES (29) was indicted
for a rape on
Mary Crawford.

p.hi: Defended at the request of the

div1.p: COURT.

GUILTY .â€”He also
PLEADED GUILTY to a conviction of felony in May, 1885, at Clerkenwell.â€”
Twelve Years' Penal Servitude.

840. The said
WILLIAM JONES
was also indicted for stealing two postal orders for 3s. and 4s. respectively, the goods of
Mary Crawford.

MARY CRAWFORD . On the morning I met the prisoner while sitting on the seat I had received a letter from my brother containing two postal orders; I had them in my pocketâ€”I showed him my brother's letter, because he said I went with somebody the night beforeâ€”he put them in his pocketâ€”he took them out of my handâ€”I was not willing he should have them, but he wanted to see my brother's letter, and said it I was going to be his wife he had better know my affairs, and he opened my purse against my willâ€”out of a few shillings there were only threepence left in itâ€”he said, "What have you done with it?"â€”I said, "What is that to you?" he took the threepence and the postal orders, and gave me the purse backâ€”I kept asking him for the orders, and I had to apologise to my landlady because I could not pay herâ€”when, on the 3rd, I saw him I caught hold of him, and told him I was going to give

him in charge, and he put some money in my handâ€”when the policeman was speaking to him I said I did not want my money; I wanted to charge himâ€”I did not know what charging was till the policeman told me.

Cross-examined by the prisoner. You snatched the postal orders from meâ€”I did not then give you in charge, because you told me they were all right, and that you would change them and give them back to meâ€”you returned me seven shillings and sixpence on the Thursday when I told you I would give you in chargeâ€”you never asked for sixpence; you said you gave me a shilling, I said you did notâ€”I never said you deserved sixpenceâ€”I did not know I had got the money; I was all shaking, and I afraidâ€”you told me to keep quiet and say nothing about the other [charge], and you would come to Tichborne Street later on; but I walked from you, telling you I did not want it, but wanted to see a policemanâ€”I was sent for to a public-house to see if you were the manâ€”I saw you begin to run in the Edgware Roadâ€”I do not remember the inspector saying he could not take the charge as I bad compounded the felonyâ€”I said I would give you in charge for brutally assaulting meâ€”I went to Tichborne Street and back to the Police-station.
ALFRED SMITH (B R 16). The prosecutrix described the prisoner as having a beard.

Cross-examined by the prisoner. I did not smell any drug; the prose
cutrix appeared in trouble, and was cryingâ€”she seemed perfectly sensibleâ€”I should not judge from her appearance she was under the influence of a drugâ€”I do not know if I could tell whether she was or not, but I did not notice itâ€”after she left me she walked towards Albert Gateâ€”I walked up and down for some time afterwards.

FREDERICK GRIEVE (F 192). I found the prisoner detained by Frederick Gloverâ€”the prosecutrix charged him with stealing seven shillings and assaulting herâ€”I asked her in what way; she could not tell me, but said she wanted to charge himâ€”he said, "I will give her the money back"â€”she said, "I do not want the money, I want to charge him. "

Cross-examined. The inspector did not make any remark about not being able to take the charge on account of taking the money backâ€”I did not hear the prosecutrix say anything about being druggedâ€”I was in the roomâ€”I went for a cab to take you to another Police-stationâ€”I did not know the prosecutrix was sent home.

JOHN MARTIN . When charged at the station the prisoner said, "I did not steal it, because I gave it to her back"â€”nothing was said about compounding a felonyâ€”I was sent to make inquiries; I do know whether the prosecutrix left or notâ€”she was at the station when I came back.

p.hi: The prisoner, in defence, said he gave the prosecutrix her money back, and the inspector hesitated to take the charge on the ground of her compounding a felony; he gave her seven shillings and sixpence, and she refused to take the sixpence, saying he deserved it, and that her evidence was inconsistent on both charges.

div1.p:
GUILTY .â€”
Six Months' Hard Labour, to precede the sentence of Twelve Years' in the last case.

841.
JAMES GORMAN (24) and
ALBERT GORMAN (28) were again indicted with
RICHARD PRICE (24)
, for feloniously demanding money from
Frederick Wack, by menaces.

FREDERICK WACK . I am a commission agent, of 52, Camden Roadâ€”on October 2nd, about 2.45, James Gorman came to me outside Euston Station, and I took this piece of paper (produced) as a bet for the 4.30 raceâ€”when I took it out of my pocket again I found that the four had disappearedâ€”next day James Gorman came to me near the Drummond, and said, "I want to draw a bit"â€”I said, "You want nothing, you lost your money yesterday"â€”he wanted Â£4 10s.â€”he said, "We must have it, you know"â€”I said, "This game won't suit me; I know all about this; this is the old game; I shan't pay"â€”Albert Gorman then came up, and said, "What is the matter?"â€”James said, "He won't part"â€”Albert said, "He is sure to part; he will part right enough"â€”I said, "No, I shan't"â€”Price then came up and said, "You are not going to part?"â€”I said, "No"â€”he said, "If you don't, I will have your * * out "â€”I told him I would not pay, and at that time Bannister came upâ€”they said they meant having the money, and would have itâ€”I said they would not; one of them laid hold of me by my collar, I think it was Albert, and said, "You will have to part"â€”Bannister said, "What is up here?"â€”I said, "These men want to get some money off me by the old paper trick, and I don't mean to pay "â€”he asked me if I would charge themâ€”I said, "If they will take their sovereign back I will not charge them."

Cross-examined by MR. PURCELL. I had seen Bannister the night before; he was a short distance off when the conversation occurredâ€”this was about one o'clock in the day, outside the Drummond Hotel, the landlord of which is a friend of mine, and the potman and barman know me by sightâ€”I was ten minutes' walk from the nearest police-station, and nearer than that to the fixed point, where a policeman can always be foundâ€”I have had fifteen years' experience of Dottingâ€”I could not part on a swindle.

THOMAS BANNISTER (Inspector S). I was spoken to about this on. October 2nd, and went to the Drummond Hotel about one o'clock on the 3rdâ€”I saw James Gorman come up and speak to Wack; the other Gorman was standing there, and Price was standing not far offâ€”I heard the dispute between Wack and James Gorman; and when he found that Wack did not part, Albert came up and the dispute continued, and Price came upâ€”I heard James say, "The horse has won, and we will have the fâ€”money"; and Price said, "We will have your* * out "â€”they hustled him about, and Albert Gorman came into the public-house; I went to the door; Wack seemed in a terrible state of alarm, but he did not call on meâ€”I was in plain clothes they drew attention to me, and Albert went outâ€”I went out and said to Wack in their presence, "Are those the fellows you spoke of to me?"â€”he said, "Yea"â€”I said, "I know they are rampers; I have no hesita
tion in apprehending them if you like to charge them"â€”he said, "Yes,

I will"â€”I called for assistance, and they were all takenâ€”James Gorman said, "God blind me, you will find out who I am "â€”they were taken to the station and chargedâ€”I found one of the dropping fours on Albert; he threatened Wack and the landlord, and said, "You will see what I will do"â€”Albert said he was James's legal adviser, and wished him to make a statement, which he did, and I wrote it downâ€”this is it. (Read: "On May 15th I saw Wack take the papers, and tendered him a paper, which he put inside the Drummond Hotel. When I went for the money this morning he offered me my sovereign stake, and refused to give me any more; while I was taking him, Mr. Bannister came out and gave me in custody.")â€”Price was taken by another officer.

EDWARD NURSEY (Police Sergeant S). On 3rd October Bannister called me. and I saw the three prisoners surrounding Wack; the two Gormans were struggling with him, and I saw Albert Gorman put his fingers into Wack's coat pocketâ€”I took Albert.
Cross-examined by MR. PURCELL. I was there by Bannister's directions.

p.hi:
submitted that the menaces must be such as to prevent the com
plainant being a free agent and that although there was a fraud there were no such menaces.
contended that there were menaces, as the prisoners used threats, and they were three to one against the prosecutor. The
considered that there was no case to go to the Jury.

div1.p: NOT GUILTY .

842.
ALBERT GORMAN and
RICHARD PRICE were again in
dicted for
conspiring to obtain money from
Edward Williams by false pretences.

EDWARD WILLIAMS . I am a hairdresser, of 65, Henry Streetâ€”on September 8th Albert Gorman came to me and backed a horse with me, and wonâ€”he came again on September 9th, and in my presence gave a slip of paper to an assistant in my shop, and gave me 6s., which with the previous winnings made Â£1â€”after he left I took the paper out of my assistant's hands, and it said the 2.45 race; when I first looked at it the time on it was 2.15, but it was twenty minutes later than that when he gave it to meâ€”I went out and halloaed after Gorman, and ran after him, but he took no noticeâ€”Workington did not win the race; it was not in the 2.45 race at allâ€”next day Gorman came to my shop and asked for Â£3 10s.â€”if the bet had been properly made that, would have been the sum dueâ€”I said, "The bet was not right; I shan't pay "â€”I did not say what kind of bet it was, or how the figure "4 "came into "1"â€”we went across to a public-house and had a talk; he said he should want his money; I said he was not entitled to it; the bet was with the ink trick, and he should not have itâ€”Price came in and was there, and said, "Well, I should pay, old man, and have no further bother;" he did not appear to recognise Albert Gorman; he was sitting two or three chairs awayâ€”I do not remember that they took part in the same conversation; Price could hear what was said, but I do not think he said any more about it but what I have told youâ€”I gave Albert Gorman the Â£3 10s., though I knew it was not dueâ€”I subsequently saw Inspector Bannister.

The RECORDER considered that there was no evidence that the prisoners con
spired together, and directed a verdict of
NOT GUILTY .

843.
JAMES GORMAN,
ALBERT GORMAN , and
RICHARD PRICE were again indicted for
a conspiracy to defraud
Frederick Wack.
>NOT GUILTY .

844.
ALBERT GORMAN was again indicted
for feloniously demand
ing money, with menaces, from
John Farnell.

JOHN FARNELL
repeated his former evidence. (See page 1212).
WILLIAM LENNARD (Police Sergeant L). On 19th May I arrested the prisoner, and found on him a figure "4" and a summons for an attempt at fraud on Mr. Farnell.
GUILTY .

ALBERT GORMAN then PLEADED GUILTY** to a conviction of felony in September, 1881.â€”
Twelve Months' Hard Labour
JAMES GORMAN.â€”
Twelve Months' Hard Labour.

845.
RICHARD PRICE and
ALBERT GORMAN were again in
dicted for
a robbery on
Edward Williams, and stealing ten shillings, his money.
NOT GUILTY .

846.
CHARLES WILBRAHAM PERRYMAN was indicted
for that he, being entrusted as an agent with certain securities, to wit, certificates for shares, with direction in writing, in violation of good faith and contrary to the terms of the said direction, did convert to his own use the proceeds of the said securities.
MESSRS POLAND, Q.C., and ATKIN Prosecuted, and MESSRS. COCK, Q.C., and FORREST FULTON Defended.

MR. POLAND, at the conclusion of his opening, stated that he was aware that, on behalf of the defendant, points would be raised that share certificates (which were the documents alleged to have been sent to, and to have been converted by, the defendant to his own use) were net unsecurities for the payment of money" within the meaning of the Act (24 and 25 Vict. c. 96, s. 75) (Q. v. Tatlock, 2 Q. B. D., 157); and further that no direction in writing to apply the proceeds in any particular way was sent with. the share certificates. MR. COCK and MR. FORREST FULTON urged that, upon these and other grounds, the defendant must be acquitted. They cited Huddlestone v. Goldsborough (10 Bevan, 547) to show that shares were not securities for the payment of money.

The COMMON SERJEANT (after consulting with MR. JUSTICE WRIGHT) directed the JURY to return a verdict of
NOT GUILTY, as the facts of the case did not bring it within the section of the Act under which the offence was charged.

847.
EDWARD FIRMINGER (64)
PLEADED GUILTY to writing and publishing a libel of and concerning
Francis Waldemar Firminger.â€”
Discharged on recognisances.

848.
GEORGE TILLARD (21),
JOHN FRANCIS (38),
WILLIAM HILL (62),
THOMAS JONES (62), and
JOHN DRUMMOND (51),
Breaking and entering the warehouse of
Leonard Wrightson, and stealing 53 lb. of tea and sixteen tea-chests; Second Count, Receiving the same.
MESSRS. FORREST FULTON, HORACE AVORY, and STEPHENSON Prosecuted; MR. PURCELL Defended Francis and Drummond; and MESSRS. BURNIE and

JAMES O'CONNOR . I am an outdoor officer of Customsâ€”on Friday, 14th August, at 6.45 p.m., I was on duty at the St. Olave's bonded tea warehouseâ€”I secured the premises before leaving, and made all safeâ€”the gates from the street are secured by one padlock belonging to the Crown and one to the merchant on the bar across the door; I fasten the Crown, and the principal clerk the other lockâ€”on 15th April I came there at twenty-five minutes to eight and found the gate closed; the bar was there, but the padlocks had been forced and entrance effected in that wayâ€”I entered with two constables, and found two padlocks, the property of the Crown, were broken off the inner door; they had been safe on the previous day when I leftâ€”Messrs. Wrightson own the premisesâ€”the locks had been prized by a jemmyâ€”I saw a sign of it on the bar.

WILLIAM DAWS . I am principal foreman at the St. Olave's ware-house, of which Messrs.
