Wrightson and Co. are ownersâ€”between six and seven p. m. on 14th August I left the warehouse, after noticing that all the locks on the doors were secure; I saw the Customs officer affix his lock on the outer door and I did mine; everything was secure inside when I leftâ€”next morning I arrived at the warehouse shortly after eight o'clock; I found the police in possession of the placeâ€”a desk had been broken open, and I missed several chests and half-chests of tea, and three metal casesâ€”I thought nineteen or twenty packages of tea were missing, but we have had claims for eighteen, value about Â£100â€”we missed Pekoe, broken Pekoe, Souchong, Young Hyson, and other expensive kinds of tea.
Cross-examined by MR. BURNIE. Nearly all of these Indian teas come to the London market and to other importers besides ourselves.

JOHN CURTIS . I live at 18, New Square, Minories, and am foreman to Messrs. Hamlyn and Co., general merchantsâ€”about 6 a.m. on 15th August I left my house to go to my place of businessâ€”I called to meet a fellow workman at the Angel public-house, John Street, Minories, which is about twenty-five or thirty yards from the St. Olave's bonded warehouse, on the same side of the wayâ€”my friend had not arrived; after I had been there a minute or two I noticed Tillard, Francis, and Jones leaning on a caskâ€”there was a pewter pot thereâ€”I saw an open empty van with a black horse outsideâ€”I came out to see if I could meet my friend, and I saw the three prisoners leaving the public-house to
getherâ€”Tillard led the horse and van down John Street towards where was standing; I had then got past the St. Olave's warehouseâ€”Francis and Jones were walking by the sideâ€”as soon as they got to the entrance of the St. Olave's gates Francis and Jones opened the gates, and Tillard backed the van in; then Francis and Jones came out and walked across the road to Croles' Hotelâ€”I would not be certain if the gates were closed after the van was pushed inâ€”it was near 6.30 a. m.â€”I was about twenty-five yards off at the timeâ€”my fellow workman joined me then, and we went off to our workâ€”in the course of the evening of that day I heard of

the robbery having been committed at this bonded warehouse, and at once communicated with the policeâ€”subsequently I identified Tillard at the Mansion House, he was in the dock; and I went to the Police-station and was shown a number of men, from whom I picked out Francisâ€”about a fortnight afterwards I picked out Jones.
Cross-examined by Tillard, You were in the public-house.

Cross-examined by MR. PURCELL. The public-house I went to is used by man working in the neighbourhoodâ€”I went there at sixâ€”it is a pull-up house for men going to the markets; it is open at 5.30â€”there were no other men there besides myself and the men I saw in thereâ€”I don't believe I had seen these men beforeâ€”I went to Bee if I could identify anyone on the invitation of the City police, either Egan or Outramâ€”I first saw Francis in the dock with another man, and I said, "That is the man"; they did not put him among other men, Jones they did.

Cross-examined by Jones. I don't believe you had anything in your hand when you opened the gateâ€”I did not see itâ€”the looks must have been got off before you got to the gates; you had no time to get them off when you got thereâ€”I only know O'Connor is an officerâ€”I did not see a policeman; if I bad I should have told him; you would not have done it if one had been thereâ€”I did not stop you; it was done so quick, and I was in such a hurry to get to my businessâ€”I think the locks must have been open previouslyâ€”you were in Crole's Hotel when I leftâ€”you were not in the warehouse two minutes; as soon as the van was backed in you walked away.

Re-examined. During the day I thought that I had seen no gatekeeper or officer there, and then I thought something was wrongâ€”there was nothing at the time to arouse my suspicions, but when I came to think the matter over I thought there was something wrongâ€”in the evening I saw an account of itâ€”they are the three men.

MARGARET SPOONER . I am a barmaid at Crole's Hotel, John Street, Minories, nearly opposite St. Olave's warehouseâ€”about 6.30 a. m. on 15th August I was in the bar; Francis and another man came inâ€”my attention was attracted to Francis by his walking in and out, going to the door and back, several timesâ€”the other man was reading the evening paper of the previous nightâ€”they stayed about ten minutes and then went outâ€”they both came in and out several times, and ultimately they came back together and finished their beer, and then went outâ€”on the same day the police came and I made a statementâ€”on 4th September I went to Seething Lane Police-station, where I saw about fifteen men in a row, from whom I picked out Francis as one of the men who had come in on 15th August.

Cross-examined by MR. PURCELL. Ours is not a pull-up house; work
men do not frequently come in early in the morningâ€”I had not before seen the men I saw that morningâ€”I went to the Police-station by myselfâ€”I did not see Francis in the dock or sitting by himself when I got thereâ€”Francis had not much beard then; several of the other men had beards.
Cross-examined by Jones. I should know the man who was with Francis if I saw him; I am not sure if you are that man.
CHARLES WILLIAM RUSSELL . I am a warehouseman in the employ of the Metropolitan Tea Warehouse Company, John Street, Minories, two doors from the St. Olave's bonded warehouse, on the same side of the

roadâ€”about 6.20 am. on 15th August I opened the offices, and white doing so I saw Francis, who had his overcoat collar up, and another man come out of Crole's Hotelâ€”Francis went towards the St. Olave's warehouse, and the other man went towards the Minories in a different directionâ€”after I had opened the premises on the inside I heard a stumbling of horsesâ€”I went to the door and saw a van full of tea-chests and a black horse driven by Tillard, who was sitting on the front rail of the van; as I got down to the bottom step he was just passing meâ€”he whipped up the horses and went in the direction of Swan Streetâ€”the same day the police came to my master's place, and I gave them a description of the man I had seen driving the van, and of the men I had seen leaving the hotelâ€”on 3rd September I went to Seething Lane Police-station, and from thirteen persons there I picked out Tillardâ€”on the following day I picked out Francis there; I do not pretend to identify his companion.

Cross-examined by MR. PURCELL. The men I saw coming out of the hotel were perfect strangers; I saw them from the office windowâ€”it is not an uncommon thing for men to come out of Crole's Hotelâ€”I had no reason for staring at themâ€”I did not see Francis by himself brought out of the cellsâ€”I walked up to a lot of men; they said, "Touch him," and I touched himâ€”that was after I had walked down and walked back againâ€”he was not the only dark manâ€”I don't think I said that I thought Francis was the manâ€”I have not the slightest doubt in the world about him to-day.

SAMUEL JOHN TILLY . I am a carpenter, of 85, Mansell Streetâ€”on August 15th, about 7.20, I was in John Street, Minories, and saw a black horse and a van come out of the St. Olave's tea warehouseâ€”the gates were then closed by two people, and two men sat on the window-sillâ€”the van went east towards the Minoriesâ€”there were some packages in it.â€”I noticed that the off hind-wheel was wobbling on the axletreeâ€”a man was driving it with his legs over the off-sideâ€”afterwards I saw a van standing up on end; the off-side hind wheel that I had noticed wobbling was off the axletreeâ€”it was a black horseâ€”it was the same van that. I had seen come up to the St. Olave's warehouse.
Cross-examined by Tillard. The wobbling I saw would let you go as far as the Minories, and might let you go further; I thought if the horse slipped it would break down.
Cross-examined by Jones. I was on the southern side, opposite to the warehouseâ€”I had a clear distinct look at the men's faces.

GEORGE RAYNER . I live at 88, Jamaica Street, Stepneyâ€”my father is a contractor, and lets out vansâ€”he has a yard in Jamaica Street now; on 15th August he had a yard in Bermuda Street as well; he had three altogetherâ€”about 9 a.m on 15th August I saw one of my father's vans outside a yard opposite; we had two yards in Bermuda Street and one, the Anchor and Hope yard, outside which the van was, was opposite to the other, No. 5, which I was inâ€”the horse in the van was black; it was not my father's horseâ€”Tillard was in the van (I had known him for seven months) and Francis and Jonesâ€”there was a tarpaulin cover
ing over the front of the van, and I could not see what was in itâ€”the same evening I saw the van empty in Anchor and Hope yardâ€”I saw it again on Monday, 17th August, in the afternoon, in the Jamaica Street yard; it was broken down thenâ€”afterwards I picked out
at the station Tillard, Francis, and Jones from among othersâ€”I had seen Francis before with Tillard.

Cross-examined by MR. PURCELL. I had not known Francis by name beforeâ€”I had seen him with Tillard twice, about a week before; those were the only occasions on which I had seen himâ€”he came into our yardâ€”I told the police I had seen him before, and knew him well by sight; although they knew that, they placed him among men for me to pick outâ€”he was the only man I knew by sight.

Cross-examined by Jones. You were seventy yards off when I saw you with the van; I had seen the three of you togetherâ€”I did not see your faceâ€”I know your heightâ€”the detective did not tell me to pick you out, nor did he tell me how you were dressedâ€”I could pick you out by your height.

WILLIAM EDWARDS . I live at 189, Catherine Buildings, Cable Street, and am fifteen years oldâ€”I was in Tillard's employment for about. three monthsâ€”I left him about June or July lastâ€”he was a coal merchant and greengrocer, at 75, Gray Street, Commercial Roadâ€”under the shop, and in his occupation, were two cellars which he usedâ€”I know Jones by his coming there about every other dayâ€”he was clean shaved thenâ€”after I had left Tillard's employ I was playing with some other boys in Cray Street one afternoon, and I saw Rayner's van draw up at the side entrance to Tillard's shop in Gray Streetâ€”Tillard was driving the van, two other men were in it, and Jones was walking by the side of itâ€”some sacks were in itâ€”Tillard said to the two men I don't identify that it was only corn and chaffâ€”I saw the sacks taken into the cellar by the two men whom I don't identifyâ€”there was a hole in one of the bags, and I saw some tea dropping out; it fell on the vanâ€”after the sacks had been taken into the cellar Jones, Tillard, and the other man went up to the Bedford, a public-house, with the van, which they left outsideâ€”another boy was with me; to each of us Tillard gave a pennyâ€”I cannot tell what day or what month it wasâ€”on the morning of 8th October I picked out Jones at the Police-station from among others.

Cross-examined by Tillard. I have seen vans at your shop lots of timesâ€”it is the first time I have seen sacks taken inâ€”it is not the first time you have given me a pennyâ€”I cannot say what month you discharged meâ€”I have seen bacon, eggs, and butter go into your place before.

CLARA GILDING . I live with my parents at 9, Gray Street, Philpot Street, Commercial Roadâ€”to the best of my belief I am thirteenâ€”I know Tillardâ€”he used to have a shop for greengroceries and coals at 75, Nelson Street, with a side entrance in Gray Streetâ€”I have seen Jones at Tillard's a lot of timesâ€”I remember playing one day in Gray Street, and seeing a van come up to Tillard's; and I saw some tea fall out of a hole, and Mr. Jones swept it away with his handkerchief, and then afterwards he took the broom and swept it on to the gateâ€”sacks were taken from Tillard's gate, in Gray Street, to the vanâ€”I cannot say how many sacks there wereâ€”the van was empty when I first saw it, and then I saw the sacks put into it; and I saw a hole, and tea running out, and then it was swept awayâ€”Jones and Tillard carried the sacksâ€”I saw no one else thereâ€”they were potato sacksâ€”I made a communication to my mother as to what I had seenâ€”I was not called before the Magistrate.

Cross-examined by Tillard. I don't know if I have seen a van outside your door, or if I have seen you take sacks in or out of your place beforeâ€”I never saw a van with potato sacks outside your place before.

CHARLES JOHN PEARCE . I am light carman to Mr. Raynerâ€”on 15th August I saw one of his vans empty outside the Anchor and Hope Yard in Bermuda Street, with Tillard and Francis in charge of itâ€”there was no horse in itâ€”Tillard said there were a few chips and broken wood in. the yard, I could have them if I liked for firewoodâ€”Francis heard that, he was about two yards awayâ€”I went into the Anchor and Hope Yard between 3.30 and 4, or later, and there found some bits of broken wood and a few empty tea-chests of plain wood not covered with paperâ€”on 17th August, about 9.30 a.m., I saw Francis and Tillard with Mr. Rayner's van empty, and a black horse with white points of their ownâ€”I have known Tillard for about two years; I had not seen Francis beforeâ€”Jones I only knew by his coming down once with Tillard to Rayner's stable, about taking a little light trap outâ€”I next saw Tillard after 17th August at the Police-court, when he was with two others, I thinkâ€”I identified him as the man I saw with Rayner's vanâ€”afterwards I picked out Jones from a number of men as one of the men who came down with Tillard on one occasion, and as a friend of Tillard's.
By the JURY. I knew they were tea-chests by the black marks on them, the writingâ€”I can tell a tea-chest when I see it.

JOHN ANGEL . I am a carman and contractor, of 181, Mare Street, Hackneyâ€”on Monday, 17th August, at 9.45, I was outside my shop, and saw a van which had broken down, the tyre having burst off the hind off wheel, with a crowd of people round itâ€”Tillard, whom I knew, was in charge of itâ€”he asked me if I had a van I could let him haveâ€”I said, "Yes, there is one at the yard you can go and take "â€”he took the horse out, and my van was brought down to the other oneâ€”in the broken van were sacks, which I thought contained corn or something; the name on. them was "Press Brothers, Yarmouth," to the best of my knowledgeâ€”some tarpaulins were also in the vanâ€”all the sacks were moved from the broken-down van into mineâ€”Francis assisted Tillardâ€”I asked Tillard how long he would be with the van, and he said an hour to an hour and a halfâ€”Jones stood on one side, as a spectator, as far as I could judge, and took no part in loading or unloading; he was clean shaven then, except a moustacheâ€”I went with Tillard and Francis to the public-house and had something to drinkâ€”they left the broken-down van on the near side of the road, opposite the Dolphin public-houseâ€”shortly afterwards Tillard returned, and paid me one shilling and sixpence for the hire of my vanâ€”after it was put back into my yard by Tillard I went to put my horse in to go out on my own work, and I noticed some teaâ€”the horse was a dark cob, what we call a cabber, straight forelegs the near side, and white points behind; it belongs to a cabmanâ€”the harness was white metal plateâ€”afterwards I went to Mr. Robertson's stables in Hanover Square, and saw the same harness and horse thereâ€”when the van was broken down in the road, Tillard asked Francis to go up to the owner of the van and tell him about it; he did so, and brought back two or three menâ€”I said, "You had better go and get a spanner from my place, and try and get a wheel from my place, and put a barrow underneath"â€”Tillard told Francis to get the van taken away, and he returned to take it away, going to my shop after the spanner.

Cross-examined by Jones. Five of us altogether went and had a drink; you would not have come if you had had anything to do with the men, you are too artfulâ€”I have been a policemanâ€”I saw you there.

CAROLINE HUTCHINSON . I am the wife of William Hutchinson, a grocer and provision dealer, of 28, Amherst Road, Hackneyâ€”the busi
ness is carried on in my maiden name of Caroline Newmanâ€”I had known Hill as a customer six or seven weeks before I first gave evidenceâ€”between 8 and 9 a. m. on Monday, 17th August, Hill called; I had spoken to him before about a pair of scales which I wanted to purchaseâ€”he said, "I have brought you a weighing machine;" I told him to bring it inâ€”he brought in the bottom part, and Francis brought in the top, and they fixed it up ready to be used, and went awayâ€”Hill came after ten o'clock and said, "I have brought youâ€”the weighing machine, and I have brought some horse's fodder, and I should like to try the machine to see if it is correct"â€”I said, "Decidedly"â€”he was aloneâ€”I flaw a black-covered empty van drive up to the door and stop there; another man was outside pointing, and a full van came up with what looked to me like clean sacks of flour on itâ€”immediately that van stopped outside Tillard brought a sack in to weigh what I thought was horse's foodâ€”Drummond came in with the first sack and stood on one side, and he and Hill took particular notice of how much it weighed; it was carefully weighed; they wrote on a paper how much it weighedâ€”Hill said to Drummond, "Don't be so particular and niggardly in the weight"; and then he told the other men to bring in two sacks quick, and weigh and take them to the covered vanâ€”Tillard and Francis brought them, inâ€”either Hill or Drummond told them to be quickâ€”as the sacks were weighed they were taken out and put into the empty vanâ€”when more than half the sacks were weighed, I saw some black stuff running out, and I took a handful and said, "That is tea"â€”Hill said, "You know too much"â€”I had water boiling in my shop parlour, and I made some tea; it was very good teaâ€”I used to call Hill by the name of uncle, as he was an old gentleman, and 1 forgot his nameâ€”once on that day I said, "Why, uncle, that is tea"â€”he said, "You want to know too much; you run away"â€”afterwards Hill looked worried and fretful, and I said, "What is the matter with you?"â€”and he said "It is a bad job; I wish I had not spent a lot of money over this business"â€”when I saw the tea running out I went upstairs to my husbandâ€”I had seen Drummond at Southend beforeâ€”there were a lot of sacksâ€”every sack that was taken out of the full van and weighed was put into the empty vanâ€”H ill took out "of his breast 'pocket this cheque book, and said to my husband, "Governor, I am a poor scholar; will you be good enough to fill this cheque up "; and my husband wrote something on it and handed it to Hill, who took a little time signing his name, and then he looked at the cheque, and read it, and handed it to Drummond, who folded it up and put it in his left side coat-pocketâ€”I saw him go out, and I saw the vans turning round and driving towards Moor Streetâ€”in the meantime Markham had driven up to my shopâ€”Tillard, before he went, said to me, "Will you shake hands with me?"â€”I said, "No; what for? "â€”he said, "I suppose you buy tea? I can sell you some at sixpence a pound"â€”I should not consider tea at that price was go honestlyâ€”I said, "No, my boy, I will not shake hands with you, neither will I buy tea"â€”there was a lot of tea on the floor, which I took

upâ€”a few days afterwards Hill came and said, "So I am not goings to leave the scales here?"; and I said, "Yes, my husband will not allow me to have anything to do with them"â€”they were 30s.; I did not want to give them up; they were useful to me; he took them away.

Cross-examined by MR. PURCELL. I had seen Francis beforeâ€”Drum
mond had a house close by me at Southend, and he said, "Good morn
ing"; I did not see him again till he came into my shopâ€”I did not know he was a canvasser in the drysalters' line in my shop, or that he had been in business for himself in the Cityâ€”Drummond wrote something on a piece of paper with a pencil; I did not hear Hill or anybody else ask him to do that; I do not know how he came to do itâ€”I only saw Drummond just put the weight on.

Cross-examined by MR. BURNIE. I had said to Hill two or three times before that I wished I could buy a secondhand pair of scales; that was some weeks beforeâ€”I am sure Hill said it was horse food or horse fodder when he brought the sacks inâ€”he said to Drummond, "Don't be so particular and niggardly with the weight; live and let live"â€”all he had bought of me he had paid a fair price for, and I had no suspicion of him whateverâ€”when Hill came back about the scales he said they were worth 30s.â€”I said it was not that, my husband would not let me have them.
Re-examined. According to my idea about twenty sacks were weighed.

WILLIAM HUTCHINSON . I am a commission agent at 21, Amherst Road, Hackney, where my wife has an independent business as grocer and provision dealer in her maiden name, Newmanâ€”on 17th August, between 8 and 9 a.m., I came into the shop and saw a pair of scalesâ€”I had a conversation with my wife and gave her certain instructionsâ€”between 10 and 11 she called me into the shop, where I saw Hill, whom I knew, and Drummond, whom I recognised as a man I knew slightly five years beforeâ€”I saw two sacks on the scales, and two carts outside, one empty and the other loaded, or nearly so, with sacks, backed on to the shopâ€”the sacks on the cart were similar to those on the scalesâ€”I saw two men evidently going to take the sacks off the scales; one was Tillard, and I am pretty sure I saw Francis in the neighbourhood hanging about outside, and I think Jones as well, but I am not sureâ€”I do not think I saw Francis in the shopâ€”on the sacks I saw, "Press Brothers, Yarmouth "with a crown and a ring in the middleâ€”I knew that firmâ€”on the empty van was the name, John Angelâ€”all the sacks but two were on the covered van, they reached to the tail endâ€”I saw twelve carried to the covered vanâ€”my wife called my attention to a little heap of tea on the counterâ€”I said, "Halloa, Drummond! How did you get on with your building speculations at Southend?"â€”I had originally seen him there live years before, and I think I had seen him twice in the intervalâ€”I said to Hill, "What does this mean?"â€”he said, "Well, governor, I offered the scales to the missus"â€”I said, "I know about that, and we agreed not to keep them"â€”Drummond said, "Mr. Hutchinson, there is no harm here; it is rummaged tea"â€”I said to Hill, "I wish this had not happened here; I should like to have prevented it; you will take away the scales immediately; you had better clear out at once"â€”he said, "I cannot take away the scales immediately, but I will come for them by-and-by;

I will soon be shot of this business, and then I will come for the scales"â€”Drummond had a note-book in his hand, and a piece of paper on the top of the note-book, and he had a number of figures downâ€”Hill had a piece of paper in the same wayâ€”he and Drummond got into conversation together, and I went outside the shop on account of another van drawing upâ€”when I came back into the shop, Hill took a cheque book out of his pocket and put it down on my left-hand counter opposite to where the tea was, and said, "Governor, I am no scholar; will you write out a cheque for me?"â€”I said, "No, I would rather not"â€”Drummond said, "Do oblige," and I said, "Yes, very well, I will do so"â€”I filled in the counterfoil and body of this chequeâ€”I said, "What amount?"â€”Hill said, "Â£46 "â€”I said, "I suppose I shall make it out in favour of Drummond?"â€”Drummond said, "No, it is not for me"â€”I said to Hill, "To whom am I to make it payable?"â€”he said "Evans"â€”I wrote then, "Mr. Evans, Â£46, 17th August, 1891" and the counterfoil the sameâ€”then Hill signed the cheque; tore it out of the book, went over to the provision counter and put the cheque down and took money out of his pocketâ€”Drummond took the cheque and cash and put them in his pocketâ€”they asked me to have a drink; I would not; they went awayâ€”I sent them two postcards to come and take the scales away, and they were taken away in about a weekâ€”I was present when Hill was arrested; I then saw these scales on his premises, and I pointed them out to the police as those that were at my premises, and on which the tea was weighed.

Cross-examined by MR. PURCELL. I had met Drummond five years before, I think, at Southend-on-Sea, where he was doing some building Workâ€”I understood he was in business for himself in the Cityâ€”I was told he was in business in George Yard, Fenchurch Streetâ€”I did not know that latterly he had been canvassing in the drysalting line in the neighbourhood of my shopâ€”I did not hear anyone ask him to take out his note-book and keep an account of the weighingâ€”I remained in the shop when the cheque was drawn out; I am sure Drummond took itâ€”I was between the countersâ€”I was not looking on exactly, but I saw Drummond take the cheque and moneyâ€”his and Hill's back were turned towards me ratherâ€”Drummond in the Old Jewry denied that he had received the cheque.

Cross-examined by MR. BURNIE. I believe I said before the Alderman that I said to Hill, "I wish this had not happened here; I should like to have prevented it"â€”it is in my original statementâ€”I cannot say that I noticed it was not in my deposition, but I can understand that it may have happenedâ€”I thought it was an important observation for myself; I wanted more questions to be put to me at the Police-court, I was not satisfiedâ€”the police came to me on 5th September; I had not been to them up to that time; I had heard nothing about the case, and knew nothing of any robberyâ€”they came to me about half-past ten at nightâ€”I had been at Brighton all dayâ€”I was rather alarmed and annoyed when they came.

Re-examined. I have not the slightest doubt that Drummond took up the cheque and the money; there was no one else there to take it except Hillâ€”I first heard of this tea robbery from the police, and then I said what had taken place in my shopâ€”my name has appeared in the press in
connection with this matter, and has been injured; my acquaintance with Hill and Drummond is of the very slightest kind.

JAMES PALFRY . I live at 57, Morning Lane, and am porter to Markham and Co., egg importers, Hackneyâ€”I used to work with Tillardâ€”on Monday, 17th August, I went with young Mr. Markham to Newman's shop to deliver some eggsâ€”I saw two vans at the door, one covered and one openâ€”the covered van had some sacks which seemed full in itâ€”the uncovered van which had nothing in it was John Angel's, of Mare Street, Hackneyâ€”Tillard was brushing it out when I got thereâ€”I went into the shopâ€”I saw there Hill, whom I knew by sight, and another man whom I cannot recogniseâ€”each had a piece of paper, and they were conversingâ€”Mrs. Hutchinson spoke to meâ€”when I had finished my job I had a drink with Tillard, and then the vans drove awayâ€”in consequence of what Mrs. Hutchinson said to me, I asked Tillard whether the stuff was on the crook; he said yesâ€”on the crook means stolenâ€”after having the drink, I went back to the shop and found that Hill and the two vans had disappeared.

HENRY THOMPSON . I am cashier at the London and County Bank, Shoreditch branchâ€”Hill has an account there, and had in August lastâ€”this cheque for Â£46 drawn on our bank, payable to Mr. Evans or order, and endorsed "John Evans," has been debited to Hillâ€”it was paid by me over the counterâ€”I cannot identify the person to whom I paid itâ€”these two other cheques are also drawn by Hill on our branch, and are also payable to Evansâ€”the endorsement on the first cheque is not in the same handwriting as that of the other cheques.

WILLIAM STERN . I live at 6, Hessian Street, Stepney, and am a horsekeeperâ€”in August last I was in the employment of James Robert
son, Hannibal Road, Stepney Green, a cab proprietor, in a small way of business; he had a Hansom's cab and two horses, one of them a black horse with white pointsâ€”on Saturday morning, 15th August, I went to the stables at seven o'clock as usual; I found the black horse and white metal harness were missing; the horse had been there when I left the previous night at eight or past-past eightâ€”about nine in the morning Woolmer, whom I know as "Happy," came, and was talking to me when Tillard, whom I knew by sight, and, as I believe, Francis came into the yard with the black horse and the harnessâ€”the horse was warmâ€”Happy asked Tillard where he was going with itâ€”I am hard of hear
ingâ€”Tillard said he was going to take it to Jimâ€”he put the horse into my master's cab and got on to the dicky, and drove away with itâ€”I under
stood he meant my master by Jimâ€”I don't know what became of the other manâ€”after Tillard drove away, Robertson, my master, and Jones came into the yard againâ€”I had seen Jones in the yard with my master beforeâ€”my master was drunk, Jones was soberâ€”Happy asked my master where he was going with the cabâ€”Robertson had only one cab, so that Happy was not able to go out as usualâ€”Jones said to Happy, "Come and have a drink"; Happy refusedâ€”about eleven o'clock Tillard came back with the horse and cabâ€”I have seen Jones with Robertson about half a dozen timesâ€”soon after this there was a sale at Robertson's, and the black horse, and the other horse, and the cab were soldâ€”I don't know what has become of Robertson, or where he is to be foundâ€”it is some little time back since I saw him; four or five days after this trans
action I think.
Cross-examined by Jones. It was on a Saturday in August I saw you come into the yardâ€”Mr. Murphy, the detective, told me it was the 15th.
Re-examined. I am not sure of the day of the month, but I know it was a Saturday in August; it was the same day that Tillard came about this horse.

GEORGE WOOLMER . I am a hackney carriage driverâ€”I am known as "Happy" among my friendsâ€”in August I was driving a cab belonging to James Robertson, Hannibal Road, Stepney, who had a cab and two horses at that time; one of the horses was black with white points; that was the one I always droveâ€”on Friday morning. 14th August, I saw Robertson and Jones, whom I had seen once or twice before, and another man in the yardâ€”they went towards a public-houseâ€”on the following morning I came to the yard to get out my cab; and I found the cab there, but the black horse and harness were missingâ€”I remained in the yard till one o'clockâ€”a little after eight a.m. Tillard, whom I did not know before, came in with the horse and harness, and put the horse in the cab and went away with themâ€”the horse was sweating when it came inâ€”I was there when he came backâ€”on that Saturday my master came with Jones into the yardâ€”my master was drunkâ€”I asked him what I was going to do; whether I was going outâ€”he was too far gone, and he did not give me an answer; but Jones, who was sober, said, "Give him a half of mild and bitter"â€”I did not accept the offer at first, I did afterwardsâ€”my master was known as Pipelights in the yardâ€”I saw him again on the Monday, but not after thatâ€”I don't know what became of the horse and cab; the horsekeeper told me it was soldâ€”I did not go to work on the Monday.
Cross-examined by Jones. You were with Pipelights when you treated meâ€”you led my master out of the yard and told him to treat me.

THOMAS GEORGE PRIOR . I live at 88, Jamaica Street, Stepney, and am a labourer in the employment of Mr. Rayner, the carmanâ€”I know Tillard and Francis as customers of my master, hiring vansâ€”on Satur
day, 15th August, Tillard came to the yard between five and six a.m. to hire a van; he brought a black horse with white points and harness with himâ€”I have authority to let horses to any one I knowâ€”I let him have a van which had the name of Rayner on it, and the address Bermuda Streetâ€”Tillard put the horse in the van and drove awayâ€”the next thing I saw of the van was on 17th August, when I saw it in Mare Street, Hackney, with the wheel brokenâ€”Francis fetched me to the broken-down van, the tyre had broken off the hind wheelâ€”I put a horse in the trap and went with Francis there, and found Tillard in charge of itâ€”it was emptyâ€”I saw the same black horse with white pointsâ€”I took the broken van back to my master's placeâ€”Francis rode with me to the Salmon and Ball, and left me there.
Cross-examined by MR. PURCELL. When Tillard came to hire the van Francis was not with himâ€”the first I saw of Francis was when he came for me on 17th August, to get me to fetch away the broken van.

WILLIAM LANGRIDGE . I am a carman and sack dealer, at 84, Hare Street, Bethnal Greenâ€”on Saturday, 15th August, about nine or quarter-past nine, Tillard came; I did not see how he came, but I saw a Hansom's cab thereâ€”he asked me if I had got a few light sacks I could sell himâ€”I told him I thought I hadâ€”I sold him two and a half dozen; some were plain, and some were marked, "Press Brothers, Yarmouth," and some

"Pilsbury"â€”since the case was before the Magistrate the police have shown me a number of sacks, which are very similar to those I sold to Tillard; I could not swear to them; one of them was marked, "Press Brothers, Yarmouth"â€”Tillard paid 7s. 6d. for them, put them in the cab, and drove away with themâ€”I don't think I sold him this sack with "Pilsbury" on it.

CHARLES HOWARD COOK . I am Superintendent of the Columbia Market, Shoreditchâ€”Hill occupied No. 1 Shop, Georgina Gardens, Columbia Market; no business was carried on there, Hill used it for storing; he had been in occupation of it since September, 1890.

CHARLES JOHN PEARCE (Re-examined). The broken wood I saw was a tea-chest something after the style of this chest (produced); I believe the marks on it were like theseâ€”I have seen tea-chests before when I worked at a tea dealer's; that was how I came to know it was a tea-chest.

JOHN DAVIDSON (Detective-Inspector, City). At two a.m. on 3rd September I went with other detectives to 3, Pereira Street, White
chapel, and to a room on the first floor, where I saw Tillard; he was out of bed and partly dressedâ€”I said, "We are police officers; is your name George Tillard?"â€”he said "Yes"â€”I said, "Dress yourself; you will have to go to the City with me; you must consider yourself in custody; I will tell you the charge later on"â€”he dressed himselfâ€”I said, "You will be charged with being concerned with other persons not in custody with breaking and entering St. Olave's bonded tea warehouse, and stealing therefrom, between the hours of six and seven in the morning of Saturday, 15th August, sixteen chests of tea, value about Â£80"â€”he made no replyâ€”I conveyed him to the stationâ€”on the way I said, "You are the person who engaged the van from Rayner's, Bermuda Street, Jamaica Street, Commercial Road, that van has been identified as the van that drove the tea away; you are the person who drove that van to Bermuda Street; you are also the person who gave to a lad some tea-chests"â€”he said, "I do not deny being the man who drove the tea away; I was hired to do so"â€”the charge was entered at the station; he made no replyâ€”about two o'clock on Sunday morning, 6th September, I went with other officers to 247, Green Street, Bethnal Green, a cheesemonger's and grocer's shop occupied by Hillâ€”I knocked at the door, and after some time Hill's wife admitted meâ€”I searched for Hill, but could not find himâ€”Sergeant Egan went into the back yard, and I saw him bringing Hill out of the coal cellar of the adjoining yard; he was partly dressed and had marks of coal dust on his faceâ€”the only way from his back yard into the adjoining yard, that I could see, was over a low wooden partition; we tried to get him over the wall, but ultimately we got him through the adjoining premises, and he was brought into his own premisesâ€”I said to him, "I am an officer of the City police, these are police-officers; this is Mr. Hutchinson, of 28, Amherst Road"â€”he was with usâ€”I said, "Do you know him?"â€”he said, "Yes"â€”I said, "On 15th August, St. Olave's tea warehouse, John Street, Minories, was broken into and about sixteen chests of tea were stolen therein; that tea was driven away by a horse and van to Bermuda Street on Monday, 17th August. The van was driven by the same men, containing

the tea, which had then been placed into sacks. This van broke down in Mare Street, Hackney; the tea in the sacks was removed from this van into a van belonging to John Angel, Mare Street, Hackney. The same men drove the sacks and contents to this gentleman's shop." (Pointing to Hutchinson.) "At the same time a van drew up there empty. A pair of scales had been taken into the shop. The tea was removed from Angel's van on to the scales and weighed; taken again from the scales and put into the empty van. You asked Mr. Hutchinson to fill in a cheque for Â£46; that cheque you handed, with money, to the persons who brought the tea, where is it?"â€”he said, "I did not buy the tea; I advanced money upon it; two men came to me and said they were going to clear out a shop at Hackney, and asked me if I had Â£100. I told them no, but agreed to lend them Â£46. I was to have had Â£12 for lending the money; I only got Â£10; I don't know where the men live. I know them as attending sales. I went to Hutchinson's shop to see the stuff weighed, and to see that I had not been done for my money. I gave them that cheque. I signed it; it was on the London and County Bank, Shoreditch branch"â€”I said, "The scales with which the tea was weighed are in the kitchen of this house; the marks on the sacks which contain the tea correspond with the marks on some sacks I see here, what teas have you here?"â€”he said, "All the teas I have here I have invoices for"â€”I went with him to a landing on the first floor; I saw there a large quantity of tea in three or four open tea-chests, three com
plete chests of tea, and a sack containing tea, with the name "Press Brothers, Yarmouth" on it, and these four empty sacks, two bearing the name of "Press Brothers, Yarmouth," they have been identified by the witnessesâ€”I said, "I don't believe your statement; I believe you purchased the tea for Â£46, I believe this to be some of the tea; you must consider yourself in my custody on a charge of being concerned with George Tillard and John Francis, in custody, in breaking and entering the St. Olave's bonded tea warehouse, between the hours of six and seven on Saturday, 15th August last, and stealing therein about six
teen chests of tea, of the value of Â£80; you will be further charged with receiving that property, well knowing it to have been stolen"â€”he made no replyâ€”at the station a cheque-book on the London and County Bank was found on him; the counterfoil of this cheque is in itâ€”on 9th September I saw Hill in the cells at the Mansion House in the presence of his wifeâ€”I said to him, "Will you give me the key of the shop in Columbia Market, the place is being watched; you cannot get anything out, you had better give me the key, or I shall break it open"â€”he said to Mrs. Hill, "Tell William to give him the key, it is all up now"â€”he said to me, "You will find all the teas there that you are looking for, the teas and butter you will find invoices for; the furniture belongs to a publican"â€”to Mrs. Hill he said, "I have been let into this," and he began to cryâ€”the same day I got the key from William, who is the prisoner's son, and with it I opened the premises, No. 1, Georgina Gardens, Columbia Marketâ€”I there found ten sacks of tea; on some of the sacks was, "Press Brothers, Yarmouth."

(MR. FULTON proposed to give evidence of other property stolen within the preceding twelve months, found on Hill's premises. MR. BURNIE objected, as the property was found subsequently to, and not at or about the time of, Hill's arrest.) (Q. v. Carter, 14 Cox; Q. v. Drage, 14 Cox; Q. v. Fennell and

Knight, Sessions Paper, vol. xcviii., p. 701). After hearing MR. FULTON in reply, the COMMON SERJEANT admitted the evidence.)â€”I also found two barrelsof loose cigars, a box of gum, a bag containing gum, six views, a photo of the Virgin Mary, twenty photos various, four boxes containing paints, a packet of paper and envelopes, a copying press, and a number of other articles of which this is a listâ€”all those things except the gum have been identifiedâ€”on 6th September, on searching 247, Green Street, Bethnal Green, where Hill was living, I found four chests of tea, one half-chest of green tea, and one half-chest of black tea (they have to do with this case), one barrel of cigars, a quantity of loose cigars, and a quantity of other things which have not been identified, including four remnants of silk, three pieces of plush, four pieces of ribbon, a quantity of needlework, a leather trunk with the lock forced, a cigar case, a silver mirror frame, lady's dresses, gentlemen's undershirts, and these plated goods; on some of the spoons is engraved Dresden, 1890; some of them are silverâ€”on 23rd September, William Hill handed me some property which I had seen at 247, Green Street, on 6th September. (A list of this property was read; it included hairbrushes, on one of which was A. C. Phipps, and on another Ellen Phipps, pearl necklaces, a piece of black silk, and a dress)â€”those things have been identifiedâ€”this lock has evidently been burnt, it looks as if it might belong to one of the trunksâ€”afterwards Mrs. Worcester handed me some other propertyâ€”I had not seen it before; I saw that some of it came from Columbia Market, the trunk certainlyâ€”I went there and saw her get it; it was not from No. 1â€”on Saturday, 12th September, I saw Drummond in custody at 26, Old Jewryâ€”I said, "I am an officer of the City police; you are brought here on a charge of being concerned, with George Tillard, John Francis, and William Hill, in custody, with breaking and entering St. Olave's tea warehouse, John Street, Minories, between the hours of six and seven on the morning of Saturday, 15th August last, and stealing therein about sixteen chests of tea; you will be further charged with receiving that tea knowing it to be stolen"â€”he said, "I know nothing about it"â€”I said, "Do you know a person named Hill?"â€”he said, "Yes"â€”I said, "Do you know a person named Hutchinson, of 28, Amherst Road, Hackney?"â€”he said, "Yes"â€”I said, "It is alleged against you that you were present at Hutchinson's shop on Monday, 17th August, and a van drove up loaded with sacks containing tea, the sacks were removed from that van, placed upon scales in Hutchinson's shop, and weighed; you superintended the weighing of the tea, which was afterwards taken out and put into an empty van. After the tea had been weighed you received from Hill a cheque for Â£46, which had been made out in the name of Evans by Hutchinson at the request of Hill; when the cheque was handed to you Hill also handed you some money"â€”he said, "I know nothing about any cheque; I was there at Hutchinson's, I don't know the date; I went there to get orders; I canvass Hackney, and that is on my ground"â€”he was confronted with Hutchinson, taken to Seething Lane Police-station, and detainedâ€”on 13th September, with other officers, I saw Jones at the corner of Buros Street, Commercial Roadâ€”I said, "I am a police officer; I want you"â€”I told him the same chargeâ€”he said, "You have made a mistake; I don't know the people you speak of"â€”I said, "I have certain information, and want to search your house"â€”he said, "It is only fair

that I should be there with you"â€”we went with him to a room at 7, Buros Street, which I searchedâ€”I brought away three peaked caps which have not been identifiedâ€”he was placed among fifteen other persons at Seething Lane, and identified by Curtis, Rayner, and Pearceâ€”he did not say anything when charged at the stationâ€”samples of the property I have spoken of and which I have on my list, are in the neighbourhood of the Court; it would take three or four vans to bring it all hereâ€”it has been identified by witnesses who are hereâ€”I was at the station when Francis was brought in in custody on 4th Septemberâ€”I charged him with being concerned in the breaking and entering this warehouse and receiving; he said, "I know nothing about it"â€”he was placed with twelve others and identified by Russell, Spooner, and Rayner.

Cross-examined by MR. PURCELL. I do not tell prisoners what the case for the prosecution is against them unless it is necessaryâ€”sometimes I take notesâ€”probably Drummond's words were, "I know nothing about the cheque;" he did not admit there was this cheque thereâ€”Drummond gave the address, Mary Villa, Leytonstoneâ€”an officer went there; nothing was found that was suspected to be stolenâ€”I know by inquiries that he has been in business for himself in Londonâ€”I know nothing against him in the way of any charge or conviction.

Cross-examined by MR. BURNIE. I believe there is a lavatory in Hill's yardâ€”I do not know that he was suffering from strictureâ€”I cannot say whether I intended to charge him when I brought him back to his premises; I was making inquiries thenâ€”I might have asked the questions I did if I had intended to charge him; I do not say that I examined himâ€”I told him the case against him to tell him the position he was inâ€”I did not caution him; if he had been in custody I might have done so possiblyâ€”to some of the prisoners I told the case after I took them into custody; I did not ask questions of them, nor did I caution themâ€”I found three complete chests of tea and invoices for them; which were not said by Mr. Wrightson to be similar to hisâ€”247, Green Street is a very large grocer's shopâ€”seven other officers were with me when I arrested Hill; we went down in three cabs and surrounded the place.
Cross-examined by Jones. I do not say you had tools on you, I was searching for toolsâ€”I searched your place thoroughly, and found nothing beyond the caps and some duplicates in the name of Hurley.
Re-examined. Hill has a lavatory in his own back yard; there was no reason why he should get over the wall into his neighbour's back yard, or why he should take his stricture with him.

LEONARD WRIGHTSON . I am one of the firm of Wrightson and Co., owners of the St. Olave's bonded tea warehouse, in John Street, Minoriesâ€”on 15th August I missed some tea from the warehouse; it was all different kinds of tea; these chests were broken out from the pile ready at the loophole for delivery to the railway vansâ€”we made out at the time that 1,530 lb. of tea were missing, but we have since discovered a deficiency of two more chests, or 200 lb., making in all 1,730 lb.â€”Davidson showed me some tea at Seething Lane Station; I saw it weighed; it came to 1,358 lb.â€”we missed nearly all Indian tea, and that shown me at Seething Lane was nearly all Indianâ€”I missed one chest of green tea; there was some green tea

among that shown me; and the classes of tea shown me were the same classes as we missedâ€”the value of it was about Â£80 I said at first, but I had forgotten the duty; the tea and duty together would be of the value of upwards of Â£100â€”it had been there various times, some from the year 1888â€”it had been taken from storage within twenty-four hours before probablyâ€”more than half of it was high-class teaâ€”this is an Indian chest with no paper round itâ€”the tea shown me by Davidson was some in sacks and some in chests half full, some of them, broken chestsâ€”the tea did not belong to the chests it was in; I could tell by the marks on the chests.

Cross-examined by MR. BURNIE. Some Indian tea goes to Australia, but nearly the whole body of Indian tea comes to London, so that great quantities of similar teas to these are imported every yearâ€”there are other bonded warehouses besides oursâ€”I know nothing about the retail trade, but I am the oldest warehouse keeper.

CONRAD GEORGE BEAR . I am a cigar manufacturer, of 132, Bethnal Green Roadâ€”on 13th August, about 11.45 p.m., I left my premises securedâ€”next morning I found the gate at the rear and the door lead
ing to the factory openâ€”the gate and door had been secured the night beforeâ€”I missed from 40,000 to 50,000 cigars, worth about Â£180; some in tapes, and some in ribbons, and some in fifty boxesâ€”our bunch wrapper is Japan leaf, and not one manufacturer in a hundred does thatâ€”on the premises we found a jemmy, centre-bit, and skeleton keyâ€”about 23rd September I was shown, at Seething Lane Police-station, about five thousand of these cigars; the majority of them are mineâ€”they are similar to those stolenâ€”we have opened several to see the bunch wrapper, and it is the same. (Inspector Davidson here stated that the entire quantity of cigars found at both of Hill's places was about 5,000.)

Cross-examined by MR. BURNIE. I identify some of the cigars, not all; they are similar in size and shape, and the same kind of tobaccoâ€”I don't know another manufacturer in London who uses the same kind of tobaccoâ€”I will swear the majority of the cigars are mineâ€”I get my tobacco from Charles Myers, of Fenchurch Street, who only sells that kind of tobacco to me in London; his traveller is hereâ€”I don't know what he sells in the provincesâ€”the size and shape is no patent of my own; the majority of these that I have are my shapesâ€”I alone use these bunch wrappers in London, I don't know about the country; I get them from Myersâ€”the tape round these we all use before the cigars are dried.
Re-examined. Cigars are never sent out with tapes round them as these are; they are in an unfinished condition.

THOMAS BEAR . I am the last witness's brother, and assist him in his businessâ€”I am acquainted with his make of cigar; this bundle is our goods I am certain; some of these I am rather doubtful about, but some are our make.

Cross-examined by MR. BURNIE. I pledge myself these are ours beyond doubtâ€”our girls paste their bunch wrappersâ€”this cigar is our make; the paste and bunch wrapper enable me to identify itâ€”that paste is used by other firms, but they don't paste their bunch wrappers, and we allow our girls to do itâ€”I know about the trade in London, not about that in the provinces; I have not heard that they paste thereâ€”this is the Japan bunch wrapper that we use; it is sold for outside leaf,
and I never heard of its being used for bunch wrappers; I cannot say about the country; the things I rely on are the paste, the Sumatra outside leaf, and the Japan bunch wrapper.
Re-examined. Other people use the Japan leaf for the outside; we are the only people who use it in London for the bunch wrapper.

THOMAS HENRY POTTER . I am traveller to Mr. Charles Myers, of 35, Fenchurch Streetâ€”since September 1889, I have supplied Mr. Bear with Japan tobacco leaf; I don't know his cigars, I should know what they were made ofâ€”he uses Japan leaf for the bunch wrapperâ€”that is very unusual in the tradeâ€”I know of no other manufacturer in London who does itâ€”I saw some of these cigars at the Police-station.

Cross-examined by MR. BURNIE. I travel in town and countryâ€”other manufacturers do not use that bunch wrapper in London, but I cannot pledge myself that other manufacturers in the country have not the same practice.

EMMA WILHELM . I am a lady's maid in the employment of Mr. Henry Phipps, who in April last was staying with his family at Dresdenâ€”I packed six trunks, to be sent to Englandâ€”I have since seen these two; the locks were not broken when they were sent offâ€”I have been shown by Davidson some of the property I packed in those trunks, underclothing, silver, and so on, and I identify it as my master's propertyâ€”the trunks were going to a shipping agent in Dresden to be sent overâ€”I arrived in England about 26th Aprilâ€”two trunks arrived, the other four were missingâ€”inquiries were made for the trunks about a fortnight after, but I did not see the property till I saw it in the hands of the policeâ€”I have identified other things besides those hereâ€”these are the trays belonging to the trunksâ€”the property I have identified came out of all four missing trunksâ€”the two trunks recovered had not been tampered with.
Cross-examined by MR. BURNIE. What we have recovered is a very small portion of what was lost.

ALFRED LEUNTNER . I am manager in the express department of Messrs. Pitt and Scott, carriers, of Cannon Street, and agents for Schloesman and Schefferâ€”on 23rd April we received the advice that six trunks were coming from Mr. Phipps; one trunk arrived on 4th May and one on 11th May, four trunks were missing out of the consign
mentâ€”in the ordinary way the trunks would have been delivered to us by the Great Eastern Railway.

GEORGE BERRY . I am a checker in the employment of the Great Eastern Railway Companyâ€”on 7th May I helped to check a van which contained the goods on this sheet and other goods; among the goods are four trunks consigned to Pitt and Scott, Cannon Street; they were loaded on to the vanâ€”Emery was carman.

EDWARD EMERY . I am a carman in the employment of Mrs. Howell, who is sub-contractor to Messrs. McNamara, the carriers for the Great Eastern Railway Companyâ€”about 7th May I received four trunks at Bishopsgate-station, Great Eastern Railway, on my vanâ€”this is the sheet; on it they were addressed to Messrs. Pitt and Scottâ€”I delivered at different places, and ultimately I stopped in Castle Street in order to go to McNamara's officeâ€”while I had gone down the street I heard a man whistleâ€”I only saw two persons standing against the gate when I went backâ€”when I came back my van had disappearedâ€”I went into the office and afterwards gave information to the policeâ€”next
morning I saw the van in McNamara's yardâ€”the four trunks were missing from itâ€”some of the other cases were still on the van, and I delivered them; one of them had been opened.
WILLIAM LANGRIDGE (Re-examined by Tillard). You have had a very good character; you worked for the firm of Raymond and Perry, flour and grain carmen.

By MR. AVORY. I always knew him to be a carman; his father worked for me nine yearsâ€”I am not aware that Tillard has been identi
fied as the person who drove the van away with these trunks in itâ€”I heard he gave evidence this week as the person who drove away the van in the great watch robbery on the South-Eastern Railwayâ€”I always knew him to conduct himself well since he was a lad.
THOMAS PRIOR (Re-examined by Tillard). I have known you about twelve months, and have always found you straightforward and honest.
By MR. AVORY. I lent him the van in which the tea was taken away, and I lent him the van in which to carry away the watches from the South-Eastern Railway.

p.hi: Tillard in his defence said he was employed to drive the van, and that he did not know there was anything wrong.

div1.p: CATHERINE HUTCHINSON . (Re-examined by the JURY). Drummond was not in the habit of calling upon us for orders, nor of canvassingâ€”I only saw him eight or nine years ago at Southend, and I had never seen him since at my premises till he came with Hill and the tea.

p.hi: Jones, in his defence, said that he was not in John Street on the morning in question. Hill and Drummond received good characters.

div1.p:
TILLARD, JONES, and FRANCIS,
GUILTY. HILL and DRUM
MOND,
GUILTY of receiving.
JONES** and FRANCIS PLEADED GUILTY to having been previously convicted of felonyâ€”
Five Years' Penal Servitude each.
DRUMMONDâ€”
Twelve Months' Hard Labour.
TILLARD and HILLâ€”
Judgment respited.

849.
WILLIAM DANIELS (38)
, for a rape on
Maud Andrews, a girl under fifteen years of age.
NOT GUILTY .

850.
GEORGE BOYCE GIRVAN FINDLAY (37)
, Unlawfully ob
taining Â£25 by false pretences. (See page 1193.)

WALTER BATES . I am an advertisement contractor, of 74 1/2, Grace-church Streetâ€”I have known the prisoner eight or nine years, but I lost sight of himâ€”I knew he was in London three or four years agoâ€”he came to my office last summer, to see me about some company in Americaâ€”it was then, perhaps, two years since I had seen himâ€”I

printed some prospectuses for himâ€”he called on January 29th, and said he had just arrived from France, and had not had time to get money from the bank, and was short of money, and asked me if I could cash a cheque for him for Â£25â€”I hesitated at first, but as two American gentlemen had deposited money with him I gave him a chequeâ€”he then gave me his cheque for six hundred and odd francsâ€”I said that I must have the moneyâ€”he said, "The money will be in London in four days"â€”I asked him if it was all right; he said, "Yes, I have just paid in four" or five "hundred francs," I forget whichâ€”he gave me a cheque on the Credit Foncier, and I gave him my cheque for Â£25, payable to his orderâ€”he endorsed it in my presenceâ€”I sent his cheque to my bankers, and it was returned to me with this protest (produced) for which I had to pay a guineaâ€”he had made an appointment to see me in a few days in connection with the prospectus, but he did not turn up, and I did not see him again till he was arrested in Glasgow on a warrant nine months afterwardsâ€”he said he was staying at South Bank, Bromley, except his wife and her sister, who were at Monte Carloâ€”he also said that he was staying at the Hotel Victoriaâ€”I made personal inquiries there, and also at Bromley, and of different tradesmen.

Cross-examined. I was on friendly terms with him years ago, but not recentlyâ€”about a month before this transaction he and I and other gentlemen went to the theatre and had supper togetherâ€”I was friendly with him, or I should not have given him the chequeâ€”I knew that the American gentlemen were men of substanceâ€”it was in 1882 or '83 that he swindled me before; that was on a cheque on the Royal Bank of Scotlandâ€”I got a shilling in the pound backâ€”that was his own cheque for money I had paid for him in connection with a proposed dairy company; he wished to turn a dairy farm into a companyâ€”I was not connected with it beyond doing certain work for himâ€”it was a direct swindleâ€”the American gentlemen deposited money, and the prisoner ran away with itâ€”I pledge my oath most solemnly that he said there was money to meet the chequeâ€”I had not had many transactions in cheques with him beforeâ€”this was nine or ten months ago, but I will pledge my oath to the words usedâ€”my clerk was coming in and out of the room, and I sent him to the bank with the chequeâ€”I have not brought him hereâ€”I have never seen these receipts (produced)â€”he did not show me the receipts of the bank; he explained that his name being printed in the corner was a guaranteeâ€”when I got the cheque back I wrote two letters to Mr. Vallance, and one to South Bank, Bromleyâ€”I wrote to the prisoner, and addressed him as dear Findlayâ€”I did not then think he had obtained the money from me by false pretences, or I should not have written in that toneâ€”I gave a cheque on the Monday, which came back; I have not been prosecutedâ€”I had a big bill to meet, and I was run short in consequence of the prisoner's cheque coming back.

Re-examined. The reason my cheque came back marked "N. S." was because this cheque was returnedâ€”I had not received his cheque back protested; more than four days had passed, and I had not received the moneyâ€”I got the protest ten or twelve days afterwards; it was longer than seven or eight daysâ€”I should not have paid him the money if I had known there was no money at the bank; I was very short.
ALPHONSO CHINFAUD (Interpreted). I am a clerk in the accountant's department Credit Lyonnaise, Havreâ€”I produce the original account of

Girvan Findlayâ€”it is kept by me, and is in my writingâ€”it was opened on 24th December last with 3,184 francs, that was the only sum paid inâ€”on January 1st, 1891, the balance was 1,767f. 80c.â€”on January 5th there was a payment by the head office of 1,500f., and he was debited with that, and on January 9th with 200f.â€”68f. then remained, and on January 30th 50f. were drawn out by this cheque (produced)â€”I do not remember the cheque in question being presented to me.

Cross-examined. I do not know that the cheque was dishonouredâ€”the items of this account are copies of entries in the cash-book and other books at the bank, copied by myselfâ€”we have pass-books, but the prisoner never asked for one till the last letter he wroteâ€”large or small accounts for all customers are kept on slips like thisâ€”I cannot say whether the first cheque paid in, the 1,000f. cheque, was presented twiceâ€”it is dated December 29th, and the date is not in the same writing as the bodyâ€”if the date is put in figures instead of letters we refuse pay
ment until it is put in orderâ€”if there was no date I should send it back to be put in orderâ€”I cannot say whether this cheque has been sent back to have the date put in; there is no clerk here who can tell youâ€”it would be in the cashier's department, and he is illâ€”the deposit accounts are made up twice a year, and a copy is sent on 31st December, 1890, but I cannot say for certain with regard to the prisoner's account.

Re-examined. It is the custom to send a statement of accounts to every customer twice a yearâ€”that is done by another clerkâ€”the cheque for 1,000f. was drawn on the 29th, and debited to his account on the 30th.

JOHN MITCHELL (City Detective Inspector). On August 27th I took the prisoner in Glasgow, on a warrant, which I read to himâ€”he said, "When I gave Bates the cheque I thought there was more than sufficient in the bank to meet it"â€”I found on him fourteen pawn-tickets, dated from September, 1890, to July, 1891, for jewellery and clothesâ€”the total amount of them is about Â£8; they were pawned at various placesâ€”I found this document in his possession. (A list of pawnings).

Cross-examined. The police at Glasgow were informed by telegram; the prisoner was arrested, and I went downâ€”the prisoner was travelling on commission for printingâ€”the first pawn-ticket is September, 1890â€”in the list there is a waterproof coat pawned in the name of G.D. Vaughan, not for 7s. 10d., I take it to be the 7th of the 10th month.

The Prisoner's statement before the Magistrate: "All I have to say is, in regard to the cheque of Â£25 I had no intention to defraud, and that a cheque for 1,000 francs was drawn on Havre by me prior to my leaving Paris, which I was told, three days after calling, that it being written in figures the amount would not be cashed; therefore I could not get the money, and the cheque consequently would be returned unpaid. On that presump
tion I considered I had 1,000 francs to credit, but it turned out afterwards that the cheque was paid by the Havre branch of the Credit Lyonnaise, and the money afterwards returned to me. The first cheque for 298f. 50c., which was the first cheque operating on the account at all at that bank, was not paid by the Credit Lyonnaise, on account of the informality of the date being in figures. Some time afterwards that identical cheque followed me to Paris, whereupon I gave a fresh cheque for the same, writing the date in letters; that cheque was duly honoured. The first cheque I believe can be produced."

GUILTY â€”
Nine Months' Hard Labour.

851.
VAN DELBA (35)
PLEADED GUILTY to unlawfully assaulting
Arthur Yateman, with intent, etc.â€”
Eighteen Months' Hard Labour.

852.
JAMES COLBIT CARTER (37)
, Feloniously carnally knowing
Alice Edith Carter, aged ten years. The prisoner stated that he was "
GUILTY of the attempt, " and the JURY
found that verdict. He received a good characterâ€”
Fifteen Months' Hard Labour.

853.
MARTHA McEVOY, Feloniously
setting fire to her dwelling-house, with intent to injure and defraud.

WILLIAM HENRY PETTIT . I am a firemanâ€”at eleven minutes past two on the morning of 11th September I received a call to Ordnance Roadâ€”I went to No. 8, and found the parlour at the back of the shop well alightâ€”I ordered the hydrant to be got to work, and extinguished the fireâ€”I saw the prisoner shortly after at No. 4, oppositeâ€”I asked her if she could tell how the fire occurredâ€”she said, "No;" that she closed the shop at ten and was sitting up for a lodger; she supposed she fell asleep, and when she awoke she was burntâ€”she was burnt a little in the face.
Cross-examined. I believe some oil was fetched for her faceâ€”it is a general shop for all sorts of small goods.

FRANCIS JOHN VIAN . I am a grocer, at 7, Ordnance Road, Canning Town, next door to No. 8â€”about two on Friday morning, 11th Sep
tember, I was in bedâ€”I heard a noise as of something falling at No. 8â€”I got out of bed and looked out of window; I saw smoke issuing from the back door of No. 8â€”I immediately ran round to the prisoner's side door and knockedâ€”she appeared at the door fully dressed, with her bonnet and shawl in her handâ€”I asked her if anybody was unwellâ€”she said, "No"â€”I immediately ran back to fetch my own children, which I had great difficulty in doing; the hairdresser helped me to remove themâ€”I sent for the fire brigade.

HENRY LAND . I am a hairdresser, and live at 4, Market Place, Ordnance Roadâ€”at two in the morning on 11th September my attention was called to a fire at No. 7; I was alarmed by cries of "Help" and "Fire"â€”I went to the corner and saw the prisonerâ€”I said, "Whatever is the matter?"â€”she said, "Nothing"â€”I asked if there was anyone in the houseâ€”she replied, "No"â€”I asked her if she had a key, or any means by which we could get into the house?â€”she said, "No"â€”I tried the door, it was fastâ€”I then smashed the window of the burning room; the room was well alightâ€”the fire brigade came up some minutes afterwardsâ€”the principal fire was in the kitchen or shop parlour; prin
cipally about the table; it seemed alight all round.

CHARLES COCKETT . I am a member of the Salvage Corps at West Hamâ€”on 11th September, at twenty minutes past three, I went to 7, Ordnance Road, and examined the premisesâ€”in the first floor back room there was an iron bedstead with a straw palliasse on it; there was a small

box on it with papers and ships' discharges, and some remnants of wall
paper, that was wet and smelt very strongly of turps; there had been no fire in that roomâ€”in the front room there was a wet patch on the floor, smelling strongly of turpentineâ€”I saw some matches strewed along the floor in packets, not loose; some under the bedstead and some in front of itâ€”I then went down and examined the shopâ€”I saw there had been fire in part of the shop near the doorâ€”I saw chinaware there, bundles of wood, and a galvanised-iron tank with paraffin oil in it, and under
neath the tank I saw about four packets of matches, some bundles of wood, and two packets of candlesâ€”I went into the kitchen; that was burnt outâ€”I should say the fire in the shop came from the kitchen; the door between them was burnt from the kitchen side.

Cross-examined. The turps on the bed upstairs was spread about; over the wall-paperâ€”it was more than a sprinklingâ€”the top piece of paper was wetâ€”there were twenty-four bundles of matches in dozen packetsâ€”the shop had the appearance of an oilshopâ€”the tank had a cover to itâ€”the wood was packed in a recess under the tank.

JAMES FORD . I live at 40, Commercial Road Eastâ€”I am superin
tendent of the eastern district of the Salvage Corpsâ€”about seven in the evening of 11th of September I went to Ordnance Road and examined the premises with the sergeantâ€”in my opinion there was only one fireâ€”there had been a good deal of fire round about the shopâ€”the back room was practically burnt out.

JAMES BARRETT (Police Sergeant R). I went with the last witness to No. 7, and examined the premisesâ€”I arrested the prisoner and said I should take her into custody for setting fire to her houseâ€”she said, "Very well; I must abide by the consequences"â€”I examined the palliasse upstairs; I did not notice any insects on it.

Cross-examined. The tank was about two feet square, there was eleven inches of oil in it; it had a cover onâ€”the space underneath was filled up with four gross of matches and a few bundles of woodâ€”the prisoner alleged that nine Â£5 notes were burntâ€”I know that hundreds of bills have been circulated asking for the lodger, a sailor, to come home.

BENJAMIN BLAKE . I live in Upton Park, and am a commercial tra
veller in the employ of oil merchantsâ€”I have been in the habit of supplying the prisoner with turpentine; she has had a gallon a month for the last five monthsâ€”the last I supplied her with was on 4th Sep
tember.
CLAUDE HARRISON . I am the son of Richard Harrison, surveyor to the General Fire Insurance Company; he is ill and unfit to travel.

JAMES FORD . I was present at the Police-court when Mr. Harrison gave evidence, and saw him sign his deposition. (Mr. Harrison's depo
sition was read, in which he stated that the insurance effected was for Â£200.)

GEORGE FREDERICK WATTS . I am assistant to Mr. Harrisonâ€”at the time of the insurance I made an inspection of the premisesâ€”I have since valued themâ€”there is no alteration in the stock, but the greater part of the furniture has been removed

Cross-examined. The furniture from the upper floor has been removed, the rooms are nearly vacant nowâ€”I surveyed the furniture before granting the insurance, that is not unusual; in business premises we always doâ€”I made a report to the officeâ€”I saw sufficient to recommend the acceptance of the insurance for Â£200â€”the prisoner was present
when I made the examinationâ€”it is a very small houseâ€”they appeared very respectable people.

HENRIETTA MCEVOY . I am the prisoner's daughter-in-law, the widow of her sonâ€”I live at 54, Richard Street, Hammersmithâ€”the prisoner gave me three boxes six weeks before the fire, about the beginning of August; they contained bed-clothes and wearing apparel; she told me to take the boxes, as she was going to take larger rooms when she had let the shopâ€”she gave me nothing elseâ€”I saw a public-house clock hanging in the kitchen; I never saw it anywhere else.

Cross-examined. I was married two years agoâ€”at first we lived with the prisoner; twelve months afterwards we leftâ€”afterwards I went back to live with herâ€”in August last we talked of taking a small houseâ€”she gave me the three boxes the morning I moved, and told told me to prepare a room for herself and her lodger, Mr. Hammond, when she let the shopâ€”there was a few vermin about the beds; I never saw turpentine used to kill them.

MARY LEE . I live in Ordnance Roadâ€”on the Thursday evening, the night before the fire, the prisoner asked me to take a clock to the watch
maker's; it was an ordinary kitchen clockâ€”I took it to the watch
maker's; it is there now.

MILLICENT TURNER . I live at 74, Park Roadâ€”I have known the prisoner eleven yearsâ€”I had a conversation with her about twelve months agoâ€”she said she was losing money in the shop, and she would set it on fire and get the insurance.

Cross-examined. This is not first time I have mentioned this; I told Sergeant Barrett of itâ€”she told me two or three times that she would do itâ€”when the fire took place I thought it my duty to mention itâ€”there is no bad feeling between usâ€”she has borrowed money of us to pay her rentâ€”she did not ask me to be security for her, nor did I refuse.
NOT GUILTY .

854.
JAMES WALKER (18)
PLEADED GUILTY ** to burglary in the dwelling-house of
Henry Carter, and stealing a peck of pears, after a conviction of felony at West Ham on October 15th, 1890â€”
Six Months' Hard Labour.

855.
GEORGE HARRIS (21)
, Stealing fifteen nutria skins, the goods of
George Rice; Second Count, receiving the same.

WILLIAM GIBBINS . I am manager for Mr. George Rice, a furrier carrying on business at the Hudson Bay Works, Stratford, and Great Prescott Street, Londonâ€”I do not know if we have missed nutria skinsâ€”on Thursday, 1st October, I was in our Great Prescott Street premises when Wright came with these skinsâ€”I recognised them as our nutria skinsâ€”they are not in the condition in which we should sell them, as the grease is not taken from the fur, nor the sawdust in which they are cleanedâ€”we do not usually silver them to add to the lustre before we sell themâ€”the value of the skins is about 4s. each, Â£3 altogetherâ€”they were never sold by our firm in this condition.
Cross-examined. We have workmen who dress the skins; the flesher

makes a mark on itâ€”the flesher and other workmen are not permanently employed by usâ€”there is a mark made by the flesher with a knife, and a mark made by the dresser by puncturing holesâ€”the flesher uses his own mark, which we can identifyâ€”the dresser marks it with a thing with a number of bayonet points which we supply him withâ€”I don't suggest that that instrument is peculiar to our firm, and that no other firm uses itâ€”apart from the flesher's and dresser's marks there is no private distinctive mark of our firm on those skinsâ€”the identification of the skins is partly by the flesher's mark and partly by the dresser's punctured markâ€”these skins would be an imitation of beaverâ€”I have had eighteen years' experience in the trade; I have had no experience in buying skinsâ€”I never heard of honest manufacturers buying skins in that conditionâ€”I should not buy skins in that condition if they were offered to meâ€”we have a stock of seventy thousand skinsâ€”the first consignment of these skins we had this season was early in Juneâ€”we have had nutria skins in stock for five or six yearsâ€”I can identify these as skins of 1891 by the dressingâ€”the skins of 1890 differ from those of 1891 as far as dressing is concernedâ€”1891 is the first time that this dressing has been applied to these skinsâ€”to my knowledge no workmen have been discharged over this matterâ€”no workmen take the skins homeâ€”I am always at the works from nine to six, all over the placeâ€”I have never seen the prisoner talking to any of our workmen, or hanging about the worksâ€”four shillings would be the price for these skins when they were ready for the market; they are not ready now; I cannot say what their value is now; I don't sell themâ€”we should sell them to the retailer at four shillings a skin when finishedâ€”these are not silvered; silvering gives them a gloss and makes the colour lighter, and that makes them of considerably more market valueâ€”the amount of labour and chemicals expended in silvering and dressing up a skin is worth about sixpenceâ€”I do not think we are the only merchants in London who sell nutria skins.

Re-examined. These three stabs are the flesher's mark; the flesher takes the waterproof skin from the flesh side, at our worksâ€”our men always use the same mark; if there are only a few fleshers at work their mark is two cuts, if there are half-a-dozen fleshers one gives them two cuts on the shoulder, the second at the side of the head, the third on the other shoulder, the fourth at the tail, and so on, but if there are more than six fleshers they make three marks, and these three show there must have been more than sixâ€”the flesher is responsible for the markâ€”the marks on these skins were made by our fleshersâ€”we insist on the mark being put inâ€”it is the mark of the flesher which we determine; we tell him what mark it is to be; if there are more than six fleshers the seventh has to put the third markâ€”some of the dresser's marks have been cut out, and some have been partly cut outâ€”the dresser's mark is a figureâ€”there would be no honest reason for cutting out the marksâ€”we make our own markâ€”the skins are this year's importation; we imported none earlier than Juneâ€”Mr. Rice can speak to the skins equally with myself.

By the JURY. If these skins came from another firm it would be possible for them to bear marks similar to these if the same number of fleshers were working on themâ€”other firms use perforated marks, but some have larger designs and numbersâ€”I do not know of any firm in England that does not use the perforated numbersâ€”we put no registered
trade mark on the skinsâ€”the cutting out of the mark would affect the value of the skin; no one would buy the skins with the marks cut, I think.

GEORGE RICE . I carry on a furrier's business, as the Hudson Bay Works, at Stratford, and at Great Prescott Streetâ€”these fifteen skins are mine; they were never sold by me or by my firmâ€”they are this year's importation; the earliest time we could have had them in our possession would be the first week in Juneâ€”we did not miss skins from our stockâ€”we have not taken stock since these were lostâ€”we have 60,000 or 70,000 in stockâ€”I can speak to the marks on the skins.

Cross-examined. I buy the skins raw, in a bale of 1,000 or 1,200â€”I count the baleâ€”each skin varies in weightâ€”I take stock once a year at the end of Juneâ€”there were no skins missed at the end of June this yearâ€”at one period and another we have two hundred or three hundred dressers, the number fluctuatesâ€”we have from fifteen to twenty fleshers in June to thirty in Septemberâ€”the dressers and fleshers employed by us sometimes work for other firmsâ€”my warehouseman punctures a hole in the raw skins; I have only one man who does thatâ€”our mark is a series of numbers from one to nineteenâ€”one number is put on each series of skinsâ€”No. 1 would be marked on each skin in one bale, and No. 2 on each skin in the nextâ€”never more than the unit appeared on this class of skinsâ€”I identify the number on these skins by the portion remaining, No. 4 on one skin, 2 on another, and 1 on anotherâ€”if these skins came from my firm they came from different bales, but once marked all the skins are mixed togetherâ€”I cannot swear that no other London furrier punctures No. 4 or No. 8 on his skins; I do not know of any one else who does soâ€”I have not had an investigation among my workmen since the prisoner was given into custodyâ€”I suppose the skins were stolen by someone who works in my placeâ€”we have tried to trace him; we have lost other goods, beaver and seal skinsâ€”as these skins passed before the prisoner, before he really handled them, he said, "Those are not the skins I sold to Brooks"â€”this skin is in a totally different condition to mineâ€”it does not require a person to handle this skin to see it is not similar to theseâ€”the skins were handed to him like that, and he said itâ€”this skin is silvered and these are not.

Re-examined. For these skins, finished and silvered, we should charge a little over 4s. wholesale, about the same price for the one counsel has produced; we should put a few more pence on the silveredâ€”we should not sell them at 3s. 2d. eachâ€”our business is a very large one, and we can afford to sell as cheaply as anybodyâ€”in taking stock at the end of June we should not detect the absence of fifteen skinsâ€”we use a stamp with points filed to a bayonet shape, so that we can trace in each hole the bayonet shape, and we have a certain number of points to each figure, so that it can be identified.
By the JURY. Each skin is numbered in the raw state before it is dressedâ€”we have never used numbers like these in this kind of skin until last Juneâ€”these figures are partly cut out.

LOUIS BROOK . I am a furrierâ€”I live at 31, Whitechapel Road, and have a wholesale place at No. 10, Houndsditchâ€”I bought these fifteen skins from the prisoner on 1st Julyâ€”I got an invoice, and I have the cheque also that I paid.
