(This cheque was for Â£7 10s., dated 10th July, 1891, payable to Mr. G. Harris or order, on the City Bank, signed E. Brook,

and endorsed Harris)â€”they were skins of this classâ€”I paid 3s. 2d. for themâ€”E. Brook is my wife, and the business is carried on in her name; I signed the chequeâ€”I sent these skins to have them silvered on the 1st October, handing them to Mr. George Wright, and giving him instructions about themâ€”he took them to Mr. Rice to have them silvered, and came back without themâ€”on the following afternoon, between two and four, Friday, 2nd October, I had a visit from two police officers; I gave them certain information and the receipt, and they went awayâ€”after that, in the evening, between 8 and 9, the prisoner came and asked me what was the matterâ€”I told him about the nutria skins, and I said, "The 15 nutria skins I bought of you I have sent to Mr. Rice to have them silvered, and Mr. Rice sent up two detectives to ask me where I have taken the skins from, and I was obliged to tell them and show them the invoice"â€”I said, "I am very sorry"â€”he said, "Two detectives have been round to my placeâ€”" he went awayâ€”on Saturday, between two and three, I had another visit from the prisonerâ€”he said, "Mr. Brooks, what shall I say? Shall I say I have picked them out from cuttings, or I bought them one by one since Christmas? I don't want to bring in any other people into trouble"â€”I said, "Do what you like; it is nothing to do with me"â€”Mr. Benjamin, my partner, was present at this conversation.

Cross-examined. I have been in business for myself twelve years in England, and am a practical furrierâ€”I understand English pretty well, and usually speak in English with my customersâ€”these skins are in the same condition as when the prisoner sold them to meâ€”I don't know that every furrier marks his skins with a particular mark; these are not damaged, but good skinsâ€”I did not examine these skins to see if some
thing had been cut out; I bought them exactly like thisâ€”there is a mark on these skins as if a portion had been cut outâ€”I did not notice the marks when I bought them; we never look at the leather, but at the furâ€”if pieces are put together they don't look like a solid skin; I never turn to the back to see the quality of the leather behindâ€”I did not notice that part had been cut out when I bought these skinsâ€”I did not turn it round because I thought that was where the eyes wereâ€”threepence or fourpence is the cost of silvering the skinsâ€”â€”I have never bought unsilvered skins for 3s. 2d.; I don't think I have bought silvered skins for 3s. 2d. this yearâ€”I have not been able to buy silvered skins in the market for 3s. 2d. as good in quality as theseâ€”I examined the quality of these; they had plenty of hairâ€”I cannot say if I have bought unsilvered nutria skins before; I have not done so this yearâ€”I have got a book in which I put down all I buy; everything is enteredâ€”I don't remember if I have bought unsilvered nutria skins before, unless it was four or five years agoâ€”I cannot say from whom I have bought them; I have bought them in the City, and from many placesâ€”I don't buy them in Petticoat Lane or Middlesex Streetâ€”I have no establishment thereâ€”Mr. Benjamin is the only partner I have; I am not interested in all his transactions and shops, he keeps his furrier's shop in Middlesex Street for himselfâ€”plenty of people would buy these skinsâ€”I bought plenty of these skins years ago, but I cannot rememberâ€”my name is L. Brook, I trade as E. Brook and Co.â€”E. Brook is my wife, it is her businessâ€”she does not know more about it than I doâ€”I have no

business of my own; it is a straightforward business; it is carried on in her name, because a few years ago I lost all my money, and my wife had some and opened this business in her nameâ€”since then I have paid all my debts, I own no oneâ€”my wife gave her consent to this businessâ€”this signature, E. Brook, is my writingâ€”she opened the banking account and gives me the privilege of drawing cheques on itâ€”the only business I have are a retail shop in Whitechapel and a wholesale place at 10, Houndsditchâ€”I trade as the City Fur Company, Limited, in Whitechapel, and as E. Brook and Co., wholesale furriers, at 10, Houndsditchâ€”I do not trade as H. Benjamin and Co.; that is a different thing altogether; he sells goods in his own name to his customersâ€”Benjamin and Co. is also at 10, Houndsditchâ€”it is an ordinary transaction to buy skins in this conditionâ€”I don't look whether they are in this condition or notâ€”I look at things when I buy themâ€”I never said I would not swear that these were the skins the prisoner sold me; these are the fifteen skins I bought from himâ€”I swore at first at the Police-court before I looked at my book, "I believe the skins produced are those I purchased of Harris; but I cannot swear, I have had so many"â€”I never said a word about this transaction till the detective cameâ€”I bought them openlyâ€”I had a solicitor to watch my interests at the Police-court, because I had been fifteen years in this country and never been in a Police-court before, and I went to my solicitor and told him about it, and he said he would watch the case for meâ€”I don't know if it struck me as strange that the prisoner should come and ask me what defence he was to set up, and say, "What am I to say to the detectives?"â€”he is twenty-one years of age; I am thirty-twoâ€”he was considerably upset when he came to my place; I said it had not much to do with meâ€”I produced the invoices to the detectiveâ€”they were not given back to me at the Police-court; the Magistrate took themâ€”it was my own deal, buying these skins; I don't know if Benjamin knew anything about itâ€”I did not show him the skinsâ€”I have not shown them to any
one from the time they came into my possessionâ€”I got them from the prisonerâ€”I don't know if there is another person except myself who can say I got them from the prisonerâ€”I did not hear him say these were not the skins he sold me; I don't know whether he said it or notâ€”it is untrue that he sold me sixteen skins, of which I threw this one on one side because I said it was damagedâ€”it rests only on my word that I bought these fifteen from him.

GEORGE RICE (Re-examined). These are our complete marks; we have 15 points in our 8, and 11 in our 6; in every skin the points are in the same positionâ€”I can swear to these stamps being oursâ€”I have brought this skin to show you; in these they are obliterated.

STEPHEN WHITE (Sergeant). About seven p.m. on Friday, 2nd October, I went with Whitehead to the prisoner's house, having previously been to Brook, and obtained information and an invoice from himâ€”I said to the prisoner, "We are police officers, and we are making inquiry respecting some skins. Those skins are now in the possession of Mr. Rice, at Prescott Street, and he has identified them as having been stolen from his factory. Book says that he obtained the skins from you"â€”I told him Brook said fifteen skinsâ€”the prisoner said, "Yes, I sold fifteen nutria skins to Mr. Brook; I have got a receipt for them, and can tell you where I got them from; but to-day being one of our very strict

holidays I must not touch any books or papers, but if you will come round to-morrow evening I will show you the receipt and tell you all about them"â€”I told him I would call next evening, and left himâ€”the next evening I called with Whitehead about seven o'clock; the prisoner had an invoice in his handâ€”he said, "You see I buy skins first from one party and then the other," and he handed me the receiptâ€”I said, "This does not refer to the skins I am inquiring about"â€”the prisoner said, "The nutria sets I sold to Brook were made up from pieces by myself, and the fifteen skins I sold to Brook it is a job line; I have been buying them one or two at a time in odd lots since Christmas last"â€”I said, "Can you show me a receipt for these, or tell me the name of any person from whom you have obtained them?"â€”he said, "No, I cannot show you a receipt, and I cannot tell you where I got them from, because I do not wish to get other persons into trouble"â€”I then said I was not satisfied with his explanation, and I said, "You will have to go with me to Leman Street Police-station"â€”he did soâ€”at the station, after he had been put back in the waiting room for a short time, he called me in and said, "Can I have a word with you? There is something I forgot. There were sixteen skins that I sold to Brook, but Brook threw one out. I knew that there was something wrong, and when Mr. Rice comes I shall make a clean breast of it"â€”he was taken to West Ham Police-station, and when charged he asked me to allow him to look at the skinsâ€”I let him to so, and he then said, "These are not the skins which I sold to Mr. Brook"â€”before saying that he took hold of one or two and just looked at them, he did actually handle themâ€”after he was charged he said, "Can I have bail and go with Mr. Rice and have a word with him, and I will tell you what my defence will be?"â€”Mr. Rice was presentâ€”the prisoner was not bailed then, but he was taken before the Magistrate and bailed the next day.

Cross-examined. When the prisoner said, "These are not the skins I sold to Mr. Brook," it was the first time he had seen themâ€”he said it after handling them for a moment or twoâ€”he is only twenty-oneâ€”I have known Brook about twelve years, I should think, to speak to from time to timeâ€”I don't know if he has had a fire or two at his placeâ€”I think the prisoner has been in business for himself for about two years, it may be longerâ€”he bears an irreproachable characterâ€”I believe the Bishop Suffragan of East London would have been here to speak to his character, and also the Rector of Spitalfields; the prisoner is a Jewâ€”his parents are people of most upright characterâ€”when he was at the station, and had these conversations with me, he was somewhat nervous.
By the JURY. It was about seven, after sunset, on each evening when I went to the prisoner's.
HENRY WHITEHEAD (Police officer). I was with White during the course of these investigationsâ€”I was with him on 2nd and 3rd October when he saw the prisoner, and on 2nd October when he saw Brook.

Cross-examined. I did not hear Brook give his evidenceâ€”the pri
soner's premises were not searchedâ€”to my knowledge no stolen property has been found there; if there had been it would be produced in Courtâ€”he carries on business as G. Harris, 9, Princes Street.
GEORGE WRIGHT . I am in the employ of Mr. Brook, furrierâ€”on 1st
October I took these skins to Mr. Rice's place in Great Prescott Street, and they were detained there.

Cross-examined. I have been at Brook's about eighteen monthsâ€”Brook gave me the skins in the warehouse at 31, Whitechapel Roadâ€”I did not see where he took them fromâ€”I believe they are in the same state as they were thenâ€”there was no dust on them.
Re-examined. We keep our furs on the first floor, hanging them on racksâ€”I take them down and clean them sometimesâ€”I never cleaned these.

HYAM BENJAMIN . I am a partner with Mr. Brook in his wholesale business, at 10, Houndsditchâ€”on Saturday, 3rd October, the prisoner came to Brook's place, 31, Whitechapel Road, while I was there, and said to Brook, "What shall I say? I don't want to disclose any name to the detectives with whom we are doing business; I shall tell them that I have bought a lot of clearings and pieces since Christmas, and fur pieces, and I have picked these skins out of them pieces, nutria skins" Brook said, "Do as you like; it is nothing to do with me"â€”I am a Jewâ€”the Jewish holiday was on Saturday, I don't know what date; it was New Year's holidayâ€”it begins on Friday evening after dusk, at five o'clock, and ends on the Christian Sunday at six o'clockâ€”it is not lawful for persons of my persuasion to engage in business or anything of that sort during the holiday; it is the strictest fast, except the black fastâ€”it would not be right to do anything on the Saturday night more than on the Friday night.

Cross-examined. It would be wrong to show an invoice to a policemanâ€”a man is not allowed to touch any business documentâ€”I joined Mr. Brook in partnership in 1882, as wholesale manufacturer and furrier, at Plough Street, Commercial Roadâ€”I am a partner with him now at 10, Houndsditchâ€”I have not been a constant partner with him; I left him in 1886, and joined him again in 1888â€”I found a little money for the businessâ€”it is Brook's business, but it goes under his wife's nameâ€”I called on Saturday because it was a holiday, and I went round to see my partnerâ€”I go to see him oftenâ€”no one asked me to call on this Saturday; I came of my own free-willâ€”I did not know the prisoner was going to callâ€”these skins are worth no more than 3s. 3d. each at the very mostâ€”I have lunched and had a chat with Mr. Brook; I met him outside, and I took him inside the public-house; I met Mr. Rice there tooâ€”I and Brook had no conversation; I had no curiosity as to what he had said, and he did not tell me anythingâ€”Brook told me nothing about these skins before they were soldâ€”I asked Brook what the prisoner was speaking about, and he told me they were skins that were supposed to be stolenâ€”I did not tell him it was a rather awkward matter for him; he said he had invoices to showâ€”I do not know why this man should come to Brook, and ask Brook what he should say to the police.
GEORGE RICE (Re-examined by MR. GEOGHEGAN). The prisoner was represented by Mr. Myers, a solicitor, at the Police-court.

p.hi: The prisoner received an excellent character.

div1.p: NOT GUILTY .

856.
JOHN JOHNSON (22)
, Forging and uttering a request for the delivery of a blowlamp, with intent to defraud.

HENRY STINTON . I live at 5, Cooper's Lane, Leyton, and am a flower hawkerâ€”on 13th October, about half-past twelve, the prisoner, whom I did not know, came up to me in the street, and said to me, "Charlie, do you want a job?"â€”I said, "Yes"â€”he said I was to hold some leaden pipe while he joined it, and he would give me 1s. 6d.; it would not take above two hoursâ€”he gave me this note, and told me to go to Young and Martin's, in Romford Row, Stratfordâ€”I was not more than 150 or 200 yards from that shop, which is well known. (The note read as follows: "Have you a blowlamp in stock? If so, please send one by my boy.â€”J. SIMS")â€”he said I should have to sign a receipt there, and I was to put the name of H. Williamsâ€”if I got the blowlamp, I was to take it to him in Great Eastern Street, just opposite the corner of Stratford Police-courtâ€”I took the note to Young and Martin's, and gave it to Mr. Mitchell, the shop assistantâ€”I was detained in the shop and taken to West Ham Police-station; and afterwards I saw the prisoner in the reserve roomâ€”it was half-past five when they let me go; the prisoner was then in custodyâ€”Mr. Mitchell gave me no property.
Cross-examined by the prisoner. I did not hear you say you had to wait till your governor came with the lead piping.
Re-examined. I am sure he told me to sign a receipt with a false name.

GEORGE MITCHELL . I live at Horace Road, Forest Gate, and am shop assistant to Young and Martin, a business carried on by Mr. Harry Holditch Martin, who trades in that nameâ€”on Tuesday, 13th October, about one o'clock, Stinton brought this order for a blowlampâ€”Sims had been our customer for many yearsâ€”I did not let Stinton have anything, but he was detained and taken to the stationâ€”I do not know the prisonerâ€”I gave the note to our manager.

JOHN SIMS . I am a builder, at Wentworth Road, Manor Parkâ€”I have been in the habit of dealing with Harry Holditch Martin, and have an account with himâ€”the prisoner worked for me for four months last year as a labourer, at fivepence an hourâ€”he left about July, 1890; I know nothing of his doings or whereabouts sinceâ€”I did not write this order, nor authorise it to be writtenâ€”I did not send him for the articlesâ€”during the time he worked for me I sent him occasionally for things, and he knew he had to sign for what I had from Martinâ€”he had no authority from me to get the blowlamp.
By the JURY. I give orders on pieces of paper of this description when I give them.

ARTHUR FRENCH . I am getting on for fourteenâ€”I live at 181, Vicarage Lane, West Hamâ€”I stand outside Young and Martin's, and hold horsesâ€”on 1st October the prisoner brought me this piece of paper and asked if I would mind taking a note into Young and Martin'sâ€”he said when I got the article I was to take it back to him; he would be round by the County Bank, in Romford Roadâ€”he told me to sign the name of W. Brown. (The note was: "Gentlemen, please let the bearer have a small tenon saw if you have one")â€”he said I was to have a penny if I brought the sawâ€”I was about three doors from Martin's at the timeâ€”I went to Martin's shop, gave the order and got the saw, and signed a receipt in my own name, A. French, because the shopman told me to do soâ€”I met the prisoner outside the County Bank, and gave him the

saw and left himâ€”he went by the bankâ€”I told him I had signed my own name; I told him my nameâ€”he said it was all rightâ€”on 8th October, about noon, I saw him near St. John's Church; he crossed from the church to the Coach and Horses, and whistled to me; and then asked me if I minded taking this note to Young and Martin's. (This was: "Please send by bearer one oz. stock brush; please wrap it up to stop boy playing with it; ten or twelve oz. will suitâ€”J. SIMS, Manor Park")â€”he told me to meet him at the County Bank againâ€”I was to have a pennyâ€”I took the order to Martin's, and gave it to Sutton thereâ€”he gave me a brushâ€”I signed my own name for itâ€”I brought the brush in paper to the prisoner at the bankâ€”next day I saw the prisoner again, and he gave me this note in the Broadway, Stratford. (This was: "Please let bearer have two pairs of tinmen's snips and a small screw hammer")â€”he asked me to take that into Young and Martin's, upstairsâ€”I did so; I had a con
versation with a gentleman upstairs, as the result of which I went back to the prisoner, a gentleman from Martin's following behind meâ€”I told the prisoner a gentleman wanted to see him, and that they would not let me have the goods, and he walked away quickly, saying he was going to see his masterâ€”he did not say who his master wasâ€”I next saw him at the station, where I picked him out.

ROBERT MARLEY . I live at Great Eastern Street, and am employed at Young and Martin'sâ€”on 1st October French brought me this order, which I took as being from Mr. Sims, and I supplied him with the saw, and he signed this noteâ€”ours is an open shop, with show-rooms up
stairs.

WILLIAM SUTTON . I live at Warkwick Road, Romford Road, and am employed by Mr. Martinâ€”on 8th October French came with this note; in accordance with it I wrapped up a brush in paper, and he signed this receipt, and took the brush away.

HENRY CASHMAN . I live at 21, Prospect Road, Walthamstow, and am salesman to Young and Martin, on the first floor, where people would be sent to for small screw-hammers and tinmen's snipsâ€”a little boy came there with this orderâ€”I did not let him have the goodsâ€”I followed him, and saw him speak to the prisonerâ€”I was a hundred yards away, with a churchyard in front of me; I could see through the railingsâ€”the prisoner went away fast, I followed; he turned and caught sight of me, and he suddenly got out of my sightâ€”on the 13th, when Stinton came, I detained him and fetched a constable, and afterwards saw him with the prisonerâ€”I picked the prisoner out from among others at the station.
Cross-examined. On the 8th October you turned and apparently saw me, because you dodged away directly, and I lost sight of you.
Re-examined. The boy spoke to him before he went away quickly.
JOHN SIMS (Re-examined). These three other orders were not written by me nor with my authority.

FREDERICK FORTH (Detective Sergeant). Shortly after noon on 13th October I saw the prisoner in a passage in the Grove, Stratford, looking in the direction of Young and Martin's shop, which he could see from where he wasâ€”French had given me a description of himâ€”I went up and said to the prisoner, "I am a police constable; I shall take you into custody for uttering forged orders, and obtaining goods from

Messrs. Young and Martin"â€”the prisoner said, "It is hunger that has made me do it"â€”I arrested himâ€”as to a statement he made, he has given me no description of a man, nor asked me to make inquiries, nor procured any witness.

Cross-examined. I did not hear you give a description of a man about your height and with side whiskers; I heard you speaking to Mr. Sims, but I did not hear what it wasâ€”you did not say you had seen the man in the next turning to Abbey Lane; I did not put it down in my pocket-book.
Re-examined. Except for the prisoner's statement, I have no knowledge of the supposed person meeting him four times.
JOHN SIMS (Re-examined). I know of no man that sent the prisoner for these things; he has never asked me to bring anyone hereâ€”all the men in my employment have been with me for about two months.

By the COURT. When he was in the hands of the police he said to me, "This is a bad job, Mr. Sims"â€”I said, "You ought to have known better than to do such a thing"â€”he said, "A man sent me with these orders"â€”I asked him what manâ€”he said, "Some man that said he was at work for you"â€”I said, "What is his name?"â€”he said, "I don't know; I don't know where he lives."

By the prisoner. You did not say, "He told me not to tell my brother he did work on his own account, as if it got to your ears you would dis
charge him."

The prisoner's statement before the Magistrate: "I have been sent by another party with these notes, being known by Mr. Sims, and being promised work by this other man who sent me, and his telling me that if Mr. Sims knew he had work on his own hook he would most likely sack him."

GUILTY
of uttering â€”
Nine Months' Hard Labour.

857.
WILLIAM TOMLINSON (26) and
HENRY TOMLINSON (18),
Unlawfully obtaining from
Emily and
William Stokes 5s. 6d. by false pretences, with intent to defraud; and other sums from other persons, with a like intent; William Tomlinson having been convicted of felony in August, 1889, to which William Tomlinson
PLEADED GUILTY .*

After MR. LAWLESS had opened the case the prosecution, Henry Tom
linson expressed his desire to PLEAD GUILTY, thereupon the JURY found him
GUILTY â€”
Six Month's Hard Labour.
WILLIAM TOMLINSONâ€”
Twelve Months' Hard Labour.

858.
SUCCI (17)
, Burglary in the dwelling-house of
George Cundy, with intent to steal therein.

p.hi: Prosecuted, and the evidence was interpreted to the prisoner.

div1.p: HENRY COOPER (Detective Sergeant). On 27th September, at 11.45 p.m., I was secreted with Willett in the Prince of Wales public-house, Prince Regent Lane, in consequence of a communication made to me by Mr. Cundy; we heard a crash of glass and saw the form of a man at the back window which leads from the yard into the barâ€”I saw the man take off his coat, put it over his hands and break out the glass bit by bit, then he put his coat on and buttoned it up, procured a ladder, and placed it through the broken pane into the barâ€”he withdrew the ladder,

and placed a plank there which went more perpendicularly into the barâ€”he got down the plank into the bar, came to the counter, lifted the flap, passed through inside the bar past me, and turned to the left to the tillâ€”I lifted up another flap and jumped on to his backâ€”he shouted out in English, "Oh! oh! don't hurt me, don't hurt me!"â€”I took him by the scruff of the neck and kept him till Mr. Cundy, whom we aroused, came down with a lightâ€”Mr. Cundy found the prisoner's boots in my presence, he had none on thenâ€”Willett was with me all the time, and went to the station with me and himâ€”the window does not openâ€”the public-house closes at ten, and we were locked in in front of the bar.
JOHN WILLETT (K 585). I was watching with Cooperâ€”I have heard his evidence; it is true.

JOHN GEORGE CUNDY . I keep the Prince of Wales public-house, Prince Regent Laneâ€”on this night I was aroused just before twelve by Cooper and Willettâ€”I found the prisoner in custodyâ€”I asked where his boots were; he said on the top of the house on the leadsâ€”I got a ladder and found them; I asked if they were his, and he said they were, and put them onâ€”he talks English perfectly well; I was conversing with him for five minutes.
The prisoner. I approve of all the witnesses say; it is true.

GUILTY â€”
Eight Months' Hard Labour.

859.
HENRY ROBINSON, Unlawfully
attempting to procure the commission of an act of gross indecency by
John Judd.

p.hi: The prisoner received a good character.

div1.p: NOT GUILTY .

860.
ALFRED DOLBY (30)
, Unlawfully and carnally knowing
Pris
cilla Cushion, a girl under sixteen.

The Prisoner, in the hearing of the Jury, said that he desired to PLEAD GUILTY, and thereupon the Jury found him
GUILTY .â€”
Discharged on recog
nisances.

861.
ESTHER POLLARD,
RHODA BROWN , and
JOHN POLLARD, Stealing
a pair of boots and other articles, the property of
Martha Gill.

MARTHA GILL . I am a widow, living at 26, Mallam Road, Forest Hillâ€”the two female prisoners and Brown's mother have occupied two rooms thereâ€”no one but they and I have lived thereâ€”I had no servants; I am a laundress, and Esther Pollard and Brown worked for meâ€”Brown has carried on the work for me since Christmas at three shillings a dayâ€”they had been into my roomsâ€”on 23rd September I went away, after locking up my rooms and boxes in them containing propertyâ€”on 10th October I came back and found the doors unlocked, the boxes open, and things had been taken outâ€”my drawers and a large chest were all stripped; my own,

my daughter's, and children's clothes were takenâ€”a pair of boots that were missing I afterwards saw at Mr. Barstow's pawnshop; I have seen some of my sheets, two tablecloths, two counterpanes, and some underlinen at Mr. Chard's, a pawnbroker at Forest Hillâ€”the constable showed me other of my property at Sydenham Stationâ€”the female prisoners were locked up when I came home; I was sent forâ€”before I went I instructed them to carry on my business in the laundry and wash-house, and not to enter my roomsâ€”their key would not fit my door when I left, because I tried itâ€”this (produced) is the key of my room.

Cross-examined by MR. WARBURTON. This is my parlour keyâ€”Brown and her mother have lived with me for four years; Mrs. Pollard came on 19th Juneâ€”I was their landladyâ€”Brown paid me rent, and I deducted Mrs. Pollard's rent from the amount I paid her for workâ€”I asked them to look after my house and business, but they were not to go into my private rooms, which I locked upâ€”I left the laundry, washhouse, and where the work was done unlockedâ€”these boots were my son-in-law's; he died in June.
Re-examined. I recognise these bootsâ€”I identified the property at the Court belowâ€”these are my counterpanes, tablecloths, and cloak.

CATHERINE BROWN . I have lived for six years at 26, Mallam Road, and am Rhoda Brown's motherâ€”on 23rd September Mrs. Gill went awayâ€”on 8th October the male prisoner came to the house in the night, or early in the morningâ€”I had not seen him there before; I had heard a man go into the house before when we were in bedâ€”about two or three in the morning I and my daughter were asleep, and I heard a man knock at the door, and I heard a man come inâ€”in the morning, about nine o'clock, I saw John Pollard go out, carrying two large bundlesâ€”Esther Pollard, his mother, followed him with a little hamper basket, and my daughter was going to see him off by trainâ€”I said, "There is some
thing wrong; you have got something there belonging to Mrs. Gill"â€”Esther Pollard said, "I am off, good-bye; it is my own"â€”the man did not hear me speak; he was ahead of his motherâ€”soon after they had gone I went to Forest Hill Railway Stationâ€”just before I got there I saw the prisoners; John had no bundles then, Esther had the hamper basketâ€”in the booking office at the station I saw two large bundles; one was wrapped in Mrs. Gill's green cover, which I had carried over many baskets of clothesâ€”my daughter only saw the prisoners off by the trainâ€”I went and gave some information to the police.

Cross-examined by Esther Pollard. I said to you, "Your son is taking things away not belonging to you"â€”you said to me at the end of the week, "Take my two sheets and get 2s. on them, and when the washing comes home we will take them out again," I pawned two of Mrs. Gill's sheets, and you had 1s. and my daughter had 1s.â€”when I took the washing home my daughter gave you back 1s. towards redeeming the sheetsâ€”you had some things as well as Mrs. Gill, and you said these sheets were yoursâ€”you are the cause of this troubleâ€”I did not know my daughter knew anything of what was in the bundles.

Cross-examined by MR. WARBURTON. I believe I said before the Magistrate that I accused her of having stolen the property. (This did not appear in the depositions.)â€”I was told to answer the questions put to meâ€”my daughter went with them to see them off by train, and said she would not be long before she was backâ€”the railway station is about ten

minutes' walk from where I lodgedâ€”there were not a great many people about at that timeâ€”it is a main roadâ€”not many gentlemen go from our part to the trains; poor people live thereâ€”the parcels were in the booking officeâ€”there were not many people about thenâ€”John Pollard carried two bundles tied together, and his mother carried a hamper.
Re-examined. Mrs. Pollard had the pawnticket for the sheets; I did not know they were Mrs. Gill's at the time; I have found it out since.

CHARLES BURSTOW . I am a pawnbroker, at 53 and 55, High Street, Sydenhamâ€”this pair of boots were pledged with me for 3s. on 21st September by Ann Pollard, Willow Walkâ€”she is the male prisoner's wife, I believe; she is not here nowâ€”I know the female prisoner by sightâ€”this is the counterpart.

Cross-examined by MR. WARBURTON. My shop is a quarter of an hour or twenty minutes from Forest Hillâ€”I know the neighbourhood where Mrs. Gill livedâ€”it is a big streetâ€”about nine o'clock I should think some hundreds of gentlemen go to the City, and people are about in the street; people stealing would run a risk of being seen by a great many peopleâ€”there are workmen's trains as early as five o'clock in the morning, I think.

GEORGE HART . I am assistant to William Chard, a pawnbroker of 8, Devonshire Street, Forest Hillâ€”these two sheets were pawned with me on 26th September, for 2s., in the name of Ann Pollard; I do not know who byâ€”this is the counterpartâ€”I also produce a child's cloak, a sheet, a tablecloth, counterpane, and children's things, all pledged on 7th October by Jane Reynolds, 3, Newart's Road; and a counterpane on the same date for 2s. 6d., by Jane Brown, of 40, Newart's Road; and a child's cloak for 2s.â€”the two female prisoners came together and pledged those last three parcels.
Esther Pollard. "I pledged one parcel."
Rhoda Brown. "I pledged one."

ROBERT GOWER (P 542). On 8th October I saw the female prisoners near the railway station, and watched them for about three hoursâ€”I stopped them on the station platform, and took them into custodyâ€”Esther Pollard had a basket about twelve inches by nine inches, in which I found five pawntickets, some of which I produce.

FREDERICK BUNTING (Detective Sergeant P). On Sunday, 11th Oc
tober, I went to Mrs. Gill's houseâ€”I found in the door of Esther Pol
lard's room this key, which unlocks the prosecutrix's front and back room; it had been filed downâ€”it also unlocked Mrs. Pollard's doorâ€”on 12th October, at midnight, I went to 51, Willow Walk, where I saw John Pollard, and took him into custody on this chargeâ€”he said, "I did not expect you this time at night; can I have bail?"â€”I took him to the station, where he was detainedâ€”I found on him a pawnticket for a pair of boots; the duplicate has been produced by Mr. Burstowâ€”the prisoner threw it on the bed at meâ€”I had not asked anything about pawntickets.

Cross-examined by MR. WARBURTON. The prisoner has been living there with his wife for a long timeâ€”he is quite a respectable manâ€”his mother had been arrested three days beforeâ€”he made no attempt to get away that I know ofâ€”his mother lived about half a mile off himâ€”he gave up the pawnticket without my asking for it.

The prisoners' statements before the Magistrate. Esther Pollard says: "Mrs. Brown pawned seven sheets, produced to-day, and we shared the money; the other four pawntickets are my own." Rhoda Brown says: "Mrs. Pollard has just told the truth about the sheets."

Esther Pollard, in her defence, stated that Mrs. Gill had left them to do work, and had given them no money, and that she had pawned things to get food. Brown said that she had lost her purse with 23s. in it, and that she pawned these things to carry her on during the week, with the intention of getting them out again, and with no intention of stealing them.

John Pollard received a good character.â€”
NOT GUILTY .

ESTHER POLLARD and BROWNâ€”
GUILTY . ESTHER POL
LARDâ€”
Eight Months' Hard Labour.
BROWNâ€”
Four Months' Hard Labour.

862.
ESTHER POLLARD,
RHODA BROWN , and
JOHN POL
LARD were again indicted for
stealing a watch, a suit of clothes, and other articles of
Martha Gill, in her dwelling-house.
No evidence was offered against John Pollard â€”
NOT GUILTY .

863.
CHARLES FLUTTER (24) and
ROSINA FLUTTER (19) were indicted for
the manslaughter of
Charles William Lawrence.

GEORGE FREDERICK ROUMIEU . I am Coroner for West Surreyâ€”on 4th August I held an inquiry into the death of Charles William Lawrenceâ€”the prisoner, Rosina Flutter, was present in Court: she was duly sworn, aad made a statement, and on the 7th she also gave evidenceâ€”these are my original depositions; they were sworn before meâ€”the inquiry was adjourned from the 4th to the 7th, and Rosina then made a further statement on oath. (The deposition of Rosina Flutter on 4th August was read, as follows:â€”"I am the wife of Charles Flutter, living at Stoughton Lane, Stoke; the deceased was my son, aged four months; he died on Saturday, August 1st, three weeks ago last Saturday; I had the child in my arms, he fell out and pitched on the back of his head on the boards; he did not bleed. I did not notice anything on his head till a day or two afterwards, when I saw a lump on the side of his head; it got worse; I did not notice any discoloration. At eight p.m. on Satur
day I put it in the perambulator; I noticed it was dying soon after
wards. I told my sister Alice about the child falling, not my husband till later on. I did not go out on Saturday night and leave the child in bed. Mrs. Harding gave me notice, I do not know why; she did not tell me. When the child was dead, I sent for Mrs. Shollick. I gave it milk on Saturday, it did not have anything else; it had bread and milk on Friday, half a teacupful of milk and small slice of bread, the same as supper; I gave it milk during the night; it was restless. My husband did not return till nine at night"â€”Further examination on Friday, 7th

Augustâ€”"I wish to correct the evidence I gave on the last occasion. I did not let the baby fall, the cause of the injury was by my husband hitting it three weeks last Saturday. No one else was in the house when I returned. I found the child upstairs dressed. Then I noticed a large bump on the head. I asked my husband if he had hit the baby; he made no answer, he was the worse for liquor. He said, "I did not think I hit it so hard.' I had no further conversation with him about it. I told the tale about the perambulator to screen my husband, he told me to say so." (MR. JUSTICE WRIGHT interposed, and considered that this latter statement was not receivable as evidence against the male prisoner. MR. TORR adduced it as evidence against the female prisoner herself. MR. JUSTICE WRIGHT was of opinion that it was not desirable to go on upon the second statement, but to confine it to the first.)

ERNEST MORSEY . I am a M.R.C.S., practising at Guildfordâ€”on 4th August I made a post-mortem examination of the baby of the two prisoners; it was apparently about five months oldâ€”I weighed itâ€”the normal weight of a child five months old, properly nourished, would be about eleven lbs.; this baby weighed seven and three-quarters lbs.â€”it was not particularly small, not a dwarf, the length of the body was twenty-three inchesâ€”externally I found a brown discoloration on the forehead on the right sideâ€”above the right ear I found a dark-coloured lumpâ€”there was a small scar on the outside of the left elbow, about a quarter of an inch in diameter; these were all the external appearancesâ€”the child was very thinâ€”I found a fracture of the skull on the right side of the head, corresponding to the lungs, also ulcera
tion of the brain with adhesion of the membranesâ€”that was sufficient to cause deathâ€”in my opinion the injury to the brain was the cause of death; the other organs of the body were healthy, subject to the emaciationâ€”there was a little liquid in the stomachâ€”there was nothing in the appearance of the internal organs sufficient to cause deathâ€”if medical aid had been provided in time probably death might have been preventedâ€”I cannot speak positively as to that, but probably life might have been saved.
Cross-examined by Rosina Flutter. There was no bruise on the child's chest.

SARAH BROWN . I am the wife of William Brown, a labourer, of Stoke, near Guildfordâ€”on 1st August, at ten minutes past eleven, I was called to Mrs. Flutter's house in Stoughton Roadâ€”I saw the baby lying on the perambulator on its left side; its eyes and mouth just movedâ€”I said, "The baby is dead;" I saw a large lump on its ear, and I said, "What is this on the baby's head, Mrs. Flutter?"â€”she said, "I let it drop off my arm three weeks ago to-day"â€”I said, "Have you had any medical aid?"â€”she said, "No"â€”I said, "It is a very bad job for you; you will get into great trouble because of it"â€”I told her to send for someone, and went awayâ€”I did not touch the baby; I only looked at itâ€”the same day, after the police had seen it, I washed it and laid it out; it was dreadfully dirtyâ€”I noticed vermin on its clothesâ€”besides the bruise on the head, I saw a mark on the left elbow about the size of a shilling.
JANE HARDING . I am the wife of James Harding, and live in Avenue Terrace Stokeâ€”the prisoners lodged with me about two months from the 22nd April lastâ€”on a Saturday night, about three weeks after

they came there, the female prisoner went out for a short time, leaving the baby in charge of her husbandâ€”after she had gone out I heard the baby crying upstairsâ€”I called to the father to bring it down to meâ€”he came down with it, and gave it to me at the bottom of the stairsâ€”I did not notice anything about the baby till my husband got a lightâ€”then I noticed that it was injured; its eye was hurt, and it was bleeding at the mouthâ€”during the time the prisoners lodged with me the mother did not treat the child wellâ€”as a rule she looked after itâ€”I had several times cautioned her in consequence of the way she treated the child.
Charles Flutter. There was no sign of injury to the child when you took it from me. Witness. Yes there was.

JAMES HARDING . I am the husband of the last witnessâ€”I remember the prisoners coming to lodge with usâ€”about a fortnight or three weeks after they came, I remember the female prisoner going out and leaving the baby with her husbandâ€”I heard the baby cry, and while he was trying to pacify it I heard him say, "You young b----, I will kill you" my wife came in just at the time, and she said, "Charles, bring the baby down here and see if I can pacify it"â€”the baby was very illtreated while they were there, in respect of cleanliness and feeding, and such as that.
Charles Flutter. I did not say so. Witness. He did, I heard it.

By the JURY. The prisoner owes me four shillings rentâ€”he was upstairs when I heard him use that expression; I was downstairs in my own room, my door was not closedâ€”I am deaf, but I heard what he said.

ELLEN LOUISA BAKER . I am the wife of Thomas Baker, of Besley Cottage, Stokeâ€”I know the female prisoner, not the manâ€”on a Tuesday in July I remember going into the Priory Tap, in North Street, Guildfordâ€”I saw the female there with the baby; also a Mrs. Goodallâ€”the baby was lying in the perambulator crying; it was covered upâ€”I asked her to unwrap the baby, as it was crying soâ€”the prisoner said, "Oh, let the little b----lie"â€”Mrs. Goodall uncovered it, and it was in a heat of sweatâ€”Mrs. Goodall told her if she did not see to the baby it would be smotheredâ€”she said she should not care if the little b----was smotheredâ€”I said, "You ought to be ashamed of yourself"â€”she said, "Oh, a b----bastard like that; if I had my will I would smother all such little b----bastards like that"â€”I said, "Why did you have a little bastard then if you don't like it?"â€”I saw her again on the 30th July, at her houseâ€”I saw the baby, and had it in my lapâ€”I noticed two bruises, one on each side of the forehead, and a lump on the right side of the headâ€”I asked her what marks they wereâ€”she said, "Oh, birthmarks"â€”I said, "Birthmarks?"â€”she said, "Yes"â€”I said, "I should not like such marks as that on my baby's head"â€”I told her to take the baby to the doctorâ€”she said, "I am going to the doctor's this afternoon"; she said her husband persuaded her to take it to the doctorâ€”this conversation took place about ten or eleven in the morningâ€”I saw her again the same evening, I asked her if she had taken the baby to the doctorâ€”she said, "No"; but she had told her husband that she had taken it to the doctor's.
Rosina Flutter. What I told you was that I would tell my husband to take it to the doctor's. Witness. No, you said you told him that you had taken it to the doctor's.

CHARLES WALTER BAKER .â€”I am Deputy Chief Constable of Surreyâ€”on 7th August a communication was made to me about the female pri
soner, in consequence of which I saw herâ€”she was not in custodyâ€”she said she wished to tell the truth, as she did not last Tuesday when before the Coronerâ€”her husband was not presentâ€”I cautioned herâ€”she then made a statement; I did not take it down in writingâ€”afterwards I saw the husband, he was standing a short distance awayâ€”I repeated to him the statement his wife had made to meâ€”when she began to make the statement I stopped her, warned her, and told her the nature of itâ€”she then said, "It was my husband that caused the blow on the child's head"â€”I don't think he could hear what she said at first, he was too far away, but I repeated her statement to him; it was this, that she stated before the Coroner that she had let the child fall and caused the blow on its head, "but I never did let it fall; it was my husband that struck the child on its head with his hand which caused the blow, three weeks ago last Saturday"â€”the male prisoner said, "I have struck the child, but it was when I was in drink"â€”I think that was all he said.
Charles Flutter. I did not say so, but I can't properly recollect that I did hit the child.

ALICE GOODALL . I was at the Priory Tap in North Street, Guildford, on a Tuesday in July, when Mrs. Baker was thereâ€”the baby was crying, and I said to the female prisoner, "Rose, go and see to the baby"â€”she would not, and I went and uncovered the baby, and it was in one beat of sweatâ€”she said she wished all the little b----bastards were smotheredâ€”on 10th July she brought the child to my kitchen in a bassinette, and went into the garden picking fruit; I called her in and said, "Rose, will you come in and see to this dear little baby?"â€”she said, "No, I won't"â€”I went to it and found the bottle and changed it, the skin and all came with it; I spoke to her about it, and she said she wished all the little b----s were dead and out of the way.

By the COURT. I have not had any quarrel with herâ€”I never said a word only when I found the baby like this; I said she should not enter my house any more, because she did not properly look after the baby.

AMELIA SEARLE . I live in the same road as the prisonersâ€”in July I went to help the female prisoner clean up her houseâ€”the baby was thereâ€”she beat it so in the chest that it could not cry, she beat it to make it cryâ€”I did not say anything to her about the baby; I don't remember her saying anything to me about itâ€”on the same day I saw her knock it about in Mr. Collins' houseâ€”I said to her, "Rose, you will get yourself into trouble"â€”she said. "I don't care if I get six months, I can do that," and she took it by its arms and said, "You little b----I will break your little b----neck."

Rosina Flutter. You did not see me knock the breath out of my child. Witness. Yes, you did; you hit it in the chest, and shut it up in the perambulator; you did not say, "If they give me six months through it I shall do it innocently"â€”it is the truth I am sayingâ€”we have never had any quarrel.

CHARLES FLUTTER,
GUILTY â€”
Three Years' Penal Servitude.
ROSINA FLUTTER,
GUILTY â€”
Twelve Months' Hard Labour.

864.
JAMES HARRIS (53)
, Feloniously setting fire to a stack of corn, the goods of
James Weller.

JAMES WELLER . I am a baker, residing at Shere, Surreyâ€”on 13th September, between 9.30 and 9.35, I received information as to a fireâ€”I went to a rick of oats and found it on fireâ€”it was partly destroyed when I got thereâ€”its value was Â£50 or Â£60â€”I know the prisoner as having resided in Shereâ€”he had done odd jobs for meâ€”some time ago he called me all the f----g things he could put his tongue to, and told me to go and play with----and all sorts of thingsâ€”that was about six weeks before the fireâ€”he used abusive expressions towards me in the streetâ€”he gave no reason for itâ€”he said I would sooner employ foreigners than I would natives; if I gave him employment he would not do it.

Cross-examined. I fixed the time of the fire as near as I could guessâ€”I went into the White Horse, Shere, about 9.30, and I had not been there five minutes when information of the fire cameâ€”I had a watch in my pocketâ€”I looked at itâ€”I saw it was 9.35, or a little laterâ€”I rent the field the stack stands inâ€”there is a right-of-way through it within twelve yards of the stackâ€”the villagers don't go there a good dealâ€”I go there between the lights, because I have some pigs there and I go to feed themâ€”I do not know that a man refused to help to put the fire outâ€”I swear that-a man lay there tight, but I found out that man was not there at the time of the fireâ€”he was in the village when the fire broke outâ€”"tight" is the Shere for "drunk."

EDWARD EVANS . I am a labourer, living at Shereâ€”I know the pri
sonerâ€”on Sunday, 13th September, I was in the Prince of Wales public-house, in Shereâ€”the prisoner was in my companyâ€”he left about 9.30â€”I know where the rick wasâ€”about three minutes' walk from the Prince of Walesâ€”I left about 9.45â€”I did not see the prisoner again that nightâ€”we had conversed at the Prince of Wales about a summonsâ€”that was a month before this job happenedâ€”the prisoner was bringing up what Weller had doneâ€”he said it was a bit of spiteâ€”he gave Weller a very bad character, and said he ought to be made pay for the sum
monsâ€”I had to pay a sovereignâ€”I was summoned, and the prisoner said Weller ought to have paid it instead of me, and that he ought to be hung.

Cross-examined. The prisoner did not say anything about this sum
mons on the night of the fireâ€”he was sympathising with meâ€”I was fined a sovereignâ€”after paying the sovereign the prisoner began about enemies, and brought Weller inâ€”he thought I was ill-treated, and Weller ought to payâ€”a good many people thought soâ€”I had not said soâ€”I thought soâ€”they like him very well in the village, but not people who work for him; he can only give them about a fortnight's work, and cannot pay them more than half-a-crown a day; I have no fault to find with Wellerâ€”they who work for him give him a very bad name; he won't find them enough work, only a week or a fortnight; he keeps a bit of a farm and beats a man down; they don't like him because he won't find them longer work; I cannot think what it is forâ€”I was in the Prince of Wales the night before the fire from 6 till 9.30â€”the prisoner sat with me all the evening running my character down, and said Weller
ought to be made to pay the fineâ€”he had been drinkingâ€”I know where he livesâ€”his way home lies across a bit of waterâ€”a short time ago he was ducked in the stream by some boys.

Re-examined. I was up before the Magistrate because they said I was drunkâ€”Weller had nothing to do with it, only the man working for him, supposed to be his sonâ€”that was the reason Weller was to pay the fineâ€”this man works in a baker's shop on his premises.

FREDERICK PARSONS . I keep the Prince of Wales beer-house, Shereâ€”on Sunday, 13th September, I saw the prisoner thereâ€”he left at 9.25; he had been in the house about two and a half hoursâ€”a quarter of an hour after I heard an alarm of fireâ€”I know where the prisoner lives; going out of the Prince of Wales you turn to the left, the Prince of Wales is on the right-hand side of the road going towards the stackâ€”the nearest way for him was past Dartnell's corner, pass a butcher's shop, turn left along the Lower Street, turn over a little wooden bridge, and go up to his houseâ€”in going from the Prince of Wales to the stack that was burnt you turn to the right, and when you get 300 yards you turn to the right, and the stack lies on your right-hand side just in the gateâ€”that would not be the direct way to his house, but quite the oppositeâ€”in going from the stack to the prisoner's house you pass the Prince of Wales; that would be going through the recreation-groundâ€”that is what we call the allotment fieldâ€”then you go through the lime walks and over the same bridge, as it would be the other way.

Cross-examined. He could get that wayâ€”the nearest way from the Prince of Wales to the prisoner's house would be across a streamâ€”there is no clock in the tap-roomâ€”the prisoner did not come at six o'clock in the evening; I never noticed exactlyâ€”I would not contradict Evans, because I am not sure.

WILLIAM FINCH . I was a policemanâ€”this plan (produced) is drawn from the Ordnance mapâ€”I know the district perfectly wellâ€”I have lived there thirteen yearsâ€”I know the Prince of Wales, where the prisoner resides, and where the stack was burntâ€”this plan accurately represents the localityâ€”going from the Prince of Wales the prisoner's proper way would be to the leftâ€”that would be the shortest wayâ€”taking the direction where the stack was burnt he would turn to the right coming from the Prince of Walesâ€”turning to the right, he would not pass Dartnell's corner, but would go a considerably roundabout way to his homeâ€”he would go about 400 yards furtherâ€”that would be out of a distance of about a quarter of a mileâ€”nearly twice as farâ€”the turning to the right where the fire was leads to Shere Heath, that is a footpathâ€”I went with Sergeant Hatton on 14th September, at 7 a.m., to the prisoner's residence at Shereâ€”we asked the prisoner to account for where he was on the previous night; he said he was drunk at the Prince of Wales, that he left there and came home by Dartnell's corner, and was indoors about eight; he might have met some one, but had no recol
lection of itâ€”Dartnell's corner would bring him into the Lower Streetâ€”I am quite sure of thatâ€”that would be his shortest way home.

Cross-examined. We asked him whether he had met anyoneâ€”his recol
lection was not hazy, he was perfectly "solid" and sober that morningâ€”he spoke in his ordinary mannerâ€”his recollection was not accurate of what took place the night beforeâ€”the prisoner is somewhat unpopular in the neighbourhoodâ€”it was reported in the paper that two men refused
to help to put it outâ€”I do not believe all the papers sayâ€”I believe that is perfectly true.

WILLIAM HARRIS . I am a carpenter, living at Shereâ€”on Sunday, 13th September, about 9.30 p.m., I was between sixty and seventy yards from where the stack was burnt down before it was burntâ€”I was going in the direction of the Prince of Walesâ€”I met the prisoner going the other wayâ€”he would have to turn up another road to get to the stackâ€”he was going in that directionâ€”I was coming from Gomshallâ€”to go to the stack he would either go round the road, making about twenty yards difference, or go over the bank in about fifty yardsâ€”he would not have to turn back to go to the rickâ€”I said, "Good-night"â€”he stopped, but only said, "Good night"â€”in about ten minutes I heard a cry of fireâ€”in consequence of hearing the cry of fire I went back and saw the rick burningâ€”I heard the cry of fire at the Prince of Wales'sâ€”that is about two hundred yards from where I met the prisoner.

Cross-examined. If the prisoner had gone straight on the road it would have led him to Shere Heath Bridgeâ€”that would take him to where he lives if he went far enough roundâ€”he was going in the direction of the fire if he turned up the other roadâ€”I said before the Magistrate, "He stopped and said something, I did not know what it was"â€”he said something, I could hardly hearâ€”it was not very distinctâ€”I do not know if he was under the influence of drinkâ€”he is sometimes.

ALFRED ARNOLD . I am a gardener, and live at Shereâ€”I am in the service of the Duke of Northumberlandâ€”on 13th September I was at the corner of Albury Park, between 9.30 and 10 p.m.â€”in consequence of noticing a fire I went towards itâ€”I went along the allotment fieldâ€”I met the prisoner in the footpath in the allotment field, about 200 or 300 yards from the fire, about half an hour after noticing the fireâ€”I asked him where the fire wasâ€”he said something I could not understandâ€”I said, "That's you, Shake; I know you, Shake"â€”he said something, I did not hear whatâ€”Shake is his nicknameâ€”after I saw him I went on to the fireâ€”the fire was not on the way from the Prince of Wales to his house.
Cross-examined. It was after 9.30 when I saw the prisonerâ€”I cannot fix the time definitelyâ€”he spoke twice, but I could not understand what he said.

WILLIAM HATTON (Sergeant Surrey Constabulary). I am stationed at Alburyâ€”I went with Finch to the prisoner's lodgings at 7 a.m. on 14th Septemberâ€”we asked the prisoner to account for where he was on the night of Sunday, the 13thâ€”he said, "I was at the Prince of Wales beer-house, and stopped there till 8 o'clock; I went home along the Lower Street, I do not remember meeting anyone"â€”I am quite sure he said the Lower Streetâ€”I went there in consequence of information receivedâ€”I questioned him because I suspected himâ€”I was instructed to do thatâ€”at four p.m. on the 14th I apprehended the prisoner in the highway at Shereâ€”I told him I should charge him on suspicion with setting fire to Mr. Weller's stack on the night of the 13thâ€”he replied, "I don't know more about it than what you do"â€”I took him to the Police-station; I found on him a match-box containing two matchesâ€”at 6.45 on the same evening I was present at the Police-station when the charge was readâ€”the prisoner said, in answer to the charge, "I was at the Prince of Wales beer-house; I left there about eight o'clock, and went straight home
by Dartnell's corner, and went to bed"â€”that is by the Lower Street; Dartnell's corner, which is followed by the Lower Street, would be his nearest way home.

Cross-examined. When I asked the prisoner to account for his time I was merely acting on suspicionâ€”I did not caution him; I was only making inquiriesâ€”I did not find the matches on him till a quarter to seven the day after the fireâ€”I believe he smokes, I am not certain.
The prisoner's statement before the Magistrate was: "I am quite innocent of the fire."
NOT GUILTY .

865.
WALTER NICHOLOSON
, for a rape on
Ellen Eastwood.
NOT GUILTY .

866.
JAMES BRAMLEY
(a soldier, 25), for a rape on
Annie Bright.
NOT GUILTY .

867.
WILLIAM ARCHER (41)
, for a rape on
Hannah Archer, the younger.

p.hi: Defended, at the request of the Court.

div1.p:
GUILTY â€”
Twenty Years' Penal Servitude.

868.
ARTHUR MAY, Unlawfully
and carnally knowing
Emma Wright, a girl fourteen years and six months, at Dorking.
NOT GUILTY .

869.
WILLIAM TAPPING, Rape
on
Louisa Elizabeth Smith, aged thirteen years.

GUILTY
of the attempt â€”
Twelve Months' Hard Labour.

870.
LUCY CLARISSA HOLLOWAY (35)
, Stealing a Gladstone bag, a suit of clothes, and other articles, of the
Great Western Railway Company; also
a tin box, two brooches, and other articles.

ROBERT HENRY DUNN . I am a wine merchant, and live at Wrexhamâ€”on Monday, 22nd June, I travelled from Wrexham to Paddington by the Great Western Railway, arriving there after fiveâ€”among my luggage I had a brown Gladstone bagâ€”this (produced) is itâ€”it contained clothes, shirts marked with my name, and other thingsâ€”I did not miss my bag at Paddington, but on arriving at the hotelâ€”I next saw it about three months after in the possession of the police at Wandsworth Police-stationâ€”I believe the contents were all there.

ROLEY CONNOLLY FAULKNER . I am in the Civil Service at the Straits Settlementsâ€”in July last I travelled by train from Plymouth to Padding
ton, arriving there at 6.30 p.m.â€”my luggage was all labelled at Ply
mouth for the cloak-room at Paddingtonâ€”I had a number of packages,

among them a tin box containing jewellery and wearing apparelâ€”at Paddington a porter took the luggage out of the vanâ€”I did not observe whether the tin box was put outâ€”I went to the cloak-room with the porter and the luggageâ€”I did not notice that the tin box was not with them; it had a canvas cover with straps roundâ€”next morning when I went to obtain the luggage I found the tin box was not thereâ€”I have not seen it since, or any of the contentsâ€”there was a ticket No. 53 on all the articles, that was put on at Plymouth; there was also another label on the box, "Cabin P. & O."
The Prisoner. I should like to know the date. Witness. 22nd July.

THOMAS DOWDELL . I am a porter in the service of the Great Western Railway Company at Paddington.â€”on 22nd July I was on duty at the Lost Property Office about seven p.m.â€”any luggage on the platform unclaimed is brought into the officeâ€”a tin box with a canvas cover was brought into the office as unclaimed luggage; I think the cover was drawn together by a stringâ€”it was labelled "Paddington"â€”it remained in the office till about half-past eight; the prisoner then came to claim itâ€”she had her hand resting on the box as it stood apartâ€”she said, "This is my box, I want a cab to take it away"â€”I said, "You must sign your name and address if it is your property"â€”she said yes, she was quite willing to sign for itâ€”I asked her what train the box had come byâ€”she said, "The train that arrived at 6.30"â€”I asked her what train she arrived byâ€”she said she had only just arrived; there was another train from the West of England in, within a few minutes' timeâ€”she signed the book, which I produce; I read it as "L. Mill, 9, Hunter Street"â€”she took the box awayâ€”next morning Mr. Faulkner came to claim his luggage, and he then complained of the loss of the tin boxâ€”I recalled the fact of the woman having been there the night before, and the book was examinedâ€”I next saw her at Wandsworth Police-court; I picked her out from a number of other women.
Cross-examined. The person who claimed the box was dressed as the person I saw at Wandsworth; it was on 22nd July, the same date as is in our book.

HOWARD HAWGOOD . I am an auctioneer at Aldershotâ€”on 23rd August I travelled from Aldershot to Waterloo by the South-Western Railwayâ€”I arrived at Waterloo about a quarter to ten p.m.â€”among my luggage I had a Gladstone bag; this is itâ€”on my arrival I went to the guard's van for my bag, and it was not thereâ€”I got to the van before any luggage was got outâ€”the bag contained a quantity of clothing, and three Â£5 Bank of England notesâ€”when I next saw it, it was in the possession of the railway policeâ€”a large part of the contents were still in it; there were a few things missing besides the notes and several papers and documents and a few articles of clothing; most of the things were in the bag.
Cross-examined. I could not give the numbers of the notes; there were missing two shirts, four silk handkerchiefs, two pairs of socks, and two fancy white waistcoats.

ABRAHAM GODFREY . I am a medical practitioner at Southamptonâ€”on 10th August my nephew was staying with me; he left on that day for London, taking a portmanteau with himâ€”he has left for Americaâ€”I recognise this Gladstone bagâ€”I identify it as my nephew's, it is marked
with his name; I also identify a pair of opera-glasses that were in the bag, and this photograph with his name written on the back in pencil.
Cross-examined. I have no idea whether the contents are right; I did not see the bag packed.

ANNIE HARRIS . I am a nurse employed at Ryde's Farm, West Clan
don, Surreyâ€”on 8th September I was travelling from Littlehampton by the London and Brighton Railway to Victoriaâ€”I had a tin box with meâ€”at Victoria it was missingâ€”I next saw it in the possession of the police at Wandsworthâ€”I missed from it Â£4 in gold, a gold brooch, and an apron with stripesâ€”this is the brooch with a horseshoe on it.

HENRY BROWN . I am cloak-room clerk at the Brighton Railway at Victoriaâ€”on 8th September I remember Miss Harris coming and com
plaining of the loss of her boxâ€”that same afternoon it had been put on an omnibus by mistake; next morning it came back to Victoria, there-upon I put a label on it and an address, and sent it off to Miss Harris at West Clandon that evening by Clapham Junctionâ€”this is the label in my writing.

JOHN REW . I am a guard in the service of the Brighton Railwayâ€”on 8th September, at 9.4, I had a tin box in my charge addressed to Miss Harris, West Clandon, with the label attached to itâ€”I put it out at Clapham Junction to go to West Clandon.

JOHN THORLEY (Police Sergeant V). In consequence of information I went on 10th September to 21, Hanbury Street, Lavender Hill, in com
pany with Constables Gill and Hopkins, with a search-warrantâ€”I saw the prisoner there in the first floor front roomâ€”I told her we were police officers, that I had a warrant to search the house, as I had reason to believe there was property there the part proceeds of larceniesâ€”I asked her who the property belonged to that was in the roomâ€”she said, "Everything here belongs me to with the exception of that tin box," pointing to the tin box which has been identified by Miss Harris; she said, "That was brought here by mistake for one that I left at Waterloo"â€”I asked her what was in itâ€”she said, "I don't know, I have not opened it"â€”on the bed alongside of the prisoner I saw a bundle of ladies' wearing apparelâ€”I asked who they belonged to; she said, "Well, they came out of that box"â€”I then saw a large bag, which has been identified by Mr. Hawgoodâ€”I asked how she accounted for thatâ€”she said, "That belongs to my adopted son, he went away some time ago, owing me a lot of money; he has since written to me to send his clothes to him, but I refused to do so until he sent me some money"â€”I then called her attention to the small Gladstone, identified by Mr. Godfrey, and asked her who that belonged toâ€”she said, "That be
longs to me, I have only just had it repaired"â€”I asked where it had been repaired, she then pointed along the edgesâ€”I could not notice it on the outside, but on the inside the canvas lining had been cut right through, it looks as if the bag had been cut open, it was empty; the property that is now in it I found in various parts of the roomâ€”the bag, identified by Mr. Hawgood, was not full; there was a bundle of clothes on the bed which were identified as likely to belong to Mr. Hawgoodâ€”in addition to these things I found a miscellaneous collection of articles, men's clothes, dresses, dress materials, and all kinds of thingsâ€”this brooch, identified by Miss Harris, I found among a number of articles in a little cupboard.
Cross-examined. I did not find the bags belonging to Mr. Hawgood and Mr. Dunn full of things and strapped up; some were on the bed and some in two different cupboards.

WALTER HOPKINS . I am one of the officers who went with the last witness to execute the search-warrantâ€”I found the bag, identified by Mr. Dunn, under the bed, with a number of other articles, baskets and bundles and everything you could mention; there was not room to put your head underâ€”in the cupboard I found this label, which was attached to Miss Harris's boxâ€”on 18th September, at Wandsworth Police-court, Miss Harris said, "I have got all but the Â£4 now"â€”the prisoner said, "The Â£4 that Miss Harris lost I have in my purse"â€”her purse had been examined on the 10th, and more than Â£4 was found in it.

Cross-examined. This was said in the gaoler's roomâ€”I did not say to you, "Can't you tell me the address of that man, where he is to be found?"â€”nor did you say, "He is nothing but an acquaintance, only a lodger"â€”I did not ask you where your purse was, nor did you say there were two rings in itâ€”I did not say, "If one was a wedding-ring and on your finger you could have had it"â€”you did not say I had no business with the purse, as it was not his moneyâ€”I did not whisper to you and ask where the man was.

MARTHA BRUCE . I rent the house, 21, Hanbury Roadâ€”the prisoner took my first floor front on 19th June; her daughter was with her, but she went away the same day; the prisoner was the only person occupy
ing the roomâ€”she brought a great deal of luggage with herâ€”on Thursday, 10th September, I heard her come in about half-past eleven at night, and I heard another footstepâ€”I heard a box dropped on the stairs, and the prisoner said, "Hush!"â€”next night she showed me an apron with stripes to it, and she said she had had a dozen made to go to service with as nurseâ€”I did not see any name on that one, but next day I saw two on the line, she had washed them, and they had the name of Annie Harris on themâ€”she said she had a dozen of linen and a dozen of cambric; these were cambricâ€”on the Saturday previous I gave her a piece of elastic to put round a case like this; I could not swear to it, I did not have it in my handâ€”my little boy said there was a Â£5 note in it, I did not see itâ€”she said she was going to change a Â£5 note, that was later on in the evening.
JOHN THORLEY (Re-examined). I first saw this case in the cupboard in the prisoner's room.

p.hi: The prisoner handed in a written defence, the purport of which was that six months ago she met a gentleman who claimed acquaintance with her, and came to lodge with her, and that the bags and articles found in her room were left there by him.

div1.p:
GUILTY â€”
Four Years' Penal Servitude.

871.
EMMA WICKHAM, Unlawfully
endeavouring to conceal the birth of her child.
MR. WILLSON, for the prosecution, offered no evidence.
NOT GUILTY .

872.
GEORGE RICHARDS (29)
, Unlawfully writing and publishing a defamatory label of and concerning
Henry Frisby.

GUILTY â€”
Discharged on his own recognisance, on the promise of not repeating the offence.

873.
ALFRED MARSHALL (44) and
ROBERT LEIGH (27)
, Steal
ing 1,875 watches, the property of the
South-Eastern Railway Company. Second Count, Feloniously receiving the same.
MARSHALL
PLEADED GUILTY to the Second Count.

JOSEPH TOWER . I am a checker in the employ of the South-Eastern Railway Company at London Bridge Stationâ€”on Monday, 24th August, early in the morning, a man named Tillard came to me and asked me for Stockwell's first lot of goodsâ€”I told him he would have to wait, and afterwards put forty-five packages on his cartâ€”he signed this delivery-sheet, "G. Jones,' in my presence and left.
Cross-examined. I could not tell from the appearance of the packages what they contained.

GEORGE TILLARD (In custody). I am a carmanâ€”I did not know the prisoner before thisâ€”a few days before August 24th Marshall spoke to me about bringing some things away from London Bridge Stationâ€”I got a van from Rayner's yard, and went and got these goods from Towerâ€”I afterwards went with Marshall again to Rayner's yard, and he took another van there and obtained some more goodsâ€”he drove one van in my companyâ€”we went to Lea Bridge Road and stopped at a villa there, where I saw somebody very like Leigh, but I am not positive of him.

Cross-examined. I was originally charged with taking part in this rob
bery, and while I was a prisoner I was suddenly put in the witness-box, and the charge against me withdrawnâ€”I am in custody now on another chargeâ€”whether it was Leigh or not who took part in the unloading he did not offer to pay me any moneyâ€”Marshall took the most prominent part in unloading the goods; the man who assisted him did not appear in a hurry, or frightened, or nervousâ€”it was about 9.30 a.m.

CAROLINE MCMINN . I live at 1, Blaskin Villas, Lea Bridge Road, Claptonâ€”the prisoner Leigh is my brother; he lives at the Tap House, Mile End, about two miles from meâ€”on Sunday, August 23rd, about seven p.m., he asked me if I would lend him the stable behind my house for some men to put some stuff inâ€”I told him Mr. Salmon had the key, and he leftâ€”he came again about eight o'clock next morning, and was there about an hour and a half or two hoursâ€”I saw a cart come into the road; he was there then, and I saw him talking to Marshall.

Cross-examined. That was about two hours after the cart came; he was having breakfast with me when the cart came inâ€”at that time he held the licence for the Compasses in Smart Street, Bethnal Green.
Re-examined. My brother was there when the cart came into the yard, and he went away and came back, and I saw him talking to Marshall.

FREDERICK WILLIAM SALMON . I live next door to Mrs. McMinnâ€”on August 24th I had permission to use her stable to put my bicycle inâ€”I was taking it out that day about eight a.m., and saw the prisoner Leighâ€”he said, "Good morning," and told me he should want the stable probably for a very short timeâ€”I left the key in the door.
Cross-examined. He said the goods would be cleared out in the course of the dayâ€”the stable is about fifty yards from the road.

WILLIAM THICK (Detective Sergeant H). On 24th August I received infor
mation about this robbery, between eleven and twelve oclock, and with other officers kept watch upon No. 1A, Glaskin Villas, Lea Bridge Road, Mrs. McMinn's house, all that afternoonâ€”I saw Leigh go into the house several times between four and six p.m.â€”I first saw him and Marshall about two o'clock togetherâ€”I went into the stable just before two o'clock the following morning, and found 1,875 gold and silver watches and forty-six packages of silk, furs, and embroideriesâ€”this board was there with a label on it, marked, "Flenner, 3,721" (produced)â€”these are probably foreign railway labelsâ€”I have some of the watches here, they were all in boxes similar to these; they had been taken out of the pack
ing cases, parts of which were there, and this is the lid of one of themâ€”they have been torn open by some instrument, not opened in the regular wayâ€”some of the silks were left in the cases, not unrolled, but piled up on top of the othersâ€”I remained there till 6.30 a.m., when the two prisoners came in togetherâ€”I said, "I am a police-officer, and so are the others with me; how do you account for the watches in the stable?"â€”Leigh said, "I know nothing about this man here," pointing to Marshall; "on Sunday night last he asked me to get a stable to plant some stuff"â€”I said, "Who are the other men?"â€”he said, "I don't know"â€”I said, "There has been a big jewel robbery at London Bridge, and I believe these to be part of the proceeds, and you will both be charged"â€”I handed them over to the other officers, and later in the day they were charged at Stone's Endâ€”the charge was read over to them, and they made no replyâ€”you can only see the roof of the stable from the road.

Cross-examined. Leigh made no reply to the chargeâ€”he had told my brother officer that he was waiting for a man named Jonesâ€”before a man gets a licence for a beer-house he must produce evidence of good characterâ€”I do not think he has been at the Tap House very longâ€”it is a very low neighbourhood; I believe he has always conducted it respectablyâ€”there is a glass door in the stable, but no window or stallsâ€”there is a wall; it is intended for a coach-house and stables, and there is a hole in the wall large enough for a man to get through; a sack hung over the hole, and those goods were beyond the wallâ€”a man going into the stable could not see the goodsâ€”I believe the van had a name on the shaft.

JOHN COLE (Detective Sergeant H). I arrested Marshall, and while we were detained Leigh said, "Wait"â€”I said, "What do you mean?"â€”he said, "If you wait a little longer you will get some more; there are more than us in it."

Cross-examined. I made this note of the conversation almost immediately I left the houseâ€”Leigh mentioned Jones' name to Sergeant Pearceâ€”I did not hear him say that the things were put in for a man named Jones, and if we waited a little longer Jones would come, but I was not paying particular attentionâ€”Marshall was living in Usk Street at that time.

ALBERT PEARCE (Detective Sergeant). I was with Cole. I took the prisoners to the stable and showed them the goods, and then took them back to the house and told them they would be taken to the Borough; Leigh said, "Can't you wait? there are more than us in it; the others
will be there presently"; Marshall said, "Yes, we must see Mr. Jones; he will be home soon."
Cross-examined. Marshall lives in Usk Street, five or ten minutes' walk from the Tap Houseâ€”I have seen him about that neighbourhoodâ€”I heard Leigh say that he knew nothing about the watches.

JOHN BAPTISTE KAPPER . I am chief clerk to Messrs. Dantiger and Co., of Basle, Switzerlandâ€”the case of which this board with the labels on it formed part was sent to Englandâ€”Dantiger and Co., had a customer named Herman Rayner.

ERNEST HARTJEN . I am a clerk to Schaeffer and Co., of 28, Watling Street, watch manufacturersâ€”I received this invoice D from J. C. Greadybill, of Slurier, near Basleâ€”the numbers of five of the watches produced at the Police-court tally with numbers on this invoiceâ€”the five are worth Â£2.
Cross-examined. They are worth ten shillings eachâ€”this (produced) is a two-guinea one.

HERMAN WAGNER . I am a watch manufacturer in Switzerlandâ€”I have no establishment in England, but a relation of mine hasâ€”in August this year I received the invoice marked F, but did not receive the goods till I got some of them from the policeâ€”they corresponded with the numbers in the invoiceâ€”this board was addressed by my clerkâ€”the goods in the invoice are worth about Â£300; I have not got them all back.

GEORGE STOCKWELL . I am a continental carrier, of King Street, Cheapsideâ€”on August 24th I received the invoice B, and sent a man to London Bridge Station to get the goods, but he did not get themâ€”I did not authorise Tillard or Jones to get them for me, and I did not receive themâ€”I have seen some goods at the Police-station which correspond with those mentioned in the invoice.

MARSHALL,
GUILTY .â€”He then PLEADED GUILTY** to a conviction in February, 1888, in the name of
Alfred Doveâ€”
Seven Years' Penal Servitude.
LEIGH,
GUILTY â€”
Four Years' Penal Servitude.

874.
THOMAS FRANKS (20)
PLEADED GUILTY to burglary in the dwelling-house of
Samuel Sheard, with intent to steal; also
to breaking into the dwelling-house of
Mary Ann Elsey, and stealing one pair sugar tongs, three coats and other articles.â€”
Six Months' Hard Labour.

875.
CAROLINE CHENNELL (35)
, to unlawfully procuring
Emily Channell, aged fourteen years, to have carnal connection with
William Lucas and other persons.â€”
Twelve Months' Hard Labour.
[Pleaded guilty: See original trial image.]

876.
GEORGE PRENTICE (24)
, to feloniously marrying
Mary Ann Gage, his wife being alive.â€”
Eighteen Months' Hard Labour.
[Pleaded guilty: See original trial image.]

877.
THOMAS BAIGENT (17)
, to unlaw
fully attempting to carnally know
Edith Mabel Gosden, aged seven years.â€”
Twelve Months' Hard Labour.
[Pleaded guilty: See original trial image.]

878.
LEONARD MORRISON WHITNEY (18)
, to burglary in the dwelling-house of
Elam Ellis, and stealing 1s. 2d. and a pair of bootsâ€”
Three Days' Imprisonment, having been two months in custody.
[Pleaded guilty: See original trial image.] And

(879).
RICHARD HERBERT TERRY DRAPER (14), and
CHARLES ALFRED HELSDON (15),
to burglary in the dwelling-house of Cordelia Weeks, and stealing a quantity of tea and other articles.â€”
[Pleaded guilty: See original trial image.] Recommended to mercy by the prosecutrix. â€”
Four Days' Imprisonment each.

880.
ARTHUR TAYLOR (24)
, Burglariously breaking into the dwelling-house of
Henry Barnes, with intent to steal.

HENRY BARNES (L 152). On 26th October, about 3.30 a.m., I was with Sergeant Mobsby in Lower Kennington Laneâ€”Mr. Lewis made a communication to us, and we examined his place and found a broken window in the rearâ€”we searched the place, but found no one insideâ€”I went outside; the sergeant assisted me to get up on a warehouse, and I found the prisoner crouched in a gutter about twenty yards offâ€”he got up and ran along the warehouse about twenty yards, and jumped down to the ground, about ten feet, and then commenced scaling the walls in the rear of Readwell Streetâ€”I followed him, and about the twelfth wall I came up to him, but at the third wall I cut my wrist, and therefore I could not hold himâ€”he said, "No one b----man shall take me"â€”he struggled on the ground, and I drew my truncheon with my left hand and struck him on his headâ€”the occupier of the house came and assisted me to take him to the stationâ€”he said he knew nothing about itâ€”I found nothing on him; a cap was brought to the station.

JACOB MOBSBY (L 22). I was with Barnes about 3.30 a.m.â€”I went to the King's Arms public-house and found the fanlight fittings unscrewed and laid down, and the fanlight had dropped down and was openâ€”I searched the back premises, but found no oneâ€”I put Barnes on top of a warehouse at No. 60, and shortly afterwards saw the prisoner in custodyâ€”this knife was found open in the yard of No. 62, and a cap in the yard of No. 76â€”the prisoner owned the cap but not the knifeâ€”the cap fitted him; he had passed over the spot where the cap and knife were found.

EDWARD HENRY LEWIS .
