I keep the King's Arms, Lower Kennington Laneâ€”on September 26th, when I went to bed, the house was quite safe; the fanlight was left a little way down for ventilationâ€”the fittings were secureâ€”after I went to bed I heard a movement, and afterwards heard the smash of plate-glassâ€”I went downstairs and called the policeâ€”I found the fanlight down and the window underneath brokenâ€”I fancy I have seen the prisoner in the house once or twice as a customer; and I think he was there the same eveningâ€”two fittings outside the fanlight had been taken off and laid down.

Prisoner's Defence. I came from Canada to see my mother, and found she was dead. I had no money, and laid on this shed, and seeing a dazzling light I jumped up and cut my face, and got over the wall, and fell down senseless, and the constable took me. I said, "Don't handle me roughly," but he drew his staff, knocked me on my head, and dragged me to the station. I do not know where the house is. I have been away from England nine years.
NOT GUILTY .

881.
JOHN COUSINS (20)
PLEADED GUILTY to burglary in the dwelling-house of
Spencer Best, with intent to steal.â€”
Twelve Months' Hard Labour. And

(882)
WILLIAM HUNT (20),
To stealing Â£1 2s. 6d. from the person of
William Stanley; also* to a conviction of felony in July, 1891.â€”
Ten Months' Hard Labour.
[Pleaded guilty: See original trial image.]

883.
EDWARD BARLEY (32) and
EDWARD ADAMS (36)
, Unlawfully committing certain acts of gross indecency with each other.
MR. ALLEYNE Prosecuted, MR. CORSER appeared for Barley, and MR. BURNIE for Adams.

BARLEY,
NOT GUILTY . ADAMS,
GUILTY *.â€”
Twelve Months' Hard Labour.

884.
ALFRED IVORY (39)
, Carnally knowing
Elizabeth Harriet Boulter, a girl under thirteen; Second Count, attempting to carnally know her.

The Prosecutrix not understanding the nature of an oath, MR. WARBURTON submitted that the charge could not be substantiated, as there was no evidence to corroborate her statement. MR. ROACH agreed that there was no corrobo
ration, and THE COMMON SERJEANT directed a verdict of
NOT GUILTY .

885.
ALFRED WINTER (42)
, Unlawfully and indecently assaulting
Jessie Cutler, a girl under thirteen.
NOT GUILTY .

886.
JOHN CORNELL (20) and
WILLIAM GREEN (22)
, Rob
bery, with another man, not in custody, with violence, on
Thomas Nichol
son, and stealing one chain, six seals, and one stone.

THOMAS NICHOLSON . I am an insurance agent, and live at Guernsey Lodge, Surbitonâ€”on 24th August, between 10.30 and 10.45 a.m. I was at Waterloo Station, waiting for my train, and having half an hour to spare I walked outside into Waterloo Roadâ€”I was standing looking at a billâ€”there men were standing thereâ€”Green, who was one of them, rushed on me and snatched my chain and seals, and ran away with itâ€”I ran after him calling, "Stop thief!" I ran up a dark street for himâ€”he went up a ladder to escape out of a door leading into Waterloo Station; the door was locked, and just as I was getting hold of him Cornell came up and kicked me on my right foot and left leg, and they pitched me on to my head, and if it had not been for the silk hat I was wearing, I should have broken my head and lost my lifeâ€”I got up and called, "Police!" and they ran awayâ€”the value of my chain and seals was Â£20â€”they did not get my watch, they broke the chainâ€”this is one of the seals; it was afterwards foundâ€”in consequence of this assault I was some time under the doctor's careâ€”on the Saturday following I identified the prisoners from among othersâ€”I have no doubt about them.

Cross-examined by MR. ROACH. I have described what occurred as being momentary; it was very cleverly doneâ€”the light of a street lamp was on their countenances very brilliantly, and I could pick them out from a thousand menâ€”I identified Cornell from among others at once by his height and clothes.
Cross-examined by Green. You had dark clothes on, and a low hat, pretty well over your eyes.
Re-examined. I have not the slightest doubt they are the two men.

ALFRED CAMBER (Detective L). I heard of this robbery on the evening of 24th August, and on the 28th, with Darby, I arrested Cornellâ€”I said, "I am a police officer; I shall arrest you on suspicion, answering the description of a man wanted for highway robbery on the 24th"â€”he said, "All right, I will go with you, but I hope you get the others"â€”
on the 29th we wired for Mr. Nicholson, and the two prisoners were placed among seven or eight others, and he came and identified them.
Cross-examined by MR. ROACH. Cornell said nothing about my having made a mistake.

EDWARD DARBY (Detective L). I was with Camber when he arrested Cornellâ€”I arrested Green outside the station in Kennington Road on the morning of the 29thâ€”I told him I should arrest him for being con
cerned with Hines and Cornell for stealing a gold chain and sealsâ€”he replied, "I am innocent of it; I don't know the other two; I went to the Surrey Theatre that night"â€”I said, "What time did you leave the Surrey Theatre?"â€”he said, "At half-past eleven"â€”I said, "What did you see?"â€”he said "The English Rose"â€”I said, "Tell me who you were with, and I will tell him to attend the Court"â€”he said, "I was with myself, but I came out with Mrs. Cummings and her daughter, who live at Cornwall Road, but it is no good going to them; I am going to plead guilty, and have it settled here"â€”Cornell said, "Yes, we are both going to plead guilty, as we don't want to go to the Sessions; but we are both innocent of this."
Cross-examined by MR. ROACH. The Cummings were not at the Court; Green refused to give me their addressâ€”he said it was no good troubling them to attend.

WILLIAM HENRY BENT . I am a carman, of 5, Cross Street, Waterloo Roadâ€”on 25th August, at half-past four a.m., I found this locket in Cross Street, Waterloo Road, under the railway archâ€”I gave it to the police.

DANIEL JOHN HARDY . I am landlord of 2, Morford Place, Lambethâ€”Cornell has lodged with me for some timeâ€”he works as a labourerâ€”on 24th August he went out at 6.30 dressed in his Sunday clothes; he and Green both went out together in their Sunday clothesâ€”their friends have since pawned those clothesâ€”I next saw him about twelve in the Corn
wall Road; that is not a stone's throw from Waterloo Stationâ€”I have known Cornell between three and four years; I don't know what charac
ter he bears.

THOMAS WILLIAM CAMP . I am a master builderâ€”I have known Cornell about fourteen yearsâ€”I was with Cornell up to about nine p.m. on 24th August; he said he was going to the Surrey Theatreâ€”I met him again about five or ten minutes to twelve in the Waterloo Road, not far from the station.

p.hi: Green, in his defence, stated that he had been to the theatre on this evening, and knew nothing of the robbery. He called

div1.p:
ELIZA CUMMINGS . I am married, and live at 124 1/2, Cornwall Road, Lambethâ€”on Monday night, 24th August, I met Green, whom I have known from a child, at the Surrey Theatre, at nine o'clockâ€”we left him inside, and came outside to have refreshment, and we went back againâ€”we did not see Green again till we came out when it was all over at 11.30; he was by himselfâ€”he left us at the Pear Tree, at the corner of Corn
wall Road, about 11.45â€”a young lady was with usâ€”he had a black suit, collar, and tie on.

ALICE CHAMPION . I am single, and live at 124 1/2, Cornwall Road, Lambethâ€”on 24th August I saw Green at the Surrey Theatre, about nineâ€”we saw no more of him till 11.30, when we saw him outside, and
he came down the Waterloo Road as far as the Pear Tree, with Mrs. Cummings and me.

GUILTY . GREEN was further charged with a conviction of felony in April, 1891, to which he PLEADED GUILTYâ€”
Twelve Months' Hard Labour.
CORNELLâ€”
Nine Months' Hard Labour.

p.hi: The case of Sidney Kershaw, removed to this Court from the Manchester Assizes, was also tried this Session.

div1.p: ADJOURNED TO MONDAY, NOVEMBER 16TH, 1891.

Alexander Scott.. 943.. Twelve Months' Hard Labour.
George Edward Rogers.. 1052.. Four Days' Imprisonment.

Ashton Leslie, alias
Horace Liddington .. 1053.. Three Days' Imprisonment.
Julius Spitzel.. 1082.. Three Years' Penal Servitude.
Charles Marsden.. 1148.. Eighteen Months' Hard Labour.
Joseph Arthur Armstrong.. 1153.. Two Days' Imprisonment.
Albert Isaacs.. 1187.. Twelve Months' Hard Labour.
William Charles Mitchell.. 1193.. Discharged on Recognisances.
